paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter THESEUS, HIPPOLYTA, and PHILOSTRATE, with others$NEWLINE$THESEUS$NEWLINE$HIPPOLYTA$NEWLINE$PHILOSTRATE
paragraphs.translated: THESEUS and HIPPOLYTA enter with PHILOSTRATE and others.$NEWLINE$THESEUS$NEWLINE$HIPPOLYTA$NEWLINE$PHILOSTRATE

paragraphs.original: THESEUS$NEWLINE$Now, fair Hippolyta, our nuptial hour$NEWLINE$Draws on apace. Four happy days bring in$NEWLINE$Another moon. But oh, methinks how slow$NEWLINE$This old moon wanes! She lingers my desires,$NEWLINE$Like to a stepdame or a dowager$NEWLINE$Long withering out a young man’s revenue.
paragraphs.translated: THESEUS$NEWLINE$Our wedding day is almost here, my beautiful Hippolyta. We’ll be getting married in four days, on the day of the new moon. But it seems to me that the days are passing too slowly—the old moon is taking too long to fade away! That old, slow moon is keeping me from getting what I want, just like an old widow makes her stepson wait to get his inheritance.

paragraphs.original: HIPPOLYTA$NEWLINE$Four days will quickly steep themselves in night.$NEWLINE$Four nights will quickly dream away the time.$NEWLINE$And then the moon, like to a silver bow$NEWLINE$New bent in heaven, shall behold the night$NEWLINE$Of our solemnities.
paragraphs.translated: HIPPOLYTA$NEWLINE$No, you’ll see, four days will quickly turn into four nights. And since we dream at night, time passes quickly then. Finally the new moon, curved like a silver bow in the sky, will look down on our wedding celebration.

paragraphs.original: THESEUS$NEWLINE$Go, Philostrate,$NEWLINE$Stir up the Athenian youth to merriments.$NEWLINE$Awake the pert and nimble spirit of mirth.$NEWLINE$Turn melancholy forth to funerals.$NEWLINE$The pale companion is not for our pomp.
paragraphs.translated: THESEUS$NEWLINE$Go, Philostrate, get the young people of Athens ready to celebrate and have a good time. Sadness is only appropriate for funerals. We don’t want it at our festivities.

paragraphs.original: Exit PHILOSTRATE$NEWLINE$PHILOSTRATE
paragraphs.translated: PHILOSTRATE exits.$NEWLINE$PHILOSTRATE

paragraphs.original: Hippolyta, I wooed thee with my sword$NEWLINE$And won thy love doing thee injuries.$NEWLINE$But I will wed thee in another key,$NEWLINE$With pomp, with triumph, and with reveling.
paragraphs.translated: Hippolyta, I wooed you with violence, using my sword, and got you to fall in love with me by injuring you. But I’ll marry you under different circumstances—with extravagant festivals, public festivities, and celebration.

paragraphs.original: Enter EGEUS and his daughter HERMIA, and LYSANDER and DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$EGEUS$NEWLINE$HERMIA$NEWLINE$LYSANDER$NEWLINE$DEMETRIUS
paragraphs.translated: EGEUS enters with his daughter HERMIA, and LYSANDER and DEMETRIUS.$NEWLINE$EGEUS$NEWLINE$HERMIA$NEWLINE$LYSANDER$NEWLINE$DEMETRIUS

paragraphs.original: EGEUS$NEWLINE$Happy be Theseus, our renownèd duke.
paragraphs.translated: EGEUS$NEWLINE$Long live Theseus, our famous and respected duke!

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: THESEUS$NEWLINE$Thanks, good Egeus. What’s the news with thee?
paragraphs.translated: THESEUS$NEWLINE$Thanks, good Egeus. What’s new with you?

paragraphs.original: EGEUS$NEWLINE$Full of vexation come I with complaint$NEWLINE$Against my child, my daughter Hermia.—$NEWLINE$Stand forth, Demetrius.—My noble lord,$NEWLINE$This man hath my consent to marry her.—$NEWLINE$Stand forth, Lysander.—And my gracious duke,$NEWLINE$This man hath bewitched the bosom of my child.—$NEWLINE$Thou, thou, Lysander, thou hast given her rhymes,$NEWLINE$And interchanged love tokens with my child.$NEWLINE$Thou hast by moonlight at her window sung$NEWLINE$With feigning voice verses of feigning love,$NEWLINE$And stol'n the impression of her fantasy$NEWLINE$With bracelets of thy hair, rings, gauds, conceits,$NEWLINE$Knacks, trifles, nosegays, sweetmeats—messengers$NEWLINE$Of strong prevailment in unhardened youth.$NEWLINE$With cunning hast thou filched my daughter’s heart,$NEWLINE$Turned her obedience (which is due to me)$NEWLINE$To stubborn harshness.—And, my gracious duke,$NEWLINE$Be it so she will not here before your grace$NEWLINE$Consent to marry with Demetrius,$NEWLINE$I beg the ancient privilege of Athens.$NEWLINE$As she is mine, I may dispose of her—$NEWLINE$Which shall be either to this gentleman$NEWLINE$Or to her death—according to our law$NEWLINE$Immediately provided in that case.
paragraphs.translated: EGEUS$NEWLINE$I’m here, full of anger, to complain about my daughter Hermia.—Step forward, Demetrius.—My lord, this man, Demetrius, has my permission to marry her.—Step forward, Lysander.—But this other man, Lysander, has cast a magic spell over my child’s heart.—You, you, Lysander, you’ve given her poems, and exchanged tokens of love with my daughter. You’ve pretended to be in love with her, singing fake love songs softly at her window by moonlight, and you’ve captured her imagination by giving her locks of your hair, rings, toys, trinkets, knickknacks, little presents, flowers, and candies—things that can really influence an impressionable young person. You’ve connived to steal my daughter’s heart, making her stubborn and harsh instead of obedient (like she should be).—And, my gracious duke, if she won’t agree to marry Demetrius right now, I ask you to let me exercise the right that all fathers have in Athens. Since she belongs to me, I can do what I want with her—as the law says: I can either make her marry Demetrius—or have her killed.

paragraphs.original: THESEUS$NEWLINE$What say you, Hermia? Be advised, fair maid:$NEWLINE$To you your father should be as a god,$NEWLINE$One that composed your beauties, yea, and one$NEWLINE$To whom you are but as a form in wax,$NEWLINE$By him imprinted and within his power$NEWLINE$To leave the figure or disfigure it.$NEWLINE$Demetrius is a worthy gentleman.
paragraphs.translated: THESEUS$NEWLINE$What do you have to say for yourself, Hermia? Think carefully, pretty girl. You should think of your father as a god, since he’s the one who gave you your beauty. To him, you’re like a figure that he’s sculpted out of wax, and he has the power to keep that figure intact or to disfigure it. Demetrius is an admirable man.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: HERMIA$NEWLINE$So is Lysander.
paragraphs.translated: HERMIA$NEWLINE$So is Lysander.

paragraphs.original: THESEUS$NEWLINE$In himself he is.$NEWLINE$But in this kind, wanting your father’s voice,$NEWLINE$The other must be held the worthier.
paragraphs.translated: THESEUS$NEWLINE$You’re right, Lysander’s admirable too. But since your father doesn’t want him to marry you, you have to consider Demetrius to be the better man.

paragraphs.original: HERMIA$NEWLINE$I would my father looked but with my eyes.
paragraphs.translated: HERMIA$NEWLINE$I wish my father could see them with my eyes.

paragraphs.original: THESEUS$NEWLINE$Rather your eyes must with his judgment look.
paragraphs.translated: THESEUS$NEWLINE$No, you must see them as your father sees them.

paragraphs.original: HERMIA$NEWLINE$I do entreat your grace to pardon me.$NEWLINE$I know not by what power I am made bold$NEWLINE$Nor how it may concern my modesty$NEWLINE$In such a presence here to plead my thoughts,$NEWLINE$But I beseech your grace that I may know$NEWLINE$The worst that may befall me in this case,$NEWLINE$If I refuse to wed Demetrius.
paragraphs.translated: HERMIA$NEWLINE$Your grace, please forgive me. I don’t know what makes me think I can say this, and I don’t know if speaking my mind to such a powerful and noble person as yourself will damage my reputation for modesty. But please, tell me the worst thing that could happen to me if I refuse to marry Demetrius.

paragraphs.original: THESEUS$NEWLINE$Either to die the death or to abjure$NEWLINE$Forever the society of men.$NEWLINE$Therefore, fair Hermia, question your desires.$NEWLINE$Know of your youth. Examine well your blood—$NEWLINE$Whether, if you yield not to your father’s choice,$NEWLINE$You can endure the livery of a nun,$NEWLINE$For aye to be in shady cloister mewed,$NEWLINE$To live a barren sister all your life,$NEWLINE$Chanting faint hymns to the cold, fruitless moon.$NEWLINE$Thrice-blessèd they that master so their blood$NEWLINE$To undergo such maiden pilgrimage.$NEWLINE$But earthlier happy is the rose distilled$NEWLINE$Than that which, withering on the virgin thorn,$NEWLINE$Grows, lives, and dies in single blessedness.
paragraphs.translated: THESEUS$NEWLINE$You’ll either be executed or you’ll never see another man again. So think carefully about what you want, beautiful Hermia. Consider how young you are, and question your feelings. Then decide whether you could stand to be a nun, wearing a priestess’s habit and caged up in a cloister forever, living your entire life without a husband or children, weakly chanting hymns to the cold and virginal goddess of the moon. People who can restrain their passions and stay virgins forever are holy. But although a virgin priestess might be rewarded in heaven, a married woman is happier on Earth. A married woman is like a rose who is picked and made into a beautiful perfume, while a priestess just withers away on the stem.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: HERMIA$NEWLINE$So will I grow, so live, so die, my lord,$NEWLINE$Ere I will yield my virgin patent up$NEWLINE$Unto his lordship, whose unwishèd yoke$NEWLINE$My soul consents not to give sovereignty.
paragraphs.translated: HERMIA$NEWLINE$I’d rather wither away than give up my virginity to someone I don’t love.

paragraphs.original: THESEUS$NEWLINE$Take time to pause, and by the next new moon—$NEWLINE$The sealing day betwixt my love and me$NEWLINE$For everlasting bond of fellowship—$NEWLINE$Upon that day either prepare to die$NEWLINE$For disobedience to your father’s will,$NEWLINE$Or else to wed Demetrius, as he would,$NEWLINE$Or on Diana’s altar to protest$NEWLINE$For aye austerity and single life.
paragraphs.translated: THESEUS$NEWLINE$Take some time to think about this. By the time of the next new moon—the day when Hippolyta and I will be married—be ready either to be executed for disobeying your father, to marry Demetrius as your father wishes, or to take a vow to spend the rest of your life as a virgin priestess of the moon goddess.

paragraphs.original: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$Relent, sweet Hermia—And, Lysander, yield$NEWLINE$Thy crazèd title to my certain right.
paragraphs.translated: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$Please give in, sweet Hermia.—And Lysander, stop acting like she’s yours. I’ve got more of a right to her than you do.

paragraphs.original: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$You have her father’s love, Demetrius.$NEWLINE$Let me have Hermia’s. Do you marry him.
paragraphs.translated: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$Her father loves you, Demetrius. So why don’t you marry him and let me have Hermia?

paragraphs.original: EGEUS$NEWLINE$Scornful Lysander, true, he hath my love,$NEWLINE$And what is mine my love shall render him.$NEWLINE$And she is mine, and all my right of her$NEWLINE$I do estate unto Demetrius.
paragraphs.translated: EGEUS$NEWLINE$It’s true, rude Lysander, I do love him. That’s why I’m giving him my daughter. She’s mine, and I’m giving her to Demetrius.

paragraphs.original: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$(to THESEUS) I am, my lord, as well derived as he,$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$As well possessed. My love is more than his.$NEWLINE$My fortunes every way as fairly ranked,$NEWLINE$(If not with vantage) as Demetrius'.$NEWLINE$And—which is more than all these boasts can be—$NEWLINE$I am beloved of beauteous Hermia.$NEWLINE$Why should not I then prosecute my right?$NEWLINE$Demetrius, I’ll avouch it to his head,$NEWLINE$Made love to Nedar’s daughter, Helena,$NEWLINE$And won her soul. And she, sweet lady, dotes,$NEWLINE$Devoutly dotes, dotes in idolatry$NEWLINE$Upon this spotted and inconstant man.
paragraphs.translated: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$(to THESEUS) My lord, I’m just as noble and rich as he is. I love Hermia more than he does. My prospects are as good as his, if not better. And beautiful Hermia loves me—which is more important than all those other things I’m bragging about. Why shouldn’t I be able to marry her? Demetrius—and I’ll say this to his face—courted Nedar’s daughter, Helena, and made her fall in love with him. That sweet lady, Helena, loves devoutly. She adores this horrible and unfaithful man.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: THESEUS$NEWLINE$I must confess that I have heard so much$NEWLINE$And with Demetrius thought to have spoke thereof,$NEWLINE$But being overfull of self-affairs,$NEWLINE$My mind did lose it.—But, Demetrius, come.$NEWLINE$And come, Egeus. You shall go with me.$NEWLINE$I have some private schooling for you both.—$NEWLINE$For you, fair Hermia, look you arm yourself$NEWLINE$To fit your fancies to your father’s will,$NEWLINE$Or else the law of Athens yields you up$NEWLINE$(Which by no means we may extenuate)$NEWLINE$To death, or to a vow of single life.—$NEWLINE$Come, my Hippolyta. What cheer, my love?—$NEWLINE$Demetrius and Egeus, go along.$NEWLINE$I must employ you in some business$NEWLINE$Against our nuptial and confer with you$NEWLINE$Of something nearly that concerns yourselves.
paragraphs.translated: THESEUS$NEWLINE$I have to admit I’ve heard something about that, and meant to ask Demetrius about it, but I was too busy with personal matters and it slipped my mind.—Anyway, Demetrius and Egeus, both of you, come with me. I want to say a few things to you in private.—As for you, beautiful Hermia, get ready to do what your father wants, because otherwise the law says that you must die or become a nun, and there’s nothing I can do about that.—Come with me, Hippolyta. How are you, my love?—Demetrius and Egeus, come with us. I want you to do some things for our wedding, and I also want to discuss something that concerns you both.

paragraphs.original: EGEUS$NEWLINE$With duty and desire we follow you.
paragraphs.translated: EGEUS$NEWLINE$We’re following you not only because it is our duty, but also because we want to.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt. Manent LYSANDER and HERMIA$NEWLINE$LYSANDER$NEWLINE$HERMIA
paragraphs.translated: They all exit except LYSANDER and HERMIA.$NEWLINE$LYSANDER$NEWLINE$HERMIA

paragraphs.original: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$How now, my love? Why is your cheek so pale?$NEWLINE$How chance the roses there do fade so fast?
paragraphs.translated: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$What’s going on, my love? Why are you so pale? Why have your rosy cheeks faded so quickly?

paragraphs.original: HERMIA$NEWLINE$Belike for want of rain, which I could well$NEWLINE$Beteem them from the tempest of my eyes.
paragraphs.translated: HERMIA$NEWLINE$Probably because my cheeks' roses needed rain, which I could easily give them with all the tears in my eyes.

paragraphs.original: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$Ay me! For aught that I could ever read,$NEWLINE$Could ever hear by tale or history,$NEWLINE$The course of true love never did run smooth.$NEWLINE$But either it was different in blood—
paragraphs.translated: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$Oh, honey! Listen, in books they say that true love always faces obstacles. Either the lovers have different social standings—

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: HERMIA$NEWLINE$O cross! Too high to be enthralled to low.
paragraphs.translated: HERMIA$NEWLINE$Oh, what an obstacle that would be! Imagine being too high on the social ladder, and falling in love with someone beneath you.

paragraphs.original: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$Or else misgraffèd in respect of years—
paragraphs.translated: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$Or else they were very different ages—

paragraphs.original: HERMIA$NEWLINE$O spite! Too old to be engaged to young.
paragraphs.translated: HERMIA$NEWLINE$How awful! Being too old to marry someone young.

paragraphs.original: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$Or else it stood upon the choice of friends—
paragraphs.translated: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$Or else their guardians and advisors said no—

paragraphs.original: HERMIA$NEWLINE$O hell, to choose love by another’s eyes!
paragraphs.translated: HERMIA$NEWLINE$What hell, to have your love life determined by someone else!

paragraphs.original: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$Or, if there were a sympathy in choice,$NEWLINE$War, death, or sickness did lay siege to it,$NEWLINE$Making it momentary as a sound,$NEWLINE$Swift as a shadow, short as any dream,$NEWLINE$Brief as the lightning in the collied night;$NEWLINE$That, in a spleen, unfolds both heaven and Earth,$NEWLINE$And ere a man hath power to say “Behold!”$NEWLINE$The jaws of darkness do devour it up.$NEWLINE$So quick bright things come to confusion.
paragraphs.translated: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$Or, even if the lovers are a good match, their love might be ruined by war, death, or sickness, so that the affair only lasts an instant. Their time together might be as fleeting as a shadow or as short as a dream, lasting only as long as it takes a lightning bolt to flash across the sky. Before you can say “look,” it’s gone. That’s how intense things like love are quickly destroyed.

paragraphs.original: HERMIA$NEWLINE$If then true lovers have been ever crossed,$NEWLINE$It stands as an edict in destiny.$NEWLINE$Then let us teach our trial patience,$NEWLINE$Because it is a customary cross,$NEWLINE$As due to love as thoughts and dreams and sighs,$NEWLINE$Wishes and tears, poor fancy’s followers.
paragraphs.translated: HERMIA$NEWLINE$If true lovers are always thwarted, then it must be a rule of fate. So let’s try to be patient as we deal with our problem. It’s as normal a part of love as dreams, sighs, wishes, and tears.

paragraphs.original: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$A good persuasion. Therefore, hear me, Hermia.$NEWLINE$I have a widow aunt, a dowager$NEWLINE$Of great revenue, and she hath no child.$NEWLINE$From Athens is her house remote seven leagues,$NEWLINE$And she respects me as her only son.$NEWLINE$There, gentle Hermia, may I marry thee.$NEWLINE$And to that place the sharp Athenian law$NEWLINE$Cannot pursue us. If thou lovest me then,$NEWLINE$Steal forth thy father’s house tomorrow night.$NEWLINE$And in the wood, a league without the town—
paragraphs.translated: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$That’s the right attitude. So, listen, Hermia. I have an aunt who is a widow, who’s very rich and doesn’t have any children. She lives about twenty miles from Athens, and she thinks of me as a son. I could marry you there, gentle Hermia, where the strict laws of Athens can’t touch us. So here’s the plan. If you love me, sneak out of your father’s house tomorrow night and meet me in the forest a few miles outside of town.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Where I did meet thee once with Helena$NEWLINE$To do observance to a morn of May—$NEWLINE$There will I stay for thee.
paragraphs.translated: You remember the place—I met you there once with Helena to celebrate May Day.—I’ll wait for you there.

paragraphs.original: HERMIA$NEWLINE$My good Lysander!$NEWLINE$I swear to thee by Cupid’s strongest bow,$NEWLINE$By his best arrow with the golden head,$NEWLINE$By the simplicity of Venus' doves,$NEWLINE$By that which knitteth souls and prospers loves,$NEWLINE$And by that fire which burned the Carthage queen$NEWLINE$When the false Troyan under sail was seen,$NEWLINE$By all the vows that ever men have broke$NEWLINE$(In number more than ever women spoke),$NEWLINE$In that same place thou hast appointed me,$NEWLINE$Tomorrow truly will I meet with thee.
paragraphs.translated: HERMIA$NEWLINE$Oh, Lysander, I swear I’ll be there tomorrow. I swear by Cupid’s strongest bow and his best gold-tipped arrow, by the Goddess of Love’s innocent doves, by everything that ties lovers together, by the bonfire where Queen Dido burned herself to death when her lover Aeneas jilted her, and by all the promises that men have broken (and men have broken more promises than women have ever made). I give you my word, I will meet you at that spot tomorrow.

paragraphs.original: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$Keep promise, love. Look, here comes Helena.
paragraphs.translated: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$Keep your promise, my love. Look, here comes Helena.

paragraphs.original: Enter HELENA$NEWLINE$HELENA
paragraphs.translated: HELENA enters.$NEWLINE$HELENA

paragraphs.original: HERMIA$NEWLINE$Godspeed, fair Helena! Whither away?
paragraphs.translated: HERMIA$NEWLINE$Hello, beautiful Helena! Where are you going?

paragraphs.original: HELENA$NEWLINE$Call you me “fair”? That “fair” again unsay.$NEWLINE$Demetrius loves your fair. O happy fair!$NEWLINE$Your eyes are lodestars, and your tongue’s sweet air$NEWLINE$More tunable than lark to shepherd’s ear$NEWLINE$When wheat is green, when hawthorn buds appear.$NEWLINE$Sickness is catching. Oh, were favor so,$NEWLINE$Yours would I catch, fair Hermia, ere I go.$NEWLINE$My ear should catch your voice. My eye, your eye.$NEWLINE$My tongue should catch your tongue’s sweet melody.$NEWLINE$Were the world mine, Demetrius being bated,$NEWLINE$The rest I’d give to be to you translated.
paragraphs.translated: HELENA$NEWLINE$Did you just call me “beautiful”? Take it back. You’re the beautiful one as far as Demetrius is concerned. Oh, you’re so lucky! Your eyes are like stars, and your voice is more musical than a lark’s song is to a shepherd in the springtime. Sickness is contagious—I wish beauty were contagious too! I would catch your good looks before I left. My ear would be infected by your voice, my eye by your eye, and my tongue would come down with a bad case of your melodious speech. If the world were mine, I’d give it all up—everything except Demetrius—to be you.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: O, teach me how you look and with what art$NEWLINE$You sway the motion of Demetrius' heart.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, teach me how you look the way you do, and which tricks you used to make Demetrius fall in love with you.

paragraphs.original: HERMIA$NEWLINE$I frown upon him, yet he loves me still.
paragraphs.translated: HERMIA$NEWLINE$I frown at him, but he still loves me.

paragraphs.original: HELENA$NEWLINE$Oh, that your frowns would teach my smiles such skill!
paragraphs.translated: HELENA$NEWLINE$Oh, if only my smiles could inspire love as effectively as your frowns!

paragraphs.original: HERMIA$NEWLINE$I give him curses, yet he gives me love.
paragraphs.translated: HERMIA$NEWLINE$I curse him, but he loves me.

paragraphs.original: HELENA$NEWLINE$Oh, that my prayers could such affection move!
paragraphs.translated: HELENA$NEWLINE$If only my prayers could inspire that kind of affection!

paragraphs.original: HERMIA$NEWLINE$The more I hate, the more he follows me.
paragraphs.translated: HERMIA$NEWLINE$The more I hate him, the more he follows me around.

paragraphs.original: HELENA$NEWLINE$The more I love, the more he hateth me.
paragraphs.translated: HELENA$NEWLINE$The more I love him, the more he hates me.

paragraphs.original: HERMIA$NEWLINE$His folly, Helena, is no fault of mine.
paragraphs.translated: HERMIA$NEWLINE$It’s not my fault he acts like that, Helena.

paragraphs.original: HELENA$NEWLINE$None, but your beauty. Would that fault were mine!
paragraphs.translated: HELENA$NEWLINE$That’s true, it’s your beauty’s fault. I wish I had a fault like that!

paragraphs.original: HERMIA$NEWLINE$Take comfort. He no more shall see my face.$NEWLINE$Lysander and myself will fly this place.$NEWLINE$Before the time I did Lysander see$NEWLINE$Seemed Athens as a paradise to me.$NEWLINE$Oh, then, what graces in my love do dwell,$NEWLINE$That he hath turned a heaven unto a hell!
paragraphs.translated: HERMIA$NEWLINE$Don’t worry. He won’t see my face ever again. Lysander and I are running away from here. Before I saw Lysander, Athens seemed like paradise to me. But Lysander’s so attractive that he’s turned heaven into hell!

paragraphs.original: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$Helen, to you our minds we will unfold.$NEWLINE$Tomorrow night when Phoebe doth behold$NEWLINE$Her silver visage in the watery glass,$NEWLINE$Decking with liquid pearl the bladed grass$NEWLINE$(A time that lovers' flights doth still conceal),$NEWLINE$Through Athens' gates have we devised to steal.
paragraphs.translated: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$Helena, we’ll tell you about our secret plan. Tomorrow night, when the moon shines on the water and decorates the grass with tiny beads of pearly light (the time of night that always hides runaway lovers), we plan to sneak out of Athens.

paragraphs.original: HERMIA$NEWLINE$(to HELENA) And in the wood where often you and I$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Upon faint primrose beds were wont to lie,$NEWLINE$Emptying our bosoms of their counsel sweet,
paragraphs.translated: HERMIA$NEWLINE$(to HELENA) In the woods where you and I used to lounge around on the pale primroses, telling each other sweet secrets—that’s where Lysander and I will meet.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: There my Lysander and myself shall meet.$NEWLINE$And thence from Athens turn away our eyes$NEWLINE$To seek new friends and stranger companies.$NEWLINE$Farewell, sweet playfellow. Pray thou for us.$NEWLINE$And good luck grant thee thy Demetrius!—$NEWLINE$Keep word, Lysander. We must starve our sight$NEWLINE$From lovers' food till morrow deep midnight.
paragraphs.translated: From then on we’ll turn our backs on Athens. We’ll look for new friends and keep the company of strangers. Goodbye, old friend. Pray for us, and I hope you win over Demetrius!—Keep your promise, Lysander. We need to stay away from each other until midnight tomorrow.

paragraphs.original: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$I will, my Hermia.
paragraphs.translated: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$I will, my Hermia.

paragraphs.original: Exit HERMIA$NEWLINE$HERMIA
paragraphs.translated: HERMIA exits.$NEWLINE$HERMIA

paragraphs.original: Helena, adieu.$NEWLINE$As you on him, Demetrius dote on you!
paragraphs.translated: Goodbye, Helena. I hope Demetrius comes to love you as much as you love him!

paragraphs.original: Exit LYSANDER$NEWLINE$LYSANDER
paragraphs.translated: LYSANDER exits.$NEWLINE$LYSANDER

paragraphs.original: HELENA$NEWLINE$How happy some o'er other some can be!$NEWLINE$Through Athens I am thought as fair as she.$NEWLINE$But what of that? Demetrius thinks not so.$NEWLINE$He will not know what all but he do know.$NEWLINE$And as he errs, doting on Hermia’s eyes,$NEWLINE$So I, admiring of his qualities.$NEWLINE$Things base and vile, holding no quantity,$NEWLINE$Love can transpose to form and dignity.$NEWLINE$Love looks not with the eyes but with the mind.$NEWLINE$And therefore is winged Cupid painted blind.$NEWLINE$Nor hath Love’s mind of any judgment taste—$NEWLINE$Wings and no eyes figure unheedy haste.$NEWLINE$And therefore is Love said to be a child,$NEWLINE$Because in choice he is so oft beguiled.$NEWLINE$As waggish boys in game themselves forswear,$NEWLINE$So the boy Love is perjured everywhere.$NEWLINE$For ere Demetrius looked on Hermia’s eyne,$NEWLINE$He hailed down oaths that he was only mine.
paragraphs.translated: HELENA$NEWLINE$It’s amazing how much happier some people are than others! People throughout Athens think I’m as beautiful as Hermia. But so what? Demetrius doesn’t think so, and that’s all that matters. He refuses to admit what everyone else knows. But even though he’s making a mistake by obsessing over Hermia so much, I’m also making a mistake, since I obsess over him. Love can make worthless things beautiful. When we’re in love, we don’t see with our eyes but with our minds. That’s why paintings of Cupid, the god of love, always show him as blind. And love doesn’t have good judgment either—Cupid, has wings and no eyes, so he’s bound to be reckless and hasty. That’s why they say love is a child. because it makes such bad choices. Just as boys like to play games by telling lies, Cupid breaks his promises all the time. Before Demetrius ever saw Hermia, he showered me with promises and swore he’d be mine forever.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: And when this hail some heat from Hermia felt,$NEWLINE$So he dissolved, and showers of oaths did melt.$NEWLINE$I will go tell him of fair Hermia’s flight.$NEWLINE$Then to the wood will he tomorrow night$NEWLINE$Pursue her. And for this intelligence$NEWLINE$If I have thanks, it is a dear expense.$NEWLINE$But herein mean I to enrich my pain,$NEWLINE$To have his sight thither and back again.
paragraphs.translated: But when he got all hot and bothered over Hermia, his promises melted away. I’ll go tell Demetrius that Hermia is running away tomorrow night. He’ll run after her. If he’s grateful to me for this information, it’ll be worth my pain in helping him pursue my rival Hermia. At least I’ll get to see him when he goes, and then again when he comes back.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: HERMIA exits.$NEWLINE$HERMIA

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter QUINCE the carpenter, and SNUG the joiner, and BOTTOM the weaver, and FLUTE the bellows-mender, and SNOUT the tinker, and STARVELING the tailor$NEWLINE$QUINCE$NEWLINE$SNUG$NEWLINE$BOTTOM$NEWLINE$FLUTE$NEWLINE$SNOUT$NEWLINE$STARVELING
paragraphs.translated: QUINCE, the carpenter, enters with SNUG, the cabinetmaker; BOTTOM, the weaver; FLUTE, the bellows-repairman; SNOUT, the handyman; and STARVELING, the tailor.$NEWLINE$QUINCE$NEWLINE$SNUG$NEWLINE$BOTTOM$NEWLINE$FLUTE$NEWLINE$SNOUT$NEWLINE$STARVELING

paragraphs.original: QUINCE$NEWLINE$Is all our company here?
paragraphs.translated: QUINCE$NEWLINE$Is everyone here?

paragraphs.original: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$You were best to call them generally, man by man, according to the scrip.
paragraphs.translated:
BOTTOM$NEWLINE$You should call their names
generally, one person at a time, in the order in which their names appear on this piece of paper.$NEWLINE$generally,$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: QUINCE$NEWLINE$Here is the scroll of every man’s name which is thought fit, through all Athens, to play in our interlude before the duke and the duchess, on his wedding day at night.
paragraphs.translated: QUINCE$NEWLINE$This is a list of the names of all the men in Athens who are good enough to act in the play we’re going to perform for the duke and duchess on their wedding night.

paragraphs.original: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$First, good Peter Quince, say what the play treats on, then read the names of the actors, and so grow to a point.
paragraphs.translated: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$First, Peter Quince, tell us what the play is about, then read the names of the actors, and then shut up.

paragraphs.original: QUINCE$NEWLINE$Marry, our play is The most lamentable comedy and most cruel death of Pyramus and Thisbe.$NEWLINE$cruel death of Pyramus and Thisbe
paragraphs.translated: QUINCE$NEWLINE$All right. Our play is called A Very Tragic Comedy About the Horrible Deaths of Pyramus and Thisbe.$NEWLINE$A Very Tragic Comedy About the Horrible Deaths of Pyramus and Thisbe

paragraphs.original: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$A very good piece of work, I assure you, and a merry.—Now, good Peter Quince, call forth your actors by the scroll.—Masters, spread yourselves.
paragraphs.translated: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$Let me tell you, it’s a great piece of work, and very—funny.—Now, Peter Quince, call the names of the actors on the list. Men, gather around him.

paragraphs.original: QUINCE$NEWLINE$Answer as I call you.—Nick Bottom, the weaver?
paragraphs.translated: QUINCE$NEWLINE$Answer when I call your name.—Nick Bottom, the weaver?

paragraphs.original: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$Ready. Name what part I am for and proceed.
paragraphs.translated: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$Here. Tell me which part I’m going to play, then go on.

paragraphs.original: QUINCE$NEWLINE$You, Nick Bottom, are set down for Pyramus.
paragraphs.translated: QUINCE$NEWLINE$You, Nick Bottom, have been cast as Pyramus.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original:
BOTTOM$NEWLINE$What is Pyramus? A lover or a
tyrant?$NEWLINE$tyrant?$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$
paragraphs.translated: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$What’s Pyramus? A lover or a tyrant?

paragraphs.original: QUINCE$NEWLINE$A lover that kills himself, most gallant, for love.
paragraphs.translated: QUINCE$NEWLINE$A lover who kills himself very nobly for love.

paragraphs.original: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$That will ask some tears in the true performing of it. If I do it, let the audience look to their eyes. I will move storms. I will condole in some measure.—To the rest.—Yet my chief humor is for a tyrant. I could play Ercles rarely, or a part to tear a cat in to make all split.$NEWLINE$The raging rocks$NEWLINE$The raging rocks$NEWLINE$And shivering shocks$NEWLINE$And shivering shocks$NEWLINE$Shall break the locks$NEWLINE$Shall break the locks$NEWLINE$Of prison gates.$NEWLINE$Of prison gates$NEWLINE$And Phoebus' car$NEWLINE$And Phoebus' car$NEWLINE$Shall shine from far$NEWLINE$Shall shine from far$NEWLINE$And make and mar$NEWLINE$And make and mar$NEWLINE$The foolish Fates.$NEWLINE$The foolish Fates$NEWLINE$This was lofty!—Now name the rest of the players.—This is Ercles' vein, a tyrant’s vein. A lover is more condoling.
paragraphs.translated: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$I’ll have to cry to make my performance believable. And as soon as I start crying, oh boy, the audience had better watch out, because they’ll start crying too. I’ll make tears pour out of their eyes like rainstorms. I’ll moan very believably.—Name the other actors.—But I’m really in the mood to play a tyrant. I could do a great job with Hercules, or any other part that requires ranting and raving. I would rant and rave really well. Like this, listen.$NEWLINE$The raging rocks$NEWLINE$The raging rocks$NEWLINE$nd shivering shocks$NEWLINE$nd shivering shocks$NEWLINE$Will break the locks$NEWLINE$Will break the locks$NEWLINE$Of prison gates.$NEWLINE$Of prison gates$NEWLINE$And the sun-god’s car$NEWLINE$And the sun-god’s car$NEWLINE$Will shine from far$NEWLINE$Will shine from far$NEWLINE$Away, and make and mar$NEWLINE$Away, and make and mar$NEWLINE$Foolish fate.$NEWLINE$Foolish fate$NEWLINE$Oh, that was truly inspired!—Now tell us who the other actors are.—By the way, my performance just now was in the style of Hercules, the tyrant style. A lover would have to be weepier, of course.

paragraphs.original: QUINCE$NEWLINE$Francis Flute, the bellows-mender?
paragraphs.translated: QUINCE$NEWLINE$Francis Flute, the bellows-repairman?

paragraphs.original: FLUTE$NEWLINE$Here, Peter Quince.
paragraphs.translated: FLUTE$NEWLINE$Here, Peter Quince.

paragraphs.original: QUINCE$NEWLINE$Flute, you must take Thisbe on you.
paragraphs.translated: QUINCE$NEWLINE$Flute, you’ll be playing the role of Thisbe.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FLUTE$NEWLINE$What is Thisbe? A wandering knight?
paragraphs.translated: FLUTE$NEWLINE$Who’s Thisbe? A knight on a quest?

paragraphs.original: QUINCE$NEWLINE$It is the lady that Pyramus must love.
paragraphs.translated: QUINCE$NEWLINE$Thisbe is the lady Pyramus is in love with.

paragraphs.original: FLUTE$NEWLINE$Nay, faith, let me not play a woman. I have a beard coming.
paragraphs.translated: FLUTE$NEWLINE$No, come on, don’t make me play a woman. I’m growing a beard.

paragraphs.original: QUINCE$NEWLINE$That’s all one. You shall play it in a mask, and you may speak as small as you will.
paragraphs.translated: QUINCE$NEWLINE$That doesn’t matter. You’ll wear a mask, and you can make your voice as high as you want to.

paragraphs.original: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$An I may hide my face, let me play Thisbe too! I’ll speak in a monstrous little voice: “Thisne, Thisne!”—“Ah, Pyramus, my lover dear, thy Thisbe dear and lady dear!”
paragraphs.translated: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$In that case, if I can wear a mask, let me play Thisbe too! I’ll be Pyramus first: “Thisne, Thisne!”—And then in falsetto: “Ah, Pyramus, my dear lover! I’m your dear Thisbe, your dear lady!”

paragraphs.original: QUINCE$NEWLINE$No, no. You must play Pyramus.—And Flute, you Thisbe.
paragraphs.translated: QUINCE$NEWLINE$No, no. Bottom, you’re Pyramus.—And Flute, you’re Thisbe.

paragraphs.original: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$Well, proceed.
paragraphs.translated: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$All right. Go on.

paragraphs.original: QUINCE$NEWLINE$Robin Starveling, the tailor?
paragraphs.translated: QUINCE$NEWLINE$Robin Starveling, the tailor?

paragraphs.original: STARVELING$NEWLINE$Here, Peter Quince.
paragraphs.translated: STARVELING$NEWLINE$Here, Peter Quince.

paragraphs.original: QUINCE$NEWLINE$Robin Starveling, you must play Thisbe’s mother.—Tom Snout, the tinker?
paragraphs.translated: QUINCE$NEWLINE$Robin Starveling, you’re going to play Thisbe’s mother.—Tom Snout, the handyman.

paragraphs.original: SNOUT$NEWLINE$Here, Peter Quince.
paragraphs.translated: SNOUT$NEWLINE$Here, Peter Quince.

paragraphs.original: QUINCE$NEWLINE$You, Pyramus' father.—Myself, Thisbe’s father.—Snug the joiner, you, the lion’s part.—And I hope here is a play fitted.
paragraphs.translated: QUINCE$NEWLINE$You’ll be Pyramus’s father—I’ll play Thisbe’s father myself—Snug, the cabinetmaker, you’ll play the part of the lion.—So that’s everyone. I hope this play is well cast now.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SNUG$NEWLINE$Have you the lion’s part written? Pray you, if it be, give it me, for I am slow of study.
paragraphs.translated: SNUG$NEWLINE$Do you have the lion’s part written down? If you do, please give it to me, because I need to start learning the lines. It takes me a long time to learn things.

paragraphs.original: QUINCE$NEWLINE$You may do it extempore, for it is nothing but roaring.
paragraphs.translated: QUINCE$NEWLINE$You can improvise the whole thing. It’s just roaring.

paragraphs.original: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$Let me play the lion too. I will roar, that I will do any man’s heart good to hear me. I will roar, that I will make the duke say, “Let him roar again. Let him roar again.”
paragraphs.translated: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$Let me play the lion too. I’ll roar so well that it’ll be an inspiration to anyone who hears me. I’ll roar so well that the duke will say, “Let him roar again. Let him roar again.”

paragraphs.original: QUINCE$NEWLINE$An you should do it too terribly, you would fright the duchess and the ladies, that they would shriek. And that were enough to hang us all.
paragraphs.translated: QUINCE$NEWLINE$If you roar too ferociously, you’ll scare the duchess and the other ladies and make them scream. And that would get us all executed.

paragraphs.original: ALL$NEWLINE$That would hang us, every mother’s son.
paragraphs.translated: ALL$NEWLINE$Yeah, that would get every single one of us executed.

paragraphs.original: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$I grant you, friends, if you should fright the ladies out of their wits, they would have no more discretion but to hang us. But I will aggravate my voice so that I will roar you as gently as any sucking dove. I will roar you an ’twere any nightingale.
paragraphs.translated:
BOTTOM$NEWLINE$Well, my friends, you’ve got to admit that if you scare the living daylights out of the ladies, they’d have no choice but to execute us. But I’ll soften my voice—you know,
aggravate it, so to speak—so that I’ll roar as gently as a baby dove. I’ll roar like a sweet, peaceful nightingale.$NEWLINE$aggravate$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: QUINCE$NEWLINE$You can play no part but Pyramus. For Pyramus is a sweet-faced man, a proper man as one shall see in a summer’s day, a most lovely, gentlemanlike man. Therefore you must needs play Pyramus.
paragraphs.translated: QUINCE$NEWLINE$You can’t play any part except Pyramus. Because Pyramus is a good-looking man, the most handsome man that you could find on a summer’s day, a lovely gentlemanly man. So you’re the only one who could play Pyramus.

paragraphs.original: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$Well, I will undertake it. What beard were I best to play it in?
paragraphs.translated: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$Well then, I’ll do it. What kind of beard should I wear for the part?

paragraphs.original: QUINCE$NEWLINE$Why, what you will.
paragraphs.translated: QUINCE$NEWLINE$Whatever kind you want, I guess.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$I will discharge it in either your straw-color beard, your orange-tawny beard, your purple-in-grain beard, or your French crown-color beard, your perfect yellow.
paragraphs.translated: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$I’ll play the part wearing either a straw-colored beard, or a sandy beard, or a red beard, or one of those bright yellow beards that’s the color of a French coin.

paragraphs.original: QUINCE$NEWLINE$Some of your French crowns have no hair at all, and then you will play barefaced.—But masters, here are your parts. And I am to entreat you, request you, and desire you to con them by tomorrow night and meet me in the palace wood, a mile without the town, by moonlight. There will we rehearse, for if we meet in the city we shall be dogged with company, and our devices known. In the meantime I will draw a bill of properties such as our play wants. I pray you, fail me not.
paragraphs.translated: QUINCE$NEWLINE$Some French people don’t have beards at all, because syphilis has made all their hair fall out, so you might have to play the part clean-shaven.—But gentlemen, here are your scripts, and I beg you to please learn them by tomorrow night. Meet me in the duke’s forest a mile outside of town. It’s best to rehearse there, because if we do it here in the city, we’ll be bothered by crowds of people and everyone will know the plot of our play. Meanwhile, I’ll make a list of props that we’ll need for the play. Now make sure you show up, all of you. Don’t leave me in the lurch.

paragraphs.original: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$We will meet, and there we may rehearse most obscenely and courageously. Take pains. Be perfect. Adieu.
paragraphs.translated: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$We’ll be there, and there we’ll rehearse courageously and wonderfully, truly obscenely. Work hard, know your lines. Goodbye.

paragraphs.original: QUINCE$NEWLINE$At the duke’s oak we meet.
paragraphs.translated: QUINCE$NEWLINE$We’ll meet at the giant oak tree in the duke’s forest.

paragraphs.original: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$Enough. Hold, or cut bowstrings.
paragraphs.translated: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$Got it? Be there, or don’t show your face again.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter a FAIRY at one side and ROBIN (ROBIN GOODFELLOW) at another$NEWLINE$FAIRY$NEWLINE$ROBIN$NEWLINE$ROBIN GOODFELLOW
paragraphs.translated: A FAIRY and ROBIN GOODFELLOW (a “puck” or mischievous spirit) meet onstage.$NEWLINE$FAIRY$NEWLINE$ROBIN GOODFELLOW

paragraphs.original: ROBIN$NEWLINE$How now, spirit? Whither wander you?
paragraphs.translated: ROBIN$NEWLINE$Hello, spirit! Where are you going?

paragraphs.original: FAIRY$NEWLINE$Over hill, over dale,$NEWLINE$Thorough bush, thorough brier,$NEWLINE$Over park, over pale,$NEWLINE$Thorough flood, thorough fire.$NEWLINE$I do wander everywhere$NEWLINE$Swifter than the moon’s sphere.$NEWLINE$And I serve the fairy queen$NEWLINE$To dew her orbs upon the green.$NEWLINE$The cowslips tall her pensioners be.$NEWLINE$In their gold coats spots you see.$NEWLINE$Those be rubies, fairy favors.$NEWLINE$In those freckles live their savors.$NEWLINE$I must go seek some dewdrops here$NEWLINE$And hang a pearl in every cowslip’s ear.$NEWLINE$Farewell, thou lob of spirits. I’ll be gone.$NEWLINE$Our queen and all our elves come here anon.
paragraphs.translated: FAIRY$NEWLINE$I go over hills and valleys, through bushes and thorns, over parks and fenced-in spaces, through water and fire. I wander everywhere faster than the moon revolves around the Earth. I work for Titania, the Fairy Queen, and organize fairy dances for her in the grass. The cowslip flowers are her bodyguards. You’ll see that their petals have spots on them—those are rubies, fairy gifts. Their sweet smells come from those little freckles. Now I have to go find some dewdrops and hang a pearl earring on every cowslip flower. Goodbye, you dumb old spirit. I’ve got to go. The queen and her elves will be here soon.

paragraphs.original: ROBIN$NEWLINE$The king doth keep his revels here tonight.$NEWLINE$Take heed the queen come not within his sight.$NEWLINE$For Oberon is passing fell and wrath$NEWLINE$Because that she, as her attendant hath$NEWLINE$A lovely boy stolen from an Indian king.$NEWLINE$She never had so sweet a changeling.$NEWLINE$And jealous Oberon would have the child$NEWLINE$Knight of his train, to trace the forests wild.$NEWLINE$But she perforce withholds the lovèd boy,$NEWLINE$Crowns him with flowers, and makes him all her joy.
paragraphs.translated: ROBIN$NEWLINE$The king’s having a party here tonight. Just make sure the queen doesn’t come anywhere near him, because King Oberon is extremely angry. He’s furious because she stole an adorable boy from an Indian king. She’s never kidnapped such a darling human child before, and Oberon’s jealous. He wants the child for himself, to accompany him on his wanderings through the wild forests. But the queen refuses to hand the boy over to Oberon. Instead, she puts flowers in the boy’s hair and makes a fuss over him.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: And now they never meet in grove or green,$NEWLINE$By fountain clear or spangled starlight sheen.$NEWLINE$But they do square, that all their elves for fear$NEWLINE$Creep into acorn cups and hide them there.
paragraphs.translated: And now Oberon and Titania refuse to speak to each other, or meet each other anywhere—neither in the forest nor on the plain, nor by the river nor under the stars. They always argue, and the little fairies get so frightened that they hide in acorn cups and won’t come out.

paragraphs.original: FAIRY$NEWLINE$Either I mistake your shape and making quite,$NEWLINE$Or else you are that shrewd and knavish sprite$NEWLINE$Called Robin Goodfellow. Are not you he$NEWLINE$That frights the maidens of the villagery,$NEWLINE$Skim milk, and sometimes labor in the quern$NEWLINE$And bootless make the breathless housewife churn,$NEWLINE$And sometime make the drink to bear no barm,$NEWLINE$Mislead night-wanderers, laughing at their harm?$NEWLINE$Those that “Hobgoblin” call you, and “sweet Puck,”$NEWLINE$You do their work, and they shall have good luck.$NEWLINE$Are not you he?
paragraphs.translated: FAIRY$NEWLINE$Unless I’m mistaken, you’re that mischievous and naughty spirit named Robin Goodfellow. Aren’t you the one who goes around scaring the maidens in the village, stealing the cream from the top of the milk, screwing up the flour mills, and frustrating housewives by keeping their milk from turning into butter? Aren’t you the one who keeps beer from foaming up as it should, and causes people to get lost at night, while you laugh at them? Some people call you “Hobgoblin” and “sweet Puck,” and you’re nice to them. You do their work for them and give them good luck. That’s you, right?

paragraphs.original: ROBIN$NEWLINE$Thou speak’st aright.$NEWLINE$I am that merry wanderer of the night.$NEWLINE$I jest to Oberon and make him smile$NEWLINE$When I a fat and bean-fed horse beguile,$NEWLINE$Neighing in likeness of a filly foal.$NEWLINE$And sometime lurk I in a gossip’s bowl$NEWLINE$In very likeness of a roasted crab,$NEWLINE$And when she drinks, against her lips I bob$NEWLINE$And on her withered dewlap pour the ale.$NEWLINE$The wisest aunt telling the saddest tale$NEWLINE$Sometime for three-foot stool mistaketh me.$NEWLINE$Then slip I from her bum, down topples she,$NEWLINE$And “Tailor!” cries, and falls into a cough,$NEWLINE$And then the whole quire hold their hips and laugh,$NEWLINE$And waxen in their mirth, and neeze, and swear$NEWLINE$A merrier hour was never wasted there.$NEWLINE$But, room, fairy! Here comes Oberon.
paragraphs.translated: ROBIN$NEWLINE$What you say is true. That’s me you’re talking about, the playful wanderer of the night. I tell jokes to Oberon and make him smile. I’ll trick a fat, well-fed horse into thinking that I’m a young female horse. Sometimes I hide at the bottom of an old woman’s drink disguised as an apple. When she takes a sip, I bob up against her lips and make her spill the drink all over her withered old neck. Sometimes a wise old woman with a sad story to tell tries to sit down on me, thinking I’m a three-legged stool. But I slip from underneath her and she falls down, crying, “Ow, my butt!” and starts coughing, and then everyone laughs and has fun. But step aside, fairy! Here comes Oberon.

paragraphs.original: FAIRY$NEWLINE$And here my mistress. Would that he were gone!
paragraphs.translated: FAIRY$NEWLINE$And here’s my mistress, Titania. I wish he’d go away!

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter OBERON, the King of Fairies, at one side with his train, and TITANIA, the Queen, at the other, with hers$NEWLINE$OBERON$NEWLINE$TITANIA
paragraphs.translated: OBERON, the Fairy King, and his followers enter. On the opposite side of the stage, TITANIA, the Fairy Queen, and her followers enter.$NEWLINE$OBERON$NEWLINE$TITANIA

paragraphs.original: OBERON$NEWLINE$Ill met by moonlight, proud Titania.
paragraphs.translated: OBERON$NEWLINE$How not nice to see you, Titania.$NEWLINE$not

paragraphs.original: TITANIA$NEWLINE$What, jealous Oberon?—Fairies, skip hence.$NEWLINE$I have forsworn his bed and company.
paragraphs.translated: TITANIA$NEWLINE$What, are you jealous, Oberon?—Fairies, let’s get out of here. I’ve sworn I’ll never sleep with him or talk to him again.

paragraphs.original: OBERON$NEWLINE$Tarry, rash wanton. Am not I thy lord?
paragraphs.translated: OBERON$NEWLINE$Wait just a minute, you brazen hussy. Aren’t you supposed to obey me, your lord and husband?

paragraphs.original: TITANIA$NEWLINE$Then I must be thy lady. But I know$NEWLINE$When thou hast stolen away from Fairyland,$NEWLINE$And in the shape of Corin sat all day,$NEWLINE$Playing on pipes of corn and versing love$NEWLINE$To amorous Phillida. Why art thou here,$NEWLINE$Come from the farthest step of India?$NEWLINE$But that, forsooth, the bouncing Amazon,$NEWLINE$Your buskined mistress and your warrior love,$NEWLINE$To Theseus must be wedded, and you come$NEWLINE$To give their bed joy and prosperity.
paragraphs.translated: TITANIA$NEWLINE$If you’re my lord and husband, I must be your lady and wife, so you’re supposed to be faithful to me. But I know for a fact that you snuck away from Fairyland disguised as a shepherd, and spent all day playing straw pipes and singing love poems to your new girlfriend. The only reason you left India was to come here and see that butch Amazon Hippolyta. She was your boot-wearing mistress and your warrior lover, and now that she’s getting married to Theseus, you’ve come to celebrate their marriage.

paragraphs.original: OBERON$NEWLINE$How canst thou thus for shame, Titania,$NEWLINE$Knowing I know thy love to Theseus? Glance at my credit with Hippolyta,$NEWLINE$Didst thou not lead him through the glimmering night$NEWLINE$From Perigouna, whom he ravishèd?$NEWLINE$And make him with fair Ægles break his faith,$NEWLINE$With Ariadne and Antiopa?
paragraphs.translated: OBERON$NEWLINE$How can you stand there shamelessly talking about me and Hippolyta, when you know that I know about your love for Theseus? Weren’t you the one who made him desert Perigouna in the middle of the night, right after he’d raped her? And weren’t you the one who made him cheat on all of his other girlfriends, like Aegles, Ariadne, and Antiopa?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: TITANIA$NEWLINE$These are the forgeries of jealousy.$NEWLINE$And never, since the middle summer’s spring,$NEWLINE$Met we on hill, in dale, forest, or mead,$NEWLINE$By pavèd fountain, or by rushy brook,$NEWLINE$Or in the beachèd margent of the sea,$NEWLINE$To dance our ringlets to the whistling wind,$NEWLINE$But with thy brawls thou hast disturbed our sport.$NEWLINE$Therefore the winds, piping to us in vain,$NEWLINE$As in revenge, have sucked up from the sea$NEWLINE$Contagious fogs, which falling in the land$NEWLINE$Have every pelting river made so proud$NEWLINE$That they have overborne their continents.$NEWLINE$The ox hath therefore stretched his yoke in vain,$NEWLINE$The ploughman lost his sweat, and the green corn$NEWLINE$Hath rotted ere his youth attained a beard.$NEWLINE$The fold stands empty in the drownèd field,$NEWLINE$And crows are fatted with the murrain flock.$NEWLINE$The nine-men’s-morris is filled up with mud,$NEWLINE$And the quaint mazes in the wanton green$NEWLINE$For lack of tread are undistinguishable.$NEWLINE$The human mortals want their winter here.$NEWLINE$No night is now with hymn or carol blessed.$NEWLINE$Therefore the moon, the governess of floods,$NEWLINE$Pale in her anger, washes all the air,$NEWLINE$That rheumatic diseases do abound.$NEWLINE$And thorough this distemperature we see$NEWLINE$The seasons alter: hoary-headed frosts$NEWLINE$Fall in the fresh lap of the crimson rose,$NEWLINE$And on old Hiems' thin and icy crown$NEWLINE$An odorous chaplet of sweet summer buds$NEWLINE$Is, as in mockery, set. The spring, the summer,$NEWLINE$The childing autumn, angry winter change$NEWLINE$Their wonted liveries, and the mazèd world,$NEWLINE$By their increase, now knows not which is which.$NEWLINE$And this same progeny of evils comes$NEWLINE$From our debate, from our dissension.$NEWLINE$We are their parents and original.
paragraphs.translated: TITANIA$NEWLINE$These are nothing but jealous lies. Since the beginning of midsummer, my fairies and I haven’t been able to meet anywhere to do our dances in the wind without being disturbed by you and your arguments. We haven’t been able to meet on a hill or in a valley, in the forest or a meadow, by a pebbly fountain or a rushing stream, or on the beach by the ocean without you disturbing us. And because you interrupt us so that we can’t dance for them, the winds have made fogs rise up out of the sea and fall down on the rivers so that the rivers flood, just to get revenge on you. So all the work that oxen and farmers have done in plowing the fields has been for nothing, because the unripe grain has rotted before it was ripe. Sheep pens are empty in the middle of the flooded fields, and the crows get fat from eating the dead bodies of infected sheep. All the fields where people usually play games are filled with mud, and you can’t even see the elaborate mazes that people create in the grass, because no one walks in them anymore and they’ve all grown over. It’s not winter here for the human mortals, so they’re not protected by the holy hymns and carols that they sing in winter. So the pale, angry moon, who controls the tides, fills the air with diseases. As a consequence of this bad weather and these bad moods the seasons have started to change. Cold frosts spread over the red roses, and the icy winter wears a crown of sweet summer flowers as some sick joke. Spring, summer, fertile autumn and angry winter have all changed places, and now the confused world doesn’t know which is which. And this is all because of our argument. We are responsible for this.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: OBERON$NEWLINE$Do you amend it then. It lies in you.$NEWLINE$Why should Titania cross her Oberon?$NEWLINE$I do but beg a little changeling boy,$NEWLINE$To be my henchman.
paragraphs.translated: OBERON$NEWLINE$Do something about it, then. You have the power to fix it. Why would Titania want to argue with her Oberon? All I’m asking for is to have that little human boy as part of my crew.

paragraphs.original: TITANIA$NEWLINE$Set your heart at rest.$NEWLINE$The Fairyland buys not the child of me.$NEWLINE$His mother was a votaress of my order,$NEWLINE$And in the spicèd Indian air by night$NEWLINE$Full often hath she gossiped by my side,$NEWLINE$And sat with me on Neptune’s yellow sands,$NEWLINE$Marking th' embarkèd traders on the flood,$NEWLINE$When we have laughed to see the sails conceive$NEWLINE$And grow big-bellied with the wanton wind;$NEWLINE$Which she, with pretty and with swimming gait$NEWLINE$Following—her womb then rich with my young squire—$NEWLINE$Would imitate, and sail upon the land$NEWLINE$To fetch me trifles and return again$NEWLINE$As from a voyage, rich with merchandise.$NEWLINE$But she, being mortal, of that boy did die.$NEWLINE$And for her sake do I rear up her boy,$NEWLINE$And for her sake I will not part with him.
paragraphs.translated: TITANIA$NEWLINE$Get over it. I won’t give up this child for all of Fairyland. His mother was one of my worshippers, and we always used to gossip together at night in India, sitting together by the ocean and watching the merchant ships sailing on the ocean. We used to laugh to see the sails fill up with wind so that they looked like they had big, pregnant bellies, as if the wind had gotten them pregnant. She would imitate them—since she was already pregnant with the little boy—and she would go sailing over the land herself to go get me little presents, and come back carrying gifts like she was a ship coming back from a voyage. But since she was a mortal, she died giving birth to that boy, and for her sake I’m raising him and will not give him up.

paragraphs.original: OBERON$NEWLINE$How long within this wood intend you stay?
paragraphs.translated: OBERON$NEWLINE$How long do you plan to stay here in this forest?

paragraphs.original: TITANIA$NEWLINE$Perchance till after Theseus' wedding day.$NEWLINE$If you will patiently dance in our round$NEWLINE$And see our moonlight revels, go with us.$NEWLINE$If not, shun me, and I will spare your haunts.
paragraphs.translated: TITANIA$NEWLINE$Maybe until after Theseus’s wedding day. If you behave yourself and join us in our circle dance and moonlight celebrations, then you can come with us. If not, leave me alone, and I’ll stay away from your turf.

paragraphs.original: OBERON$NEWLINE$Give me that boy and I will go with thee.
paragraphs.translated: OBERON$NEWLINE$Give me that boy and I’ll come with you.

paragraphs.original: TITANIA$NEWLINE$Not for thy fairy kingdom.—Fairies, away!$NEWLINE$We shall chide downright, if I longer stay.
paragraphs.translated: TITANIA$NEWLINE$Not for your entire fairy kingdom.—Come, fairies, let’s go. We’re going to have an out-and-out brawl if I stay any longer.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt TITANIA and her train$NEWLINE$TITANIA
paragraphs.translated: TITANIA and her FAIRIES exit.$NEWLINE$TITANIA$NEWLINE$FAIRIES

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: OBERON$NEWLINE$Well, go thy way. Thou shalt not from this grove$NEWLINE$Till I torment thee for this injury.—(to ROBIN GOODFELLOW)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$My gentle Puck, come hither. Thou rememberest$NEWLINE$Since once I sat upon a promontory$NEWLINE$And heard a mermaid on a dolphin’s back$NEWLINE$Uttering such dulcet and harmonious breath$NEWLINE$That the rude sea grew civil at her song$NEWLINE$And certain stars shot madly from their spheres$NEWLINE$To hear the seamaid’s music?
paragraphs.translated: OBERON$NEWLINE$Well, go on your way, then. You won’t leave this grove until I’ve paid you back for this insult. (to ROBIN GOODFELLOW) My dear Puck, come here. You remember the time when I was sitting on a cliff, and I heard a mermaid sitting on a dolphin’s back sing such a sweet and harmonious song that it calmed the stormy sea and made stars shoot out of the sky so they could hear her better?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ROBIN$NEWLINE$I remember.
paragraphs.translated: ROBIN$NEWLINE$Yes, I remember.

paragraphs.original: OBERON$NEWLINE$That very time I saw (but thou couldst not)$NEWLINE$Flying between the cold moon and the Earth,$NEWLINE$Cupid all armed. A certain aim he took$NEWLINE$At a fair vestal thronèd by the west,$NEWLINE$And loosed his love shaft smartly from his bow$NEWLINE$As it should pierce a hundred thousand hearts.$NEWLINE$But I might see young Cupid’s fiery shaft$NEWLINE$Quenched in the chaste beams of the watery moon,$NEWLINE$And the imperial votaress passèd on,$NEWLINE$In maiden meditation, fancy-free.$NEWLINE$Yet marked I where the bolt of Cupid fell.$NEWLINE$It fell upon a little western flower,$NEWLINE$Before milk-white, now purple with love’s wound.$NEWLINE$And maidens call it “love-in-idleness.”$NEWLINE$Fetch me that flower. The herb I showed thee once.$NEWLINE$The juice of it on sleeping eyelids laid$NEWLINE$Will make or man or woman madly dote$NEWLINE$Upon the next live creature that it sees.$NEWLINE$Fetch me this herb, and be thou here again$NEWLINE$Ere the leviathan can swim a league.
paragraphs.translated: OBERON$NEWLINE$That same night, I saw Cupid flying from the moon to the earth, with all of his arrows ready. (You couldn’t see him, but I could.) He took aim at a beautiful young virgin who was sitting on a throne in the western part of the world, and he shot his arrow of love well enough to have pierced a hundred thousand hearts. But I could see that Cupid’s fiery arrow was put out by watery, virginal moonbeams, so the royal virgin continued her virginal thoughts without being interrupted by thoughts of love. But I paid attention to where Cupid’s arrow fell. It fell on a little western flower, which used to be white as milk but now has turned purple from being wounded by the arrow of love. Young girls call it “love-in-idleness.” Bring me that flower. I showed it to you once. If its juice is put on someone’s eyelids while they’re asleep, that person will fall in love with the next living creature he or she sees. Bring me this plant, and get back here before the sea monster has time to swim three miles.

paragraphs.original: ROBIN$NEWLINE$I’ll put a girdle round about the Earth$NEWLINE$In forty minutes.
paragraphs.translated: ROBIN$NEWLINE$I could go around the world in forty minutes.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Exit ROBIN$NEWLINE$ROBIN
paragraphs.translated: ROBIN exits.$NEWLINE$ROBIN

paragraphs.original: OBERON$NEWLINE$Having once this juice,$NEWLINE$I’ll watch Titania when she is asleep$NEWLINE$And drop the liquor of it in her eyes.$NEWLINE$The next thing then she waking looks upon—$NEWLINE$Be it on lion, bear, or wolf, or bull,$NEWLINE$On meddling monkey or on busy ape—$NEWLINE$She shall pursue it with the soul of love.$NEWLINE$And ere I take this charm from of her sight—$NEWLINE$As I can take it with another herb—$NEWLINE$I’ll make her render up her page to me.$NEWLINE$But who comes here? I am invisible.$NEWLINE$And I will overhear their conference.
paragraphs.translated: OBERON$NEWLINE$When I have the juice of that flower, I’ll trickle some drops of it on Titania’s eyes while she’s sleeping. She’ll fall madly in love with the first thing she sees when she wakes up—even if it’s a lion, a bear, a wolf, a bull, a monkey, or an ape. And before I make her normal again—I can cure her by treating her with another plant—I’ll make her give me that little boy as my page. But who’s that coming this way? I’ll make myself invisible and listen to their conversation.

paragraphs.original: Enter DEMETRIUS, HELENA following him$NEWLINE$DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$HELENA
paragraphs.translated: DEMETRIUS enters, followed by HELENA.$NEWLINE$DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$HELENA

paragraphs.original: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$I love thee not, therefore pursue me not.$NEWLINE$Where is Lysander and fair Hermia?$NEWLINE$The one I’ll stay, the other stayeth me.$NEWLINE$Thou told’st me they were stol'n unto this wood.$NEWLINE$And here am I, and wood within this wood,$NEWLINE$Because I cannot meet my Hermia.$NEWLINE$Hence, get thee gone, and follow me no more.
paragraphs.translated: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$Look, I don’t love you, so stop following me around. Where are Lysander and beautiful Hermia? Lysander I want to stop, but Hermia stops my heart from beating. You told me they escaped into this forest. And here I am, going crazy in the middle of the woods because I can’t find my Hermia. Go away, get out of here, and stop following me.

paragraphs.original: HELENA$NEWLINE$You draw me, you hard-hearted adamant.$NEWLINE$But yet you draw not iron, for my heart$NEWLINE$Is true as steel. Leave you your power to draw,$NEWLINE$And I shall have no power to follow you.
paragraphs.translated: HELENA$NEWLINE$You attract me to you, you cruel magnet! But you must not attract iron, because my heart is as true as steel. If you let go of your power to attract me, I won’t have any power to follow you.

paragraphs.original: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$Do I entice you? Do I speak you fair?$NEWLINE$Or rather, do I not in plainest truth$NEWLINE$Tell you I do not, nor I cannot, love you?
paragraphs.translated: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$Do I ask you to follow me? Do I speak to you kindly? Don’t I tell you in the clearest terms that I do not and cannot love you?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: HELENA$NEWLINE$And even for that do I love you the more.$NEWLINE$I am your spaniel. And, Demetrius,$NEWLINE$The more you beat me, I will fawn on you.$NEWLINE$Use me but as your spaniel—spurn me, strike me,$NEWLINE$Neglect me, lose me. Only give me leave,$NEWLINE$Unworthy as I am, to follow you.$NEWLINE$What worser place can I beg in your love—$NEWLINE$And yet a place of high respect with me—$NEWLINE$Than to be usèd as you use your dog?
paragraphs.translated: HELENA$NEWLINE$Yes, but that makes me love you even more. I’m your little dog, Demetrius. The more you beat me, the more I’ll love you. Treat me like you would treat a dog—kick me, hit me, neglect me, try to lose me. Just let me follow behind you, even though I’m not good enough for you. Could I ask for a worse place in your heart than to be treated as you would treat a dog? And yet I would consider it an honor to be your dog.

paragraphs.original: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$Tempt not too much the hatred of my spirit.$NEWLINE$For I am sick when I do look on thee.
paragraphs.translated: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$Don’t push it. Just looking at you makes me sick.

paragraphs.original: HELENA$NEWLINE$And I am sick when I look not on you.
paragraphs.translated: HELENA$NEWLINE$And I get sick when I can’t look at you.

paragraphs.original: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$You do impeach your modesty too much,$NEWLINE$To leave the city and commit yourself$NEWLINE$Into the hands of one that loves you not,$NEWLINE$To trust the opportunity of night$NEWLINE$And the ill counsel of a desert place$NEWLINE$With the rich worth of your virginity.
paragraphs.translated: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$You’re risking your reputation by leaving the city and stalking someone who doesn’t love you. Standing around alone in a deserted area in the middle of the night isn’t the best way to protect your virginity.

paragraphs.original: HELENA$NEWLINE$Your virtue is my privilege. For that$NEWLINE$It is not night when I do see your face.$NEWLINE$Therefore I think I am not in the night.$NEWLINE$Nor doth this wood lack worlds of company,$NEWLINE$For you in my respect are all the world.$NEWLINE$Then how can it be said I am alone$NEWLINE$When all the world is here to look on me?
paragraphs.translated: HELENA$NEWLINE$I rely on your virtue to protect me. And because I can see your shining face, it doesn’t feel like nighttime to me. This forest doesn’t seem deserted when you’re here, because you are all the world to me. So how can anyone say I’m alone, when the whole world is here to look at me?

paragraphs.original: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$I’ll run from thee and hide me in the brakes,$NEWLINE$And leave thee to the mercy of wild beasts.
paragraphs.translated: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$I’ll run away from you and hide in the bushes, and leave you to the mercy of wild animals.

paragraphs.original: HELENA$NEWLINE$The wildest hath not such a heart as you.$NEWLINE$Run when you will, the story shall be changed.
paragraphs.translated: HELENA$NEWLINE$The wildest animal isn’t as cruel as you are. Run whenever you want to. The story of Daphne and Apollo will be changed:

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Apollo flies and Daphne holds the chase.$NEWLINE$The dove pursues the griffin. The mild hind$NEWLINE$Makes speed to catch the tiger—bootless speed,$NEWLINE$When cowardice pursues and valor flies.
paragraphs.translated: the lustful god Apollo runs away from the virginal nymph Daphne who pursues him, the dove chases after the griffin, which is usually its predator, and the gentle deer tries to hunt down the tiger—speed is useless when the cowardly person chases and the brave person runs away.

paragraphs.original: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$I will not stay thy questions. Let me go.$NEWLINE$Or if thou follow me, do not believe$NEWLINE$But I shall do thee mischief in the wood.
paragraphs.translated: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$I’m not sticking around to listen to you any longer. Leave me alone. Or if you follow me, you’d better understand that I’ll do something bad to you in the forest.

paragraphs.original: HELENA$NEWLINE$Ay, in the temple, in the town, the field$NEWLINE$You do me mischief. Fie, Demetrius!$NEWLINE$Your wrongs do set a scandal on my sex.$NEWLINE$We cannot fight for love as men may do.$NEWLINE$We should be wooed and were not made to woo.
paragraphs.translated: HELENA$NEWLINE$Yes, you already hurt me in the church, in the town, and in the fields. Shame on you, Demetrius! Your behavior is an insult to all women. We cannot fight for love as men can. We should be pursued and courted. We weren’t made to do the pursuing.

paragraphs.original: Exit DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$DEMETRIUS
paragraphs.translated: DEMETRIUS exits.$NEWLINE$DEMETRIUS

paragraphs.original: I’ll follow thee and make a heaven of hell,$NEWLINE$To die upon the hand I love so well.
paragraphs.translated: I’ll follow you and turn this hell I’m in into a kind of heaven. It would be heavenly to be killed by someone I love so much.

paragraphs.original: Exit HELENA$NEWLINE$HELENA
paragraphs.translated: HELENA exits.$NEWLINE$HELENA

paragraphs.original: OBERON$NEWLINE$Fare thee well, nymph. Ere he do leave this grove,$NEWLINE$Thou shalt fly him and he shall seek thy love.
paragraphs.translated: OBERON$NEWLINE$Goodbye, nymph. Before he leaves this part of the forest, you’ll change places: you’ll be the one running away, and he’ll be in love with you.

paragraphs.original: Enter ROBIN$NEWLINE$ROBIN
paragraphs.translated: ROBIN enters.$NEWLINE$ROBIN

paragraphs.original: Hast thou the flower there? Welcome, wanderer.
paragraphs.translated: Do you have the flower? Welcome, traveler.

paragraphs.original: ROBIN$NEWLINE$Ay, there it is.
paragraphs.translated: ROBIN$NEWLINE$Yes, here it is.

paragraphs.original: OBERON$NEWLINE$I pray thee, give it me.$NEWLINE$(takes flower from ROBIN)$NEWLINE$(takes flower from$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$I know a bank where the wild thyme blows,$NEWLINE$Where oxlips and the nodding violet grows,$NEWLINE$Quite overcanopied with luscious woodbine,$NEWLINE$With sweet musk roses and with eglantine.
paragraphs.translated: OBERON$NEWLINE$Please, give it to me. (he takes the flower from ROBIN) I know a place where wild thyme blooms, and oxlips and violets grow. It’s covered over with luscious honeysuckle, sweet muskroses and sweetbrier.$NEWLINE$(he takes the flower from$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: There sleeps Titania sometime of the night,$NEWLINE$Lulled in these flowers with dances and delight.$NEWLINE$And there the snake throws her enameled skin,$NEWLINE$Weed wide enough to wrap a fairy in.$NEWLINE$And with the juice of this I’ll streak her eyes$NEWLINE$And make her full of hateful fantasies.$NEWLINE$(gives ROBIN some of the flower)$NEWLINE$(gives$NEWLINE$some of the flower)$NEWLINE$Take thou some of it and seek through this grove:$NEWLINE$A sweet Athenian lady is in love$NEWLINE$With a disdainful youth. Anoint his eyes.$NEWLINE$But do it when the next thing he espies$NEWLINE$May be the lady. Thou shalt know the man$NEWLINE$By the Athenian garments he hath on.$NEWLINE$Effect it with some care, that he may prove$NEWLINE$More fond on her than she upon her love.$NEWLINE$And look thou meet me ere the first cock crow.
paragraphs.translated: Titania sleeps there sometimes at night, lulled to sleep among the flowers by dances and other delights. Snakes shed their skin there, and the shed skin is wide enough to wrap a fairy in. I’ll put the juice of this flower on Titania’s eyes, and fill her with horrible delusions and desires. (he gives ROBIN part of the flower) You take some of it too, and look around in this part of the forest. A sweet Athenian lady is in love with a young man who wants nothing to do with her. Put some of this flower’s juice on his eyes, and make sure to do it in such a way that the next thing he sees will be the lady. You’ll be able to tell it’s him because he’s wearing Athenian clothes. Do it carefully, so that he’ll end up loving her more than she loves him. And then make sure to meet me before the rooster’s first crow at dawn.$NEWLINE$(he gives$NEWLINE$part of the flower)

paragraphs.original: ROBIN$NEWLINE$Fear not, my lord. Your servant shall do so.
paragraphs.translated: ROBIN$NEWLINE$Don’t worry, sir. I’m at your service.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt severally
paragraphs.translated: They all exit, separately.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter TITANIA, Queen of Fairies, with her train of FAIRIES$NEWLINE$TITANIA$NEWLINE$FAIRIES
paragraphs.translated: TITANIA, the Fairy Queen, enters with her following of FAIRIES.$NEWLINE$TITANIA$NEWLINE$FAIRIES

paragraphs.original: TITANIA$NEWLINE$Come now, a roundel and a fairy song.$NEWLINE$Then for the third part of a minute, hence—$NEWLINE$Some to kill cankers in the musk-rose buds,$NEWLINE$Some war with reremice for their leathern wings$NEWLINE$To make my small elves coats, and some keep back$NEWLINE$The clamorous owl that nightly hoots and wonders$NEWLINE$At our quaint spirits. Sing me now asleep.$NEWLINE$Then to your offices and let me rest.
paragraphs.translated: TITANIA$NEWLINE$Come, dance in a circle and sing a fairy song, and then go off for a while to do your work. Some of you will kill the worms infesting the rosebuds, some of you will fight with bats to get their leathery wings, so we can make coats for my small elves. Some of you will keep that loud owl away, the one that hoots and wonders every night at us dainty fairies. Sing me to sleep now, and then go off to do your duties and let me rest.

paragraphs.translated: The FAIRIES sing.$NEWLINE$FAIRIES

paragraphs.translated: FIRST FAIRY$NEWLINE$(singing)$NEWLINE$(singing)$NEWLINE$Spiders with your webs, stay away.$NEWLINE$Spiders with your webs, stay away$NEWLINE$You long-legged things, begone!$NEWLINE$You long-legged things, begone!

paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: TITANIA sleeps$NEWLINE$TITANIA
paragraphs.translated: TITANIA falls asleep.$NEWLINE$TITANIA

paragraphs.original: SECOND FAIRY$NEWLINE$Hence, away! Now all is well.$NEWLINE$One aloof stand sentinel.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND FAIRY$NEWLINE$Okay, let’s go! Everything’s fine now. One of us will stay and stand guard.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt FAIRIES$NEWLINE$FAIRIES
paragraphs.translated: The FAIRIES exit.$NEWLINE$FAIRIES

paragraphs.original: Enter OBERON$NEWLINE$OBERON
paragraphs.translated: OBERON enters.$NEWLINE$OBERON

paragraphs.original: OBERON$NEWLINE$(squeezing flower juice on TITANIA ’s eyelids)$NEWLINE$(squeezing flower juice on$NEWLINE$’s eyelids)$NEWLINE$What thou seest when thou dost wake,$NEWLINE$Do it for thy true love take.$NEWLINE$Love and languish for his sake.$NEWLINE$Be it ounce or cat or bear,$NEWLINE$Pard or boar with bristled hair,$NEWLINE$In thy eye that shall appear,$NEWLINE$When thou wakest, it is thy dear.$NEWLINE$Wake when some vile thing is near.
paragraphs.translated: OBERON$NEWLINE$(he squeezes flower juice on TITANIA ’s eyelids)$NEWLINE$(he squeezes flower juice on$NEWLINE$’s eyelids)$NEWLINE$Whatever you see first when you wake up, think of it as your true love. Love him and yearn for him, even if he’s a lynx, a cat, a bear, a leopard, or a wild boar. Whatever’s there when you wake up will be dear to you. Wake up when something nasty is nearby.

paragraphs.original: Exit OBERON$NEWLINE$OBERON
paragraphs.translated: OBERON exits.$NEWLINE$OBERON

paragraphs.original: Enter LYSANDER and HERMIA$NEWLINE$LYSANDER$NEWLINE$HERMIA
paragraphs.translated: LYSANDER and HERMIA enter.$NEWLINE$LYSANDER$NEWLINE$HERMIA

paragraphs.original: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$Fair love, you faint with wandering in the wood.$NEWLINE$And to speak troth, I have forgot our way.
paragraphs.translated: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$My love, you look like you’re about to faint from wandering in the woods for so long, and to tell you the truth, I’ve gotten us lost.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: We’ll rest us, Hermia, if you think it good.$NEWLINE$And tarry for the comfort of the day.
paragraphs.translated: We’ll take a rest, if you think it’s a good idea, and wait until daylight when things will be easier.

paragraphs.original: HERMIA$NEWLINE$Be it so, Lysander. Find you out a bed,$NEWLINE$For I upon this bank will rest my head.
paragraphs.translated: HERMIA$NEWLINE$Let’s do that, Lysander. Find something to cushion you while you sleep. I’m going to rest my head on this little slope.

paragraphs.original: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$One turf shall serve as pillow for us both.$NEWLINE$One heart, one bed, two bosoms, and one troth.
paragraphs.translated: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$We can both sleep together on the grass. We’ll have one heart, one bed, two bodies, and one faithful vow.

paragraphs.original: HERMIA$NEWLINE$Nay, good Lysander. For my sake, my dear,$NEWLINE$Lie further off yet. Do not lie so near.
paragraphs.translated: HERMIA$NEWLINE$No, Lysander. Please, for my sake, sleep a little farther away. Don’t sleep so close to me.

paragraphs.original: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$O, take the sense, sweet, of my innocence.$NEWLINE$Love takes the meaning in love’s conference.$NEWLINE$I mean that my heart unto yours is knit$NEWLINE$So that but one heart we can make of it.$NEWLINE$Two bosoms interchainèd with an oath—$NEWLINE$So then two bosoms and a single troth.$NEWLINE$Then by your side no bed room me deny.$NEWLINE$For, lying so, Hermia, I do not lie.
paragraphs.translated: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$Oh, sweetheart, I didn’t mean anything naughty when I said that. When lovers talk to each other, their hearts should understand each other. I just meant that our hearts are joined, so we can almost think of them as one heart. Our two bodies are linked together by the promises we’ve made to each other, so there are two bodies and one faithful vow. So let me sleep next to you. If I lie next to you, I won’t lie to you—I’ll be faithful and respect you.$NEWLINE$next$NEWLINE$to
