paragraphs.original: HERMIA$NEWLINE$Lysander riddles very prettily.$NEWLINE$Now much beshrew my manners and my pride$NEWLINE$If Hermia meant to say Lysander lied.$NEWLINE$But, gentle friend, for love and courtesy$NEWLINE$Lie further off in human modesty.$NEWLINE$Such separation as may well be said$NEWLINE$Becomes a virtuous bachelor and a maid.$NEWLINE$So far be distant. And, good night, sweet friend.$NEWLINE$Thy love ne'er alter till thy sweet life end!
paragraphs.translated: HERMIA$NEWLINE$Lysander’s got a way with words. I would certainly be rude and shameful if I had implied that you were a liar. But please, darling, sleep a little farther away so we can behave properly. It’s only proper for a well-behaved bachelor and a well-behaved girl to be physically separated like this. Stay away for now, and good night, my sweet friend. I hope your love for me remains this strong for your entire life!

paragraphs.original: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$Amen, amen to that fair prayer, say I.$NEWLINE$And then end life when I end loyalty!$NEWLINE$Here is my bed. Sleep give thee all his rest!
paragraphs.translated: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$Amen to that. I hope my life ends before my loyalty to you does. I’ll sleep over here. Sleep well!

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: HERMIA$NEWLINE$With half that wish the wisher’s eyes be pressed!
paragraphs.translated: HERMIA$NEWLINE$You sleep well too.

paragraphs.original: HERMIA and LYSANDER sleep$NEWLINE$HERMIA$NEWLINE$LYSANDER
paragraphs.translated: HERMIA and LYSANDER sleep. ROBIN enters.$NEWLINE$HERMIA$NEWLINE$LYSANDER$NEWLINE$ROBIN

paragraphs.original: Enter ROBIN$NEWLINE$ROBIN

ROBIN$NEWLINE$Through the forest have I gone.$NEWLINE$But Athenian found I none,$NEWLINE$On whose eyes I might approve$NEWLINE$This flower’s force in stirring love.$NEWLINE$(sees LYSANDER and HERMIA)$NEWLINE$(sees$NEWLINE$and$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Night and silence! Who is here?$NEWLINE$Weeds of Athens he doth wear.$NEWLINE$This is he, my master said,$NEWLINE$Despisèd the Athenian maid.$NEWLINE$And here the maiden, sleeping sound$NEWLINE$On the dank and dirty ground.$NEWLINE$Pretty soul! She durst not lie$NEWLINE$Near this lack-love, this kill-courtesy.$NEWLINE$(squeezes flower juice on LYSANDER’s eyelids)$NEWLINE$(squeezes flower juice on$NEWLINE$’s eyelids)$NEWLINE$Churl, upon thy eyes I throw$NEWLINE$All the power this charm doth owe.$NEWLINE$When thou wakest, let love forbid$NEWLINE$Sleep his seat on thy eyelid.$NEWLINE$So awake when I am gone,$NEWLINE$For I must now to Oberon.
paragraphs.translated: ROBIN$NEWLINE$I’ve been through the entire forest, but I haven’t found any Athenian man to use the flower on. (he sees LYSANDER and HERMIA) Wait a second, who’s this? He’s wearing Athenian clothes. This must be the guy who rejected the Athenian girl. And here’s the girl, sleeping soundly on the damp and dirty ground. Pretty girl! She shouldn’t lie near this rude and heartless man. (he puts flower juice on LYSANDER ’s eyelids) Jerk, I throw all the power of this magic charm on your eyes. When you wake up, let love keep you from going back to sleep. Wake up when I’m gone, because now I have to go to Oberon.$NEWLINE$(he sees$NEWLINE$and$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(he puts flower juice on$NEWLINE$’s eyelids)

paragraphs.original: Exit ROBIN$NEWLINE$ROBIN
paragraphs.translated: ROBIN exits.$NEWLINE$ROBIN

paragraphs.original: Enter DEMETRIUS and HELENA, running$NEWLINE$DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$HELENA
paragraphs.translated: DEMETRIUS and HELENA enter, running.$NEWLINE$DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$HELENA

paragraphs.original: HELENA$NEWLINE$Stay, though thou kill me, sweet Demetrius.
paragraphs.translated: HELENA$NEWLINE$Stop, Demetrius! Stop, even if only to kill me.

paragraphs.original: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$I charge thee, hence, and do not haunt me thus.
paragraphs.translated: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$I’m telling you, get out of here, and don’t follow me around like this.

paragraphs.original: HELENA$NEWLINE$O, wilt thou darkling leave me? Do not so.
paragraphs.translated: HELENA$NEWLINE$Oh, will you leave me alone in the dark? Don’t.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$Stay, on thy peril. I alone will go.
paragraphs.translated: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$Stay here at your own risk. I’m going on alone.

paragraphs.original: Exit DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$DEMETRIUS
paragraphs.translated: DEMETRIUS exits.$NEWLINE$DEMETRIUS

paragraphs.original: HELENA$NEWLINE$Oh, I am out of breath in this fond chase.$NEWLINE$The more my prayer, the lesser is my grace.$NEWLINE$Happy is Hermia, wheresoe'er she lies,$NEWLINE$For she hath blessèd and attractive eyes.$NEWLINE$How came her eyes so bright? Not with salt tears.$NEWLINE$If so, my eyes are oftener washed than hers.$NEWLINE$No, no, I am as ugly as a bear,$NEWLINE$For beasts that meet me run away for fear.$NEWLINE$Therefore no marvel though Demetrius$NEWLINE$Do, as a monster, fly my presence thus.$NEWLINE$What wicked and dissembling glass of mine$NEWLINE$Made me compare with Hermia’s sphery eyne?$NEWLINE$(sees LYSANDER)But who is here? Lysander, on the ground?$NEWLINE$(sees$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Dead or asleep? I see no blood, no wound.—$NEWLINE$Lysander, if you live, good sir, awake.
paragraphs.translated: HELENA$NEWLINE$Oh, I’m out of breath from this foolish chase. The more I pray, the less I get out of it. Hermia is lucky, wherever she is, because she has beautiful eyes. How did her eyes get so bright? Not from crying. If that’s the case, tears wash my eyes more than hers. No, no, I’m as ugly as a bear, since animals that see me run away in terror. So it’s no surprise that Demetrius runs away from me as if I were a monster. What evil and deceitful mirror made me think I could rival Hermia’s starry eyes? (she sees LYSANDER) But who’s this here? Lysander, on the ground? Is he dead or sleeping? I don’t see any blood or injuries—Lysander, if you’re alive, wake up.$NEWLINE$(she sees$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$(waking) And run through fire I will for thy sweet sake.$NEWLINE$(waking)$NEWLINE$Transparent Helena! Nature shows art$NEWLINE$That through thy bosom makes me see thy heart.$NEWLINE$Where is Demetrius? Oh, how fit a word$NEWLINE$Is that vile name to perish on my sword!
paragraphs.translated: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$(waking up) I’d even run through fire if you told me to. Radiant, beautiful Helena! I feel like Mother Nature has allowed me to see into your heart, as if by magic. Where is Demetrius? Oh, I’d kill that name with my sword if I could!$NEWLINE$(waking up)

paragraphs.original: HELENA$NEWLINE$Do not say so, Lysander. Say not so.$NEWLINE$What though he love your Hermia? Lord, what though?$NEWLINE$Yet Hermia still loves you. Then be content.
paragraphs.translated: HELENA$NEWLINE$Don’t say that, Lysander. Don’t say that. Why do you care that he loves Hermia? What does it matter? Hermia still loves you, so be happy.

paragraphs.original: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$Content with Hermia? No. I do repent$NEWLINE$The tedious minutes I with her have spent.$NEWLINE$Not Hermia but Helena I love.$NEWLINE$Who will not change a raven for a dove?$NEWLINE$The will of man is by his reason swayed,$NEWLINE$And reason says you are the worthier maid.
paragraphs.translated: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$Happy with Hermia? No. I regret all the boring time I wasted with her. I don’t love Hermia; I love Helena. Who wouldn’t love a dove more than a crow? A man’s desires are influenced by his logical mind, and it’s simply logical that you’re more worthy of love than Hermia is.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Things growing are not ripe until their season.$NEWLINE$So I, being young, till now ripe not to reason.$NEWLINE$And touching now the point of human skill,$NEWLINE$Reason becomes the marshal to my will$NEWLINE$And leads me to your eyes, where I o'erlook$NEWLINE$Love’s stories written in love’s richest book.
paragraphs.translated: Fruits and vegetables don’t ripen until the right season of the year. Likewise, I’m young, and my sense of reason has just ripened. I can finally see the light. My logic has more control over my desires than it used to, and it’s telling me to look into your eyes, where I see every love story ever told.

paragraphs.original: HELENA$NEWLINE$Wherefore was I to this keen mockery born?$NEWLINE$When at your hands did I deserve this scorn?$NEWLINE$Is ’t not enough, is ’t not enough, young man,$NEWLINE$That I did never, no, nor never can,$NEWLINE$Deserve a sweet look from Demetrius' eye,$NEWLINE$But you must flout my insufficiency?$NEWLINE$Good troth, you do me wrong, good sooth, you do,$NEWLINE$In such disdainful manner me to woo.$NEWLINE$But fare you well. Perforce I must confess$NEWLINE$I thought you lord of more true gentleness.$NEWLINE$Oh, that a lady of one man refused$NEWLINE$Should of another therefore be abused!
paragraphs.translated: HELENA$NEWLINE$Why does everyone always make fun of me? What have I done to deserve this kind of treatment from you? Is it not enough, is it not enough, young man, that I’ll never be pretty enough to get a kind look from Demetrius? Do you have to harp on my inadequacy? My God, it’s wrong for you to woo me in such a cruel, disdainful way. But goodbye. I have to tell you, I thought you were a much kinder person than this. Oh, how awful that a lady who’s been rejected by one man should therefore be treated horribly by another one!

paragraphs.original: Exit HELENA$NEWLINE$HELENA
paragraphs.translated: HELENA exits.$NEWLINE$HELENA

paragraphs.original: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$She sees not Hermia.—Hermia, sleep thou there.$NEWLINE$And never mayst thou come Lysander near!$NEWLINE$For as a surfeit of the sweetest things$NEWLINE$The deepest loathing to the stomach brings,$NEWLINE$Or as the heresies that men do leave$NEWLINE$Are hated most of those they did deceive,$NEWLINE$So thou, my surfeit and my heresy,$NEWLINE$Of all be hated, but the most of me.—$NEWLINE$And all my powers, address your love and might$NEWLINE$To honor Helen and to be her knight.
paragraphs.translated: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$She doesn’t see Hermia—Hermia, keep sleeping, and don’t come near me ever again! Eating too many sweets makes people sick to their stomachs, and people always hate the mistakes they made in the past worse than anyone else hates those mistakes. Hermia, you’re the sweet I’ve had too much of, and the mistake I used to make, so I hate you more than anyone else does.—I’ll use all my talents and efforts to serve Helen and bring her honor.

paragraphs.original: Exit LYSANDER$NEWLINE$LYSANDER
paragraphs.translated: LYSANDER exits.$NEWLINE$LYSANDER

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: HERMIA$NEWLINE$(waking) Help me, Lysander, help me! Do thy best$NEWLINE$(waking)$NEWLINE$To pluck this crawling serpent from my breast.$NEWLINE$Ay me, for pity! What a dream was here.$NEWLINE$Lysander, look how I do quake with fear.$NEWLINE$Methought a serpent eat my heart away,$NEWLINE$And you sat smiling at his cruel pray.$NEWLINE$Lysander!—What, removed?—Lysander, lord!—$NEWLINE$What, out of hearing, gone? No sound, no word?—$NEWLINE$Alack, where are you? Speak, an if you hear.$NEWLINE$Speak, of all loves! I swoon almost with fear.$NEWLINE$No? Then I well perceive you all not nigh.$NEWLINE$Either death or you I’ll find immediately.
paragraphs.translated: HERMIA$NEWLINE$(waking up) Help me, Lysander, help me! Get this snake off of my chest. Oh, my God! What a terrible dream I just had! Lysander, look how I’m shaking from fear. I thought a snake was eating my heart while you sat smiling and watching. Lysander!—What, is he gone?—Lysander, my lord!—What, is he out of earshot? Gone? No answer, nothing? Oh, God, where are you? Say something if you can hear me. Say something, please! I’m almost fainting with fear. Nothing? Then I guess you’re nowhere nearby. I’ll find you—or die—right away.$NEWLINE$(waking up)

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: HERMIA exits.$NEWLINE$HERMIA

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: TITANIA sleeps. Enter the clowns: BOTTOM, QUINCE, FLUTE, SNUG, SNOUT, and STARVELING$NEWLINE$TITANIA$NEWLINE$BOTTOM$NEWLINE$QUINCE$NEWLINE$FLUTE$NEWLINE$SNUG$NEWLINE$SNOUT$NEWLINE$STARVELING
paragraphs.translated: While TITANIA is asleep onstage, the clowns—BOTTOM, QUINCE, FLUTE, SNUG, SNOUT, and STARVELING—enter.$NEWLINE$TITANIA$NEWLINE$BOTTOM$NEWLINE$QUINCE$NEWLINE$FLUTE$NEWLINE$SNUG$NEWLINE$SNOUT$NEWLINE$STARVELING

paragraphs.original: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$Are we all met?
paragraphs.translated: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$Are we all here?

paragraphs.original: QUINCE$NEWLINE$Pat, pat. And here’s a marvelous convenient place for our rehearsal. This green plot shall be our stage, this hawthorn-brake our tiring-house, and we will do it in action as we will do it before the duke.
paragraphs.translated: QUINCE$NEWLINE$Right on time. This is the perfect place to rehearse. This clearing will be the stage, and this hawthorn bush will be our dressing room. Let’s put on our play exactly as we’ll perform it for the duke.

paragraphs.original: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$Peter Quince—
paragraphs.translated: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$Peter Quince—

paragraphs.original: QUINCE$NEWLINE$What sayest thou, bully Bottom?
paragraphs.translated: QUINCE$NEWLINE$What is it, jolly Bottom?

paragraphs.original: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$There are things in this comedy of Pyramus and Thisbe that will never please. First, Pyramus must draw a sword to kill himself, which the ladies cannot abide. How answer you that?
paragraphs.translated: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$There are things in this comedy of Pyramus and Thisbe that will never work. First of all, Pyramus has to take out a sword to kill himself, which the ladies in the audience won’t be able to stand. What should we do about that?

paragraphs.original: SNOUT$NEWLINE$By 'r lakin, a parlous fear.
paragraphs.translated: SNOUT$NEWLINE$By God, that’s a real problem, it’s true.

paragraphs.original: STARVELING$NEWLINE$I believe we must leave the killing out, when all is done.
paragraphs.translated: STARVELING$NEWLINE$I think we’ll have to leave out all the killing, come to think of it.

paragraphs.original: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$Not a whit. I have a device to make all well. Write me a prologue, and let the prologue seem to say we will do no harm with our swords, and that Pyramus is not killed indeed. And for the more better assurance, tell them that I, Pyramus, am not Pyramus, but Bottom the weaver. This will put them out of fear.
paragraphs.translated: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$Not at all! I’ve got a plan that will fix everything. Write me a prologue that I can recite to the audience before the play starts. I’ll tell them that we won’t hurt anyone with our swords, and that Pyramus isn’t really dead. And to make it even clearer, we can tell them that I’m playing Pyramus but I’m not really Pyramus—really, I’m Bottom the weaver. That’ll keep them from being afraid.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: QUINCE$NEWLINE$Well. We will have such a prologue, and it shall be written in eight and six.
paragraphs.translated: QUINCE$NEWLINE$All right, we’ll have a prologue then. We’ll write it in alternating eight- and six-syllable lines, just like in a ballad.

paragraphs.original: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$No, make it two more. Let it be written in eight and eight.
paragraphs.translated: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$No, add a couple more syllables. Make it eight and eight.

paragraphs.original: SNOUT$NEWLINE$Will not the ladies be afeard of the lion?
paragraphs.translated: SNOUT$NEWLINE$Won’t the ladies be scared of the lion?

paragraphs.original: STARVELING$NEWLINE$I fear it, I promise you.
paragraphs.translated: STARVELING$NEWLINE$I’m really worried about that.

paragraphs.original: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$Masters, you ought to consider with yourselves. To bring in—God shield us!—a lion among ladies is a most dreadful thing. For there is not a more fearful wildfowl than your lion living. And we ought to look to ’t.
paragraphs.translated: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$Sirs, you ought to think to yourself, bringing in—God forbid!—a lion amongst ladies is really terrible. There’s no scarier wild bird than the living lion, and we should remember that.

paragraphs.original: SNOUT$NEWLINE$Therefore another prologue must tell he is not a lion.
paragraphs.translated: SNOUT$NEWLINE$So we need another prologue to tell everyone he’s not a real lion.

paragraphs.original: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$Nay, you must name his name, and half his face must be seen through the lion’s neck. And he himself must speak through, saying thus—or to the same defect—“Ladies,” or “Fair ladies,” “I would wish you” or “I would request you” or “I would entreat you” “not to fear, not to tremble, my life for yours. If you think I come hither as a lion, it were pity of my life. No, I am no such thing. I am a man as other men are.” And there indeed let him name his name, and tell them plainly he is Snug the joiner.
paragraphs.translated:
BOTTOM$NEWLINE$No, we can just announce the actor’s name, and let his face show through the lion costume, and have him say something himself. He should say the following, or something else to the same
defect—“Ladies,” or “Lovely ladies,” “I would like to ask you” or “I would like to request of you” or “I would like to beg you” “not to be afraid, and not to tremble with fear. I value your lives as highly as my own. If you thought I was a real lion, I would be risking my life. But no, I am not at all a lion. I am a man, just like other men.” And then he should say his name, and tell them plainly that he’s Snug the carpenter.$NEWLINE$defect$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: QUINCE$NEWLINE$Well, it shall be so. But there is two hard things: that is, to bring the moonlight into a chamber. For, you know, Pyramus and Thisbe meet by moonlight.
paragraphs.translated: QUINCE$NEWLINE$All right, that’s what we’ll do then. But there are two things we still have to figure out. How are we going to bring moonlight into a room? Because, you know, Pyramus and Thisbe meet by moonlight.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SNOUT$NEWLINE$Doth the moon shine that night we play our play?
paragraphs.translated: SNOUT$NEWLINE$Will the moon be shining on the night we’re performing our play?

paragraphs.original: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$A calendar, a calendar! Look in the almanac. Find out moonshine, find out moonshine!
paragraphs.translated: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$We need a calendar! Look in the almanac. Look up moonshine, look up moonshine!

paragraphs.original: QUINCE$NEWLINE$(takes out a book) Yes, it doth shine that night.$NEWLINE$(takes out a book)
paragraphs.translated: QUINCE$NEWLINE$(he takes out a book) Yes, the moon will shine that night.$NEWLINE$(he takes out a book)

paragraphs.original: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$Why then, may you leave a casement of the great chamber window where we play open, and the moon may shine in at the casement.
paragraphs.translated: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$Well then, you can leave one of the windows open in the big hall where we’ll be performing, and the moon can shine in through the window.

paragraphs.original: QUINCE$NEWLINE$Ay. Or else one must come in with a bush of thorns and a lantern, and say he comes to disfigure, or to present, the person of Moonshine. Then, there is another thing: we must have a wall in the great chamber. For Pyramus and Thisbe, says the story, did talk through the chink of a wall.
paragraphs.translated:
QUINCE$NEWLINE$Yes, or else someone will have to come in carrying a bundle of sticks and a lantern and say he’s come to
disfigure, or represent, the character of Moonshine, because the man in the moon is supposed to carry sticks and a lantern. But there’s still another problem: we need to have a wall in the big hall, because according to the story, Pyramus and Thisbe talked through a little hole in a wall.$NEWLINE$disfigure,$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: SNOUT$NEWLINE$You can never bring in a wall. What say you, Bottom?
paragraphs.translated: SNOUT$NEWLINE$You’ll never be able to bring in a wall. What do you think, Bottom?

paragraphs.original: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$Some man or other must present Wall. And let him have some plaster, or some loam, or some roughcast about him to signify wall. And let him hold his fingers thus, and through that cranny shall Pyramus and Thisbe whisper.
paragraphs.translated: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$Someone should play the part of Wall. He can have some plaster or clay or limestone or something on him to show the audience he’s a wall. He can hold his fingers in a V-shape like this, and Pyramus and Thisbe can whisper to each other through that little crack.

paragraphs.original: QUINCE$NEWLINE$If that may be then all is well. Come, sit down, every mother’s son, and rehearse your parts.—Pyramus, you begin. When you have spoken your speech, enter into that brake.—And so everyone according to his cue.
paragraphs.translated: QUINCE$NEWLINE$If we can do that, everything will be all right. Now sit down, everybody, and rehearse your parts—Pyramus, you start. When you have said your lines, go hide in that bush.—Everyone else, go there too when you’re not onstage.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter ROBIN unseen$NEWLINE$ROBIN
paragraphs.translated: ROBIN enters, unseen by the characters onstage.$NEWLINE$ROBIN

paragraphs.original: ROBIN$NEWLINE$(aside) What hempen homespuns have we swaggering here,$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$So near the cradle of the fairy queen?$NEWLINE$What, a play toward? I’ll be an auditor.$NEWLINE$An actor too, perhaps, if I see cause.
paragraphs.translated: ROBIN$NEWLINE$(to himself) Who are these country bumpkins swaggering around so close to where the fairy queen is sleeping? What? Are they about to put on a play? I’ll watch. And I’ll act in it, too, if I feel like it.$NEWLINE$(to himself)

paragraphs.original: QUINCE$NEWLINE$Speak, Pyramus.—Thisbe, stand forth.
paragraphs.translated: QUINCE$NEWLINE$Speak, Pyramus.—Thisbe, come forward.

paragraphs.original: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$(as PYRAMUS) Thisbe, the flowers of odious savors sweet—$NEWLINE$(as$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$(as PYRAMUS) Thisbe, flowers with sweet odious smells—$NEWLINE$(as$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: QUINCE$NEWLINE$“Odors,” “odors.”
paragraphs.translated: QUINCE$NEWLINE$“Odors,” “odors.”

paragraphs.original: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$(as PYRAMUS)$NEWLINE$(as$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$—odors savors sweet,$NEWLINE$So hath thy breath, my dearest Thisbe dear.$NEWLINE$And by and by I will to thee appear.$NEWLINE$But hark, a voice!$NEWLINE$Stay thou but here awhile,
paragraphs.translated: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$(as PYRAMUS) —odors and smells are like your breath, my dearest Thisbe dear. But what’s that, a voice! Wait here a while. I’ll be right back!$NEWLINE$(as$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: Exit BOTTOM$NEWLINE$BOTTOM
paragraphs.translated: BOTTOM exits.$NEWLINE$BOTTOM

paragraphs.original: ROBIN$NEWLINE$(aside) A stranger Pyramus than e'er played here.$NEWLINE$(aside)
paragraphs.translated: ROBIN$NEWLINE$(to himself) That’s the strangest Pyramus I’ve ever seen.$NEWLINE$(to himself)

paragraphs.original: Exit ROBIN$NEWLINE$ROBIN
paragraphs.translated: ROBIN exits.$NEWLINE$ROBIN

paragraphs.original: FLUTE$NEWLINE$Must I speak now?
paragraphs.translated: FLUTE$NEWLINE$Am I supposed to talk now?

paragraphs.original: QUINCE$NEWLINE$Ay, marry, must you. For you must understand he goes but to see a noise that he heard, and is to come again.
paragraphs.translated: QUINCE$NEWLINE$Yes, you are. You’re supposed to show that you understand that Pyramus just went to check on a noise he heard and is coming right back.

paragraphs.original: FLUTE$NEWLINE$(as THISBE ) Most radiant Pyramus, most lily-white of hue,$NEWLINE$(as$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Of color like the red rose on triumphant brier,$NEWLINE$Most brisky juvenal and eke most lovely Jew,$NEWLINE$As true as truest horse that yet would never tire.$NEWLINE$I’ll meet thee, Pyramus, at Ninny’s tomb.
paragraphs.translated: FLUTE$NEWLINE$(as THISBE) Most radiant Pyramus, you are as white as a lily, and the color of a red rose on a splendid rosebush, a very lively young man and also a lovely Jew. You are as reliable as a horse that never gets tired. I’ll meet you, Pyramus, at Ninny’s grave.$NEWLINE$(as$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: QUINCE$NEWLINE$“Ninus' tomb,” man. Why, you must not speak that yet. That you answer to Pyramus. You speak all your part at once, cues and all.—Pyramus, enter. Your cue is past. It is “never tire.”
paragraphs.translated: QUINCE$NEWLINE$That’s “Ninus’s grave,” man. And don’t say all of that yet. You’re supposed to say some of it as a reply to Pyramus. You just said all your lines at once, cues and all.—Pyramus, enter. You missed your cue. It’s “never get tired.”

paragraphs.original: FLUTE$NEWLINE$Oh. (as thisbe) As true as truest horse that yet would never tire.
paragraphs.translated: FLUTE$NEWLINE$Oh! (as THISBE) As reliable as a horse that never gets tired.$NEWLINE$(as$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: Enter BOTTOM, with an ass’s head, and ROBIN$NEWLINE$BOTTOM$NEWLINE$ROBIN
paragraphs.translated: ROBIN enters with BOTTOM, with a donkey’s head instead of a human head.$NEWLINE$ROBIN$NEWLINE$BOTTOM

paragraphs.original: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$(as PYRAMUS) If I were fair, Thisbe, I were only thine.$NEWLINE$(as$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$(as PYRAMUS) If I were handsome, my lovely Thisbe, I would still want only you.$NEWLINE$(as$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: QUINCE$NEWLINE$Oh, monstrous! Oh, strange! We are haunted. Pray, masters! Fly, masters! Help!
paragraphs.translated: QUINCE$NEWLINE$Help! It’s a monster! We’re being haunted. Run, everyone, run!

paragraphs.original: Exeunt QUINCE, FLUTE, SNUG, SNOUT, and STARVELING$NEWLINE$QUINCE$NEWLINE$FLUTE$NEWLINE$SNUG$NEWLINE$SNOUT$NEWLINE$STARVELING
paragraphs.translated: QUINCE, FLUTE, SNUG, SNOUT, and STARVELING exit.$NEWLINE$QUINCE$NEWLINE$FLUTE$NEWLINE$SNUG$NEWLINE$SNOUT$NEWLINE$STARVELING

paragraphs.original: ROBIN$NEWLINE$I’ll follow you. I’ll lead you about a round$NEWLINE$Through bog, through bush, through brake, through brier.$NEWLINE$Sometime a horse I’ll be, sometime a hound,$NEWLINE$A hog, a headless bear, sometime a fire.$NEWLINE$And neigh, and bark, and grunt, and roar, and burn,$NEWLINE$Like horse, hound, hog, bear, fire, at every turn.
paragraphs.translated: ROBIN$NEWLINE$I’ll follow you. I’ll run you around in circles, through bogs and bushes and woods and thorns. Sometimes I’ll take the shape of a horse, sometimes I’ll take the shape of a hound or a pig or a headless bear. Sometimes I’ll turn into fire! And I’ll neigh like a horse and bark like a hound and grunt like a pig and roar like a bear and burn like a fire at every turn.

paragraphs.original: Exit ROBIN$NEWLINE$ROBIN
paragraphs.translated: ROBIN exits.$NEWLINE$ROBIN

paragraphs.original: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$Why do they run away? This is a knavery of them to make me afeard.
paragraphs.translated: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$Why are they running away? This is some joke of theirs to scare me.

paragraphs.original: Enter SNOUT$NEWLINE$SNOUT
paragraphs.translated: SNOUT enters.$NEWLINE$SNOUT

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SNOUT$NEWLINE$O Bottom, thou art changed! What do I see on thee?
paragraphs.translated: SNOUT$NEWLINE$Oh, Bottom, you’ve changed! What have you got on your head?

paragraphs.original: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$What do you see? You see an ass head of your own, do you?
paragraphs.translated: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$What do you think I’ve got on my head? You’re acting like an ass, don’t you think?

paragraphs.original: Exit SNOUT$NEWLINE$SNOUT
paragraphs.translated: SNOUT exits.$NEWLINE$SNOUT

paragraphs.original: Enter QUINCE$NEWLINE$QUINCE
paragraphs.translated: QUINCE enters.$NEWLINE$QUINCE

paragraphs.original: QUINCE$NEWLINE$Bless thee, Bottom, bless thee. Thou art translated.
paragraphs.translated: QUINCE$NEWLINE$God bless you, Bottom, God bless you. You’ve been changed. Reborn.

paragraphs.original: Exit QUINCE$NEWLINE$QUINCE
paragraphs.translated: QUINCE exits.$NEWLINE$QUINCE

paragraphs.original: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$I see their knavery: this is to make an ass of me, to fright me if they could. But I will not stir from this place, do what they can. I will walk up and down here and I will sing, that they shall hear I am not afraid.$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$The ouzel cock, so black of hue$NEWLINE$The ouzel cock, so black of hue$NEWLINE$With orange-tawny bill,$NEWLINE$With orange-tawny bill$NEWLINE$The throstle with his note so true,$NEWLINE$The throstle with his note so true$NEWLINE$The wren with little quill—$NEWLINE$The wren with little quill
paragraphs.translated: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$I see what they’re up to. They want to make an ass of me, to scare me if they can. But I won’t leave this spot, no matter what they do. I’ll walk up and down and sing a song, so they’ll know I’m not afraid.$NEWLINE$(singing)$NEWLINE$(singing)$NEWLINE$The blackbird with its black feathers$NEWLINE$The blackbird with its black feathers$NEWLINE$And its orange-and-tan beak,$NEWLINE$And its orange-and-tan beak$NEWLINE$The thrush with its clear voice,$NEWLINE$The thrush with its clear voice$NEWLINE$The wren with its small, piping chirp—$NEWLINE$The wren with its small, piping chirp—

paragraphs.original: TITANIA$NEWLINE$(waking) What angel wakes me from my flowery bed?$NEWLINE$(waking)
paragraphs.translated: TITANIA$NEWLINE$(waking up) What angel is this who’s waking me up from my bed of flowers?$NEWLINE$(waking up)

paragraphs.original: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$(sings)$NEWLINE$The finch, the sparrow, and the lark,$NEWLINE$The finch, the sparrow, and the lark$NEWLINE$The plainsong cuckoo gray,$NEWLINE$The plainsong cuckoo gray$NEWLINE$Whose note full many a man doth mark$NEWLINE$Whose note full many a man doth mark$NEWLINE$And dares not answer “Nay”—$NEWLINE$And dares not answer “Nay”
paragraphs.translated: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$(singing)$NEWLINE$(singing)$NEWLINE$The finch, the sparrow, and the lark,$NEWLINE$The finch, the sparrow, and the lark$NEWLINE$The gray cuckoo with his simple song$NEWLINE$The gray cuckoo with his simple song$NEWLINE$That many men hear$NEWLINE$That many men hear$NEWLINE$But they don’t dare say no to it—$NEWLINE$But they don’t dare say no to it—

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: For indeed, who would set his wit to so foolish a bird?$NEWLINE$Who would give a bird the lie, though he cry “cuckoo” never so?
paragraphs.translated:
Of course they don’t say “no”! Who’d waste his time talking to such a stupid bird? Who’d bother to accuse
a bird of lying, even if the bird were telling him that his wife was cheating on him?$NEWLINE$a bird of lying,$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: TITANIA$NEWLINE$I pray thee, gentle mortal, sing again.$NEWLINE$Mine ear is much enamored of thy note.$NEWLINE$So is mine eye enthrallèd to thy shape.$NEWLINE$And thy fair virtue’s force perforce doth move me$NEWLINE$On the first view to say, to swear, I love thee.
paragraphs.translated: TITANIA$NEWLINE$Please sing again, sweet human. I love to listen to your voice, and I love to look at your body. I know this is the first time I’ve ever seen you, but you’re so wonderful that I can’t help swearing to you that I love you.

paragraphs.original: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$Methinks, mistress, you should have little reason for that.$NEWLINE$And yet, to say the truth, reason and love keep little company together nowadays. The more the pity that some honest neighbors will not make them friends. Nay, I can gleek upon occasion.
paragraphs.translated: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$I don’t think you’ve got much of a reason to love me. But to tell you the truth, reason and love have very little to do with each other these days. It’s too bad some mutual friend of theirs doesn’t introduce them. Ha, ha! No, I’m just kidding.

paragraphs.original: TITANIA$NEWLINE$Thou art as wise as thou art beautiful.
paragraphs.translated: TITANIA$NEWLINE$You’re as wise as you are beautiful.

paragraphs.original: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$Not so, neither. But if I had wit enough to get out of this wood, I have enough to serve mine own turn.
paragraphs.translated: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$No, that’s not true. But if I were smart enough to get out of this forest, I’d be wise enough to satisfy myself.

paragraphs.original: TITANIA$NEWLINE$Out of this wood do not desire to go.$NEWLINE$Thou shalt remain here whether thou wilt or no.$NEWLINE$I am a spirit of no common rate.$NEWLINE$The summer still doth tend upon my state.$NEWLINE$And I do love thee. Therefore go with me.$NEWLINE$I’ll give thee fairies to attend on thee.$NEWLINE$And they shall fetch thee jewels from the deep,$NEWLINE$And sing while thou on pressèd flowers dost sleep.$NEWLINE$And I will purge thy mortal grossness so$NEWLINE$That thou shalt like an airy spirit go.—$NEWLINE$Peaseblossom, Cobweb, Moth, and Mustardseed!
paragraphs.translated: TITANIA$NEWLINE$Don’t bother wishing you could leave this forest, because you’re going to stay here whether you want to or not. I’m no ordinary fairy. I rule over the summer, and I love you. So come with me. I’ll give you fairies as servants, and they’ll bring you jewels from the depths of the ocean, and sing to you while you sleep on a bed of flowers. And I’ll turn you into a spirit like us, so you won’t die as humans do.—Come here, Peaseblossom, Cobweb, Moth, and Mustardseed!

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter four fairies: PEASEBLOSSOM, COBWEB, MOTH, and MUSTARDSEED$NEWLINE$PEASEBLOSSOM$NEWLINE$COBWEB$NEWLINE$MOTH$NEWLINE$MUSTARDSEED
paragraphs.translated: Four fairies—PEASEBLOSSOM, COBWEB, MOTH, and MUSTARDSEED—enter.$NEWLINE$PEASEBLOSSOM$NEWLINE$COBWEB$NEWLINE$MOTH$NEWLINE$MUSTARDSEED

paragraphs.original: PEASEBLOSSOM$NEWLINE$Ready.
paragraphs.translated: PEASEBLOSSOM$NEWLINE$Ready.

paragraphs.original: COBWEB$NEWLINE$And I.
paragraphs.translated: COBWEB$NEWLINE$Me too.

paragraphs.original: MOTH$NEWLINE$And I.
paragraphs.translated: MOTH$NEWLINE$Me too.

paragraphs.original: MUSTARDSEED$NEWLINE$And I.
paragraphs.translated: MUSTARDSEED$NEWLINE$And me too.

paragraphs.original: ALL$NEWLINE$Where shall we go?
paragraphs.translated: ALL$NEWLINE$Where should we go?

paragraphs.original: TITANIA$NEWLINE$Be kind and courteous to this gentleman.$NEWLINE$Hop in his walks and gambol in his eyes.$NEWLINE$Feed him with apricoks and dewberries,$NEWLINE$With purple grapes, green figs, and mulberries.$NEWLINE$The honey bags steal from the humble-bees,$NEWLINE$And for night tapers crop their waxen thighs$NEWLINE$And light them at the fiery glowworms' eyes$NEWLINE$To have my love to bed and to arise.$NEWLINE$And pluck the wings from painted butterflies$NEWLINE$To fan the moonbeams from his sleeping eyes.$NEWLINE$Nod to him, elves, and do him courtesies.
paragraphs.translated: TITANIA$NEWLINE$Be kind and polite to this gentleman. Follow him around. Leap and dance for him. Feed him apricots and blackberries, with purple grapes, green figs, and mulberries. Steal honey from the bumblebees, and make candles out of the bees' wax. Light them with the light of glowworms, so my love will have light when he goes to bed and wakes up. Pluck off colorful butterfly wings, and use them to fan moonbeams away from his eyes as he sleeps. Bow to him, fairies, and curtsy to him.

paragraphs.original: PEASEBLOSSOM$NEWLINE$Hail, mortal.
paragraphs.translated: PEASEBLOSSOM$NEWLINE$Hello, mortal!

paragraphs.original: COBWEB$NEWLINE$Hail.
paragraphs.translated: COBWEB$NEWLINE$Hello!

paragraphs.original: MOTH$NEWLINE$Hail.
paragraphs.translated: MOTH$NEWLINE$Hello!

paragraphs.original: MUSTARDSEED$NEWLINE$Hail.
paragraphs.translated: MUSTARDSEED$NEWLINE$Hello!

paragraphs.original: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$I cry your worships' mercy, heartily.—I beseech your worship’s name.
paragraphs.translated: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$I beg your pardon, sirs.—Please tell me your name, sir?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: COBWEB$NEWLINE$Cobweb.
paragraphs.translated: COBWEB$NEWLINE$Cobweb.

paragraphs.original: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$I shall desire you of more acquaintance, good Master$NEWLINE$Cobweb. If I cut my finger, I shall make bold with you.—$NEWLINE$Your name, honest gentleman?
paragraphs.translated: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$I’d like to get to know you better, Mr. Cobweb. If I cut my finger, I’ll use you as a bandage to stop the bleeding.—And your name, sir?

paragraphs.original: PEASEBLOSSOM$NEWLINE$Peaseblossom.
paragraphs.translated: PEASEBLOSSOM$NEWLINE$Peaseblossom.

paragraphs.original: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$I pray you, commend me to Mistress Squash, your mother, and to Master Peascod, your father. Good Master Peaseblossom, I shall desire you of more acquaintance too.— Your name, I beseech you, sir?
paragraphs.translated: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$Please, give my regards to your mother, Mrs. Peapod, and your father, Mr. Peapod. Good Mr. Peaseblossom, I’d like to get to know you better too.—And you, may I ask what your name is, sir?

paragraphs.original: MUSTARDSEED$NEWLINE$Mustardseed.
paragraphs.translated: MUSTARDSEED$NEWLINE$Mustardseed.

paragraphs.original: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$Good Master Mustardseed, I know your patience well. That same cowardly, giantlike ox-beef hath devoured many a gentleman of your house. I promise you your kindred hath made my eyes water ere now. I desire you of more acquaintance, good Master Mustardseed.
paragraphs.translated: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$Good Mr. Mustardseed, I know you very well. Those cowardly, gigantic sides of beef have been responsible for many of your family members getting eaten as a condiment on beef. I swear to you, many members of your mustard family have made my eyes water before. I look forward to getting to know you better, Mr. Mustardseed.

paragraphs.original: TITANIA$NEWLINE$Come, wait upon him. Lead him to my bower.$NEWLINE$The moon methinks looks with a watery eye.$NEWLINE$And when she weeps, weeps every little flower,$NEWLINE$Lamenting some enforcèd chastity.$NEWLINE$Tie up my love’s tongue. Bring him silently.
paragraphs.translated: TITANIA$NEWLINE$Take good care of him. Take him to my sleeping area. The moon looks sad to me. When she cries, all the little flowers cry too. They’re sad because someone is prevented from having sex—or is having it against her will. Keep my lover quiet. Bring him to me in silence.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter OBERON, King of Fairies, solus$NEWLINE$OBERON
paragraphs.translated: OBERON, the Fairy King, enters.$NEWLINE$OBERON

paragraphs.original: OBERON$NEWLINE$I wonder if Titania be awaked.$NEWLINE$Then, what it was that next came in her eye,$NEWLINE$Which she must dote on in extremity.
paragraphs.translated: OBERON$NEWLINE$I wonder if Titania is awake yet, and if she is, I wonder what the first thing she saw was. Whatever it is, she must be completely in love with it now.

paragraphs.original: Enter ROBIN$NEWLINE$ROBIN
paragraphs.translated: ROBIN enters.$NEWLINE$ROBIN

paragraphs.original: Here comes my messenger.—How now, mad spirit?$NEWLINE$What night-rule now about this haunted grove?
paragraphs.translated: Ah, here comes my messenger.—What’s going on, you crazy spirit? What havoc have you wreaked in this part of the forest?

paragraphs.original: ROBIN$NEWLINE$My mistress with a monster is in love.$NEWLINE$Near to her close and consecrated bower,$NEWLINE$While she was in her dull and sleeping hour,$NEWLINE$A crew of patches, rude mechanicals$NEWLINE$That work for bread upon Athenian stalls,$NEWLINE$Were met together to rehearse a play$NEWLINE$Intended for great Theseus' nuptial day.$NEWLINE$The shallowest thick-skin of that barren sort,$NEWLINE$Who Pyramus presented in their sport,$NEWLINE$Forsook his scene and entered in a brake,$NEWLINE$When I did him at this advantage take,$NEWLINE$An ass’s nole I fixèd on his head.$NEWLINE$Anon his Thisbe must be answerèd,$NEWLINE$And forth my mimic comes. When they him spy,$NEWLINE$As wild geese that the creeping fowler eye,$NEWLINE$Or russet-pated choughs, many in sort,$NEWLINE$Rising and cawing at the gun’s report,$NEWLINE$Sever themselves and madly sweep the sky—$NEWLINE$So at his sight away his fellows fly;$NEWLINE$And, at our stamp, here o'er and o'er one falls.
paragraphs.translated: ROBIN$NEWLINE$My mistress Titania is in love with a monster. While she was sleeping in her bed of flowers, a group of bumbling idiots, rough workmen from Athens, got together nearby to rehearse some play they plan to perform on Theseus’s wedding day. The stupidest one, who played Pyramus in their play, finished his scene and went to sit in the bushes to wait for his next cue. I took that opportunity to stick a donkey’s head on him. When it was time for him to go back onstage and talk to his Thisbe, he came out of the bushes and everyone saw him. His friends ran away as fast as ducks scatter when they hear a hunter’s gunshot. One of them was so frightened when he heard my footsteps that he yelled, “Murder!” and called for help from Athens. They were all so afraid that they completely lost their common sense. They started to become scared of inanimate objects, terrified by the thorns and briars that catch at their clothing and pull off their sleeves and hats. I led them on in this frightened, distracted state, and left sweet

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: He “Murder!” cries and help from Athens calls.$NEWLINE$Their sense thus weak, lost with their fears thus strong,$NEWLINE$Made senseless things begin to do them wrong.$NEWLINE$For briers and thorns at their apparel snatch,$NEWLINE$Some sleeves, some hats—from yielders all things catch.$NEWLINE$I led them on in this distracted fear$NEWLINE$And left sweet Pyramus translated there.$NEWLINE$When in that moment so it came to pass,$NEWLINE$Titania waked and straightway loved an ass.
paragraphs.translated: Pyramus there, transformed into someone with a donkey’s head. At that exact moment, Titania woke up and immediately fell in love with him, an ass.

paragraphs.original: OBERON$NEWLINE$This falls out better than I could devise.$NEWLINE$But hast thou yet latched the Athenian’s eyes$NEWLINE$With the love juice, as I did bid thee do?
paragraphs.translated: OBERON$NEWLINE$This is going even better than I planned. But have you put the love juice from the flower on the eyes of that Athenian, as I asked you to do?

paragraphs.original: ROBIN$NEWLINE$I took him sleeping—that is finished too—$NEWLINE$And the Athenian woman by his side,$NEWLINE$That, when he waked, of force she must be eyed.
paragraphs.translated: ROBIN$NEWLINE$Yes, I found him when he was asleep—so that’s taken care of too—and the Athenian woman was sleeping near him. When he woke up, he must have seen her.

paragraphs.original: Enter DEMETRIUS and HERMIA$NEWLINE$DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$HERMIA
paragraphs.translated: DEMETRIUS and HERMIA enter.$NEWLINE$DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$HERMIA

paragraphs.original: OBERON$NEWLINE$(aside to ROBIN) Stand close. This is the same Athenian.$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: OBERON$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only ROBIN can hear) Step aside. Here’s the Athenian coming now.$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only$NEWLINE$can hear)

paragraphs.original: ROBIN$NEWLINE$(aside to OBERON) This is the woman, but not this the man.$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: ROBIN$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only OBERON can hear) That’s definitely the woman I saw, but it’s not the same man.$NEWLINE$(speaking so that only$NEWLINE$can hear)

paragraphs.original: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$Oh, why rebuke you him that loves you so?$NEWLINE$Lay breath so bitter on your bitter foe.
paragraphs.translated: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$Why are you so rude to someone who loves you so much? Save that kind of harsh language for your worst enemy.

paragraphs.original: HERMIA$NEWLINE$Now I but chide, but I should use thee worse.$NEWLINE$For thou, I fear, hast given me cause to curse.$NEWLINE$If thou hast slain Lysander in his sleep,$NEWLINE$Being o'er shoes in blood, plunge in the deep,$NEWLINE$And kill me too.
paragraphs.translated: HERMIA$NEWLINE$I’m only scolding you now, but I should treat you much worse, because I’m afraid you’ve given me good reason to curse you. If you killed Lysander while he was sleeping, then you’re already up to your ankles in blood. You might as well jump right into a bloodbath and kill me, too.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: The sun was not so true unto the day$NEWLINE$As he to me. Would he have stolen away$NEWLINE$From sleeping Hermia? I’ll believe as soon$NEWLINE$This whole Earth may be bored, and that the moon$NEWLINE$May through the center creep and so displease$NEWLINE$Her brother’s noontide with th' Antipodes.$NEWLINE$It cannot be but thou hast murdered him.$NEWLINE$So should a murderer look, so dead, so grim.
paragraphs.translated: He was more faithful to me than the sun is to the daytime. Would he have snuck away from me while I was asleep? I’ll believe that when I believe that there’s a hole through the center of the earth, and the moon has passed all the way through to the other side. The only possibility is that you’ve murdered him. A murderer should look like you do, so pale and grim.

paragraphs.original: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$So should the murdered look, and so should I,$NEWLINE$Pierced through the heart with your stern cruelty.$NEWLINE$Yet you, the murderer, look as bright, as clear,$NEWLINE$As yonder Venus in her glimmering sphere.
paragraphs.translated: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$That’s how someone who’s been murdered should look, and that’s how I look. You’ve pierced me through the heart with your cruelty, and yet you, the murderer, look as bright and clear as a star in the sky.

paragraphs.original: HERMIA$NEWLINE$What’s this to my Lysander? Where is he?$NEWLINE$Ah, good Demetrius, wilt thou give him me?
paragraphs.translated: HERMIA$NEWLINE$What does that have to do with my Lysander? Where is he? Oh, good Demetrius, will you find him for me?

paragraphs.original: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$I had rather give his carcass to my hounds.
paragraphs.translated: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$I would rather feed his corpse to my dogs.

paragraphs.original: HERMIA$NEWLINE$Out, dog! Out, cur! Thou drivest me past the bounds$NEWLINE$Of maiden’s patience. Hast thou slain him then?$NEWLINE$Henceforth be never numbered among men!$NEWLINE$Oh, once tell true, tell true even for my sake—$NEWLINE$Durst thou have looked upon him being awake,$NEWLINE$And hast thou killed him sleeping? O brave touch!$NEWLINE$Could not a worm, an adder, do so much?$NEWLINE$An adder did it, for with doubler tongue$NEWLINE$Than thine, thou serpent, never adder stung.
paragraphs.translated: HERMIA$NEWLINE$Get out, dog! You’ve driven me to my wit’s end. Did you kill him, then? From now on I won’t even consider you a human being. Oh, just tell the truth for once. tell the truth, if only for my sake.—Would you have even dared to look at him when he was awake? And did you kill him while he was sleeping? Oh, how brave of you! A snake could do that as easily as you could. A snake did do it, because no snake ever had a more forked, lying tongue than you have.

paragraphs.original: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$You spend your passion on a misprised mood.$NEWLINE$I am not guilty of Lysander’s blood.$NEWLINE$Nor is he dead, for aught that I can tell.
paragraphs.translated: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$You’re getting all worked up over a misunderstanding. I didn’t kill Lysander. ?As far as I know, he’s not even dead.

paragraphs.original: HERMIA$NEWLINE$I pray thee, tell me then that he is well.
paragraphs.translated: HERMIA$NEWLINE$Then please tell me he’s all right.

paragraphs.original: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$An if I could, what should I get therefore?
paragraphs.translated: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$If I told you that, what would I get out of it?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: HERMIA$NEWLINE$A privilege never to see me more.$NEWLINE$And from thy hated presence part I so.$NEWLINE$See me no more, whether he be dead or no.
paragraphs.translated: HERMIA$NEWLINE$The privilege of never seeing me again. And now I’m going to leave your despised company. You’ll never see me again, whether or not he’s dead.

paragraphs.original: Exit HERMIA$NEWLINE$HERMIA
paragraphs.translated: HERMIA exits.$NEWLINE$HERMIA

paragraphs.original: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$There is no following her in this fierce vein.$NEWLINE$Here therefore for a while I will remain.$NEWLINE$So sorrow’s heaviness doth heavier grow$NEWLINE$For debt that bankrupt sleep doth sorrow owe,$NEWLINE$Which now in some slight measure it will pay,$NEWLINE$If for his tender here I make some stay.$NEWLINE$(lies down and sleeps)$NEWLINE$(lies down and sleeps)
paragraphs.translated: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$I can’t go after her when she’s in a rage like this. So I’ll stay here for a while. Sadness gets worse when you haven’t had enough sleep. I’ll try to sleep a little here. ( DEMETRIUS lies down and falls asleep)$NEWLINE$($NEWLINE$lies down and falls asleep)

paragraphs.original: OBERON$NEWLINE$(to ROBIN) What hast thou done? Thou hast mistaken quite,$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$And laid the love juice on some true love’s sight.$NEWLINE$Of thy misprision must perforce ensue$NEWLINE$Some true love turned, and not a false turned true.
paragraphs.translated: OBERON$NEWLINE$(to ROBIN) What have you done? You’ve made a mistake and put the love-juice on someone else, someone who was truly in love. Because of your mistake someone’s true love must have turned bad, instead of this man’s false love being turned into a true love.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ROBIN$NEWLINE$Then fate o'errules that, one man holding troth,$NEWLINE$A million fail, confounding oath on oath.
paragraphs.translated: ROBIN$NEWLINE$In that case, it must be fate. That’s the way of the world. For every man who’s faithful to his true love, a million end up running after a different lover.

paragraphs.original: OBERON$NEWLINE$About the wood go swifter than the wind,$NEWLINE$And Helena of Athens look thou find—$NEWLINE$All fancy-sick she is and pale of cheer,$NEWLINE$With sighs of love, that costs the fresh blood dear.$NEWLINE$By some illusion see thou bring her here.$NEWLINE$I’ll charm his eyes against she do appear.
paragraphs.translated: OBERON$NEWLINE$Go around the forest, moving faster than the wind, and make sure you find Helena of Athens.—She’s lovesick, and her face is pale from all the sighing she’s been doing, because sighing is bad for the blood. Bring her here with some trick or illusion, and I’ll put the charm on his eyes for when she comes.

paragraphs.original: ROBIN$NEWLINE$I go, I go. Look how I go,$NEWLINE$Swifter than arrow from the Tartar’s bow.
paragraphs.translated:
ROBIN$NEWLINE$I go, I go, look at me go—faster than an arrow from a
Tartar’s bow.$NEWLINE$Tartar’s$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: Exit ROBIN$NEWLINE$ROBIN
paragraphs.translated: ROBIN exits$NEWLINE$ROBIN

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: OBERON$NEWLINE$(squeezing flower juice into DEMETRIUS ’s eyes)$NEWLINE$(squeezing flower juice into$NEWLINE$’s eyes)$NEWLINE$Flower of this purple dye,$NEWLINE$Hit with Cupid’s archery,$NEWLINE$Sink in apple of his eye.$NEWLINE$When his love he doth espy,$NEWLINE$Let her shine as gloriously$NEWLINE$As the Venus of the sky.$NEWLINE$When thou wakest, if she be by,$NEWLINE$Beg of her for remedy.
paragraphs.translated: OBERON$NEWLINE$(putting flower juice on DEMETRIUS ’s eyelids)$NEWLINE$(putting flower juice on$NEWLINE$’s eyelids)$NEWLINE$You purple flower, hit by Cupid’s arrow, sink into the pupils of this man’s eyes. When he sees the girl he should love, make her seem as bright to him as the evening star. Young man, when you wake up, if she’s nearby, beg her to cure your lovesickness.

paragraphs.original: Enter ROBIN$NEWLINE$ROBIN
paragraphs.translated: ROBIN enters.$NEWLINE$ROBIN

paragraphs.original: ROBIN$NEWLINE$Captain of our fairy band,$NEWLINE$Helena is here at hand,$NEWLINE$And the youth, mistook by me,$NEWLINE$Pleading for a lover’s fee.$NEWLINE$Shall we their fond pageant see?$NEWLINE$Lord, what fools these mortals be!
paragraphs.translated: ROBIN$NEWLINE$Helena is nearby, boss. The young man who I mistook for this one is there too, begging her to love him. Should we watch this ridiculous scene? Lord, what fools these mortals are!

paragraphs.original: OBERON$NEWLINE$Stand aside. The noise they make$NEWLINE$Will cause Demetrius to awake.
paragraphs.translated: OBERON$NEWLINE$Step aside. The noise they’re making will wake up Demetrius.

paragraphs.original: ROBIN$NEWLINE$Then will two at once woo one.$NEWLINE$That must needs be sport alone.$NEWLINE$And those things do best please me$NEWLINE$That befall preposterously.
paragraphs.translated: ROBIN$NEWLINE$Then the two of them will both pursue one girl. That will be funny enough, and preposterous situations are my favorite thing.

paragraphs.original: Enter LYSANDER and HELENA$NEWLINE$LYSANDER$NEWLINE$HELENA
paragraphs.translated: LYSANDER and HELENA enter.$NEWLINE$LYSANDER$NEWLINE$HELENA

paragraphs.original: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$Why should you think that I should woo in scorn?$NEWLINE$Scorn and derision never come in tears.
paragraphs.translated: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$Why do you think I’m making fun of you when I tell you I love you? People don’t cry when they’re mocking someone.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Look, when I vow, I weep. And vows so born,$NEWLINE$In their nativity all truth appears.$NEWLINE$How can these things in me seem scorn to you,$NEWLINE$Bearing the badge of faith to prove them true?
paragraphs.translated: Look, when I swear that I love you, I cry, and when someone cries while he’s making a promise, he’s usually telling the truth. How can it seem like I’m making fun of you, when my tears prove that I’m sincere?

paragraphs.original: HELENA$NEWLINE$You do advance your cunning more and more.$NEWLINE$When truth kills truth, O devilish holy fray!$NEWLINE$These vows are Hermia’s. Will you give her o'er?$NEWLINE$Weigh oath with oath, and you will nothing weigh.$NEWLINE$Your vows to her and me, put in two scales,$NEWLINE$Will even weigh, and both as light as tales.
paragraphs.translated: HELENA$NEWLINE$You get trickier and trickier. You’ve made the same promises to me and to Hermia—they can’t both be true! They must both be false. The promises you’re making to me belong to Hermia. Will you abandon her? If you weighed the promises you made to me against the promises you made to her, they’d come out the same—they both weigh nothing. They’re lies.

paragraphs.original: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$I had no judgment when to her I swore.
paragraphs.translated: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$I wasn’t thinking clearly when I made those promises to her.

paragraphs.original: HELENA$NEWLINE$Nor none, in my mind, now you give her o'er.
paragraphs.translated: HELENA$NEWLINE$And I don’t believe you’re thinking clearly now, as you break those promises.

paragraphs.original: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$Demetrius loves her, and he loves not you.
paragraphs.translated: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$Demetrius loves her, and he doesn’t love you.

paragraphs.original: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$(waking) O Helena, goddess, nymph, perfect, divine!$NEWLINE$(waking)$NEWLINE$To what, my love, shall I compare thine eyne?$NEWLINE$Crystal is muddy. Oh, how ripe in show$NEWLINE$Thy lips, those kissing cherries, tempting grow!$NEWLINE$That pure congealèd white, high Taurus' snow,$NEWLINE$Fanned with the eastern wind, turns to a crow$NEWLINE$When thou hold’st up thy hand. Oh, let me kiss$NEWLINE$This princess of pure white, this seal of bliss!
paragraphs.translated: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$(waking up) Oh Helena, you goddess, you divine and perfect nymph! What can I compare your eyes to? Crystal isn’t as clear as they are. Oh, your lips are as ripe as a pair of tempting cherries touching each other! The pure white of the snow on a mountaintop seems black as a crow’s wing next to the whiteness of your hands. Oh, let me kiss your beautiful white hand. It’ll make me so happy!$NEWLINE$(waking up)

paragraphs.original: HELENA$NEWLINE$O spite! O hell! I see you all are bent$NEWLINE$To set against me for your merriment.$NEWLINE$If you were civil and knew courtesy,$NEWLINE$You would not do me thus much injury.$NEWLINE$Can you not hate me, as I know you do,$NEWLINE$But you must join in souls to mock me too?$NEWLINE$If you were men, as men you are in show,$NEWLINE$You would not use a gentle lady so
paragraphs.translated: HELENA$NEWLINE$Damn it! I see you’re all determined to gang up on me for a few laughs. If you had any manners at all, you wouldn’t treat me like this. Can’t you just hate me, as I know you do? Do you have to get together to humiliate me too? If you were real men, as you pretend to be, you wouldn’t treat a lady this way, making vows and promises and praising my beauty when I know you’re really both disgusted by me. You’re competing for

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: To vow, and swear, and superpraise my parts,$NEWLINE$When I am sure you hate me with your hearts.$NEWLINE$You both are rivals, and love Hermia,$NEWLINE$And now both rivals to mock Helena—$NEWLINE$A trim exploit, a manly enterprise,$NEWLINE$To conjure tears up in a poor maid’s eyes$NEWLINE$With your derision! None of noble sort$NEWLINE$Would so offend a virgin, and extort$NEWLINE$A poor soul’s patience, all to make you sport.
paragraphs.translated: Hermia’s love, and now you’re competing to see which one of you can make fun of me the most. That’s a great idea, a really manly thing to do—making a poor girl cry! No respectable person would offend an innocent girl just to have some fun.

paragraphs.original: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$You are unkind, Demetrius. Be not so.$NEWLINE$For you love Hermia. This you know I know.$NEWLINE$And here, with all good will, with all my heart,$NEWLINE$In Hermia’s love I yield you up my part.$NEWLINE$And yours of Helena to me bequeath,$NEWLINE$Whom I do love and will do till my death.
paragraphs.translated: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$Don’t be cruel, Demetrius. I know you love Hermia, and you know I know it. Right here, right now, I swear I’m giving up all my claims on her and handing her to you. In exchange, give up your claim to love Helena, since I love her and will love her until I die.

paragraphs.original: HELENA$NEWLINE$Never did mockers waste more idle breath.
paragraphs.translated: HELENA$NEWLINE$Nobody’s ever gone to so much trouble just to make fun of someone.

paragraphs.original: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$Lysander, keep thy Hermia. I will none.$NEWLINE$If e'er I loved her, all that love is gone.$NEWLINE$My heart to her but as guest-wise sojourned,$NEWLINE$And now to Helen is it home returned,$NEWLINE$There to remain.
paragraphs.translated: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$Lysander, keep your Hermia. I don’t want her. If I ever loved her, all that love is gone now. My love for her was temporary. Now I’ll love Helena forever.

paragraphs.original: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$Helen, it is not so.
paragraphs.translated: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$Helena, it’s not true.

paragraphs.original: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$Disparage not the faith thou dost not know,$NEWLINE$Lest to thy peril thou aby it dear.$NEWLINE$Look, where thy love comes. Yonder is thy dear.
paragraphs.translated: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$Don’t insult a deep love that you don’t understand, or you’ll pay the price. Look, here comes the woman you love.

paragraphs.original: Enter HERMIA$NEWLINE$HERMIA
paragraphs.translated: HERMIA enters.$NEWLINE$HERMIA

paragraphs.original: HERMIA$NEWLINE$Dark night, that from the eye his function takes,$NEWLINE$The ear more quick of apprehension makes.$NEWLINE$Wherein it doth impair the seeing sense,$NEWLINE$It pays the hearing double recompense.
paragraphs.translated: HERMIA$NEWLINE$It’s hard to see clearly in the dark of night, but it’s easier to hear well.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Thou art not by mine eye, Lysander, found.$NEWLINE$Mine ear, I thank it, brought me to thy sound$NEWLINE$But why unkindly didst thou leave me so?
paragraphs.translated: I couldn’t see you, Lysander, but I heard your voice, and that’s how I found you. Why did you leave me alone so unkindly?

paragraphs.original: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$Why should he stay, whom love doth press to go?
paragraphs.translated: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$Why stay when love tells you to go?

paragraphs.original: HERMIA$NEWLINE$What love could press Lysander from my side?
paragraphs.translated: HERMIA$NEWLINE$But what love could make my Lysander leave me?

paragraphs.original: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$Lysander’s love, that would not let him bide,$NEWLINE$Fair Helena, who more engilds the night$NEWLINE$Than all yon fiery oes and eyes of light.$NEWLINE$Why seek’st thou me? Could not this make thee know$NEWLINE$The hate I bear thee made me leave thee so?
paragraphs.translated: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$I had to hurry to my love, beautiful Helena, who lights up the night better than all those fiery stars. Why are you looking for me? Didn’t you figure out that I left you because I hate you?

paragraphs.original: HERMIA$NEWLINE$You speak not as you think. It cannot be.
paragraphs.translated: HERMIA$NEWLINE$You can’t mean what you’re saying. It’s impossible.

paragraphs.original: HELENA$NEWLINE$Lo, she is one of this confederacy!$NEWLINE$Now I perceive they have conjoined all three$NEWLINE$To fashion this false sport, in spite of me.—$NEWLINE$Injurious Hermia! Most ungrateful maid!$NEWLINE$Have you conspired, have you with these contrived$NEWLINE$To bait me with this foul derision?$NEWLINE$Is all the counsel that we two have shared,$NEWLINE$The sisters' vows, the hours that we have spent$NEWLINE$When we have chid the hasty-footed time$NEWLINE$For parting us—oh, is it all forgot?$NEWLINE$All schooldays' friendship, childhood innocence?$NEWLINE$We, Hermia, like two artificial gods,$NEWLINE$Have with our needles created both one flower,$NEWLINE$Both on one sampler, sitting on one cushion,$NEWLINE$Both warbling of one song, both in one key,$NEWLINE$As if our hands, our sides, voices, and minds,$NEWLINE$Had been incorporate. So we grew together,$NEWLINE$Like to a double cherry—seeming parted$NEWLINE$But yet an union in partition—$NEWLINE$Two lovely berries molded on one stem;
paragraphs.translated: HELENA$NEWLINE$So, she’s in on this too! Now I see that all three of them have gotten together to play this cruel trick on me. Hurtful Hermia, you ungrateful girl, have you conspired with these two to provoke me with this horrible teasing? Have you forgotten all the talks we’ve had together, the vows we made to be like sisters to one another, all the hours we spent together, wishing that we never had to say goodbye—have you forgotten? Our friendship in our schooldays, our childhood innocence? We used to sit together and sew one flower with our two needles, sewing it on one piece of cloth, sitting on the same cushion, singing one song in the same key, as if our hands, our sides, our voices and our minds were stuck together. We grew together like twin cherries—which seemed to be separate but were also together—two lovely cherries on one stem.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: So, with two seeming bodies but one heart,$NEWLINE$Two of the first, like coats in heraldry,$NEWLINE$Due but to one and crownèd with one crest.$NEWLINE$And will you rent our ancient love asunder$NEWLINE$To join with men in scorning your poor friend?$NEWLINE$It is not friendly, ’tis not maidenly.$NEWLINE$Our sex, as well as I, may chide you for it,$NEWLINE$Though I alone do feel the injury.
paragraphs.translated: We seemed to have two separate bodies, but we had one heart. Do you want to destroy our old friendship by joining these men to insult your poor friend? It’s not friendly, and it’s not ladylike. All women would be angry with you for doing it, even though I’m the only one who’s hurt by it.

paragraphs.original: HERMIA$NEWLINE$I am amazèd at your passionate words.$NEWLINE$I scorn you not. It seems that you scorn me.
paragraphs.translated: HERMIA$NEWLINE$I’m completely dumbfounded by what you’re saying. I’m not insulting you. It sounds more like you’re insulting me.

paragraphs.original: HELENA$NEWLINE$Have you not set Lysander, as in scorn,$NEWLINE$To follow me and praise my eyes and face?$NEWLINE$And made your other love, Demetrius—$NEWLINE$Who even but now did spurn me with his foot—$NEWLINE$To call me goddess, nymph, divine, and rare,$NEWLINE$Precious, celestial? Wherefore speaks he this$NEWLINE$To her he hates? And wherefore doth Lysander$NEWLINE$Deny your love, so rich within his soul,$NEWLINE$And tender me, forsooth, affection,$NEWLINE$But by your setting on, by your consent?$NEWLINE$What though I be not so in grace as you—$NEWLINE$So hung upon with love, so fortunate—$NEWLINE$But miserable most, to love unloved?$NEWLINE$This you should pity rather than despise.
paragraphs.translated: HELENA$NEWLINE$Come on, confess. Didn’t you send Lysander, as an insult, to follow me around praising my eyes and my face? Haven’t you made your other love, Demetrius—who kicked me with his foot not long ago—call me a goddess and a divine, rare, precious, heavenly creature? Why does he talk like that to a girl he can’t stand? And why does Lysander deny that he loves you, when he loves you so deeply? Why would he show me any affection, unless you told him to? Why does it matter that I’m not as lucky or lovable as you are and that the love I feel is unrequited? You should pity me for that reason, not hate me.

paragraphs.original: HERMIA$NEWLINE$I understand not what you mean by this.
paragraphs.translated: HERMIA$NEWLINE$I don’t know what you’re talking about.

paragraphs.original: HELENA$NEWLINE$Ay, do. Persever, counterfeit sad looks,$NEWLINE$Make mouths upon me when I turn my back,$NEWLINE$Wink each at other, hold the sweet jest up—$NEWLINE$This sport, well carried, shall be chronicled.
paragraphs.translated: HELENA$NEWLINE$Oh, fine. All right, go ahead, keep up your little game, pretend to be sympathetic, but then nudge each other and wink and make faces at me when I turn my back. Keep up your wonderful game. You’re doing such a good job on this trick, someone should write a book about it.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: If you have any pity, grace, or manners,$NEWLINE$You would not make me such an argument.$NEWLINE$But fare ye well. 'Tis partly my own fault,$NEWLINE$Which death or absence soon shall remedy.
paragraphs.translated: If you had any sense of pity, or manners, you wouldn’t pretend to fight over me like this. But goodbye. It’s partly my own fault, since I followed you here. Leaving—or dying—will soon take care of everything.

paragraphs.original: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$Stay, gentle Helena. Hear my excuse.$NEWLINE$My love, my life, my soul, fair Helena!
paragraphs.translated: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$Stay, lovely Helena. Listen to my excuse. My love, my life, my soul, beautiful Helena!

paragraphs.original: HELENA$NEWLINE$Oh, excellent!
paragraphs.translated: HELENA$NEWLINE$That’s a good one.

paragraphs.original: HERMIA$NEWLINE$(to LYSANDER)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Sweet, do not scorn her so.
paragraphs.translated: HERMIA$NEWLINE$(to LYSANDER) Don’t insult her like that, Lysander darling.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$If she cannot entreat, I can compel.
paragraphs.translated: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$(to LYSANDER) If Hermia’s begging can’t make you stop insulting Helena, I can force you to do so.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$Thou canst compel no more than she entreat.$NEWLINE$Thy threats have no more strength than her weak prayers.—$NEWLINE$Helen, I love thee. By my life, I do.$NEWLINE$I swear by that which I will lose for thee$NEWLINE$To prove him false that says I love thee not.
paragraphs.translated: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$You can’t force me any more than Hermia can beg me. Your threats are no stronger than her whining.—Helena, I love you. I swear I do. I’ll give my life for you, just to prove this guy wrong when he says I don’t love you.

paragraphs.original: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$I say I love thee more than he can do.
paragraphs.translated: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$I say that I love you more than he does.

paragraphs.original: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$If thou say so, withdraw and prove it too.
paragraphs.translated: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$If that’s what you say, go fight a duel with me and prove it.

paragraphs.original: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$Quick, come.
paragraphs.translated: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$You’re on. Let’s do it.

paragraphs.original: HERMIA$NEWLINE$Lysander, whereto tends all this?
paragraphs.translated: HERMIA$NEWLINE$Lysander, where are you going with all this?

paragraphs.original: (holds LYSANDER back)$NEWLINE$LYSANDER
paragraphs.translated: (she holds LYSANDER back)$NEWLINE$LYSANDER

paragraphs.original: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$(to HERMIA) Away, you Ethiope!$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$(to HERMIA) Get away, you African!$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$(to HERMIA)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$No, no. He’ll$NEWLINE$Seem to break loose.
paragraphs.translated: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$(to HERMIA) No, no. He’ll act like he’s going to break free from you, Hermia.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: (to LYSANDER)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Take on as you would follow,$NEWLINE$But yet come not. You are a tame man, go!
paragraphs.translated: (to LYSANDER) Pretend like you’re going to follow me, but then don’t come. You’re a coward, get out of here!$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$(to HERMIA) Hang off, thou cat, thou burr! Vile thing, let loose$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Or I will shake thee from me like a serpent.
paragraphs.translated: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$(to HERMIA) Stop hanging on me, you cat, you thorn. Let go of me, or I’ll shake you off like a snake.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: HERMIA$NEWLINE$Why are you grown so rude? What change is this,$NEWLINE$Sweet love?
paragraphs.translated: HERMIA$NEWLINE$Why have you gotten so rude? What’s happened to you, my darling?

paragraphs.original: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$Thy love? Out, tawny Tartar, out!$NEWLINE$Out, loathèd medicine! O hated potion, hence!
paragraphs.translated: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$Your darling? Get out, you dark-skinned gypsy! Get out, you horrible poison. Get out!

paragraphs.original: HERMIA$NEWLINE$Do you not jest?
paragraphs.translated: HERMIA$NEWLINE$Are you joking?

paragraphs.original: HELENA$NEWLINE$Yes, sooth, and so do you.
paragraphs.translated: HELENA$NEWLINE$Of course he is, and so are you.

paragraphs.original: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$Demetrius, I will keep my word with thee.
paragraphs.translated: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$Demetrius, I’m ready to fight you as promised.

paragraphs.original: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$I would I had your bond, for I perceive$NEWLINE$A weak bond holds you. I’ll not trust your word.
paragraphs.translated: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$I wish we had a signed legal contract. I can see you don’t keep your promises very well. I don’t trust you.

paragraphs.original: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$What, should I hurt her, strike her, kill her dead?$NEWLINE$Although I hate her, I’ll not harm her so.
paragraphs.translated: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$What? Do you want me to hit Hermia, hurt her, kill her? Sure, I hate her, but I wouldn’t hurt her.

paragraphs.original: HERMIA$NEWLINE$(to LYSANDER)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$What, can you do me greater harm than hate?$NEWLINE$Hate me? Wherefore? O me! What news, my love?$NEWLINE$Am not I Hermia? Are not you Lysander?$NEWLINE$I am as fair now as I was erewhile.$NEWLINE$Since night you loved me. Yet since night you left me.$NEWLINE$Why then, you left me—Oh, the gods forbid!—$NEWLINE$In earnest, shall I say?
paragraphs.translated: HERMIA$NEWLINE$(to LYSANDER) Can you hurt me any more than by saying you hate me? Hate me? Why? What’s happened to you, my love? Am I not Hermia? Aren’t you Lysander? I’m as beautiful now as I was a little while ago. You still loved me when we fell asleep, but when you woke up you left me. So you left me—Oh, God help me!—For real?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$Ay, by my life,$NEWLINE$And never did desire to see thee more.$NEWLINE$Therefore be out of hope, of question, of doubt.
paragraphs.translated: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$I certainly did, and I never wanted to see you again. So stop hoping and wondering what I mean.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Be certain, nothing truer. 'Tis no jest$NEWLINE$That I do hate thee and love Helena.
paragraphs.translated: I’ve spelled it out for you clearly. It’s no joke. I hate you and love Helena.

paragraphs.original: HERMIA$NEWLINE$O me!$NEWLINE$(to HELENA) You juggler! You canker-blossom!$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$You thief of love! What, have you come by night$NEWLINE$And stol'n my love’s heart from him?
paragraphs.translated: HERMIA$NEWLINE$Oh, no! (to HELENA) You trickster, you snake! You thief! What, did you sneak in at night and steal my love’s heart from him?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: HELENA$NEWLINE$Fine, i' faith!$NEWLINE$Have you no modesty, no maiden shame,$NEWLINE$No touch of bashfulness? What, will you tear$NEWLINE$Impatient answers from my gentle tongue?$NEWLINE$Fie, fie! You counterfeit, you puppet, you!
paragraphs.translated: HELENA$NEWLINE$Oh, that’s very nice! You ought to be ashamed of yourself! You’re going to make me mad enough to answer you? Damn you, you faker, you puppet!

paragraphs.original: HERMIA$NEWLINE$“Puppet”? Why so?—Ay, that way goes the game.$NEWLINE$Now I perceive that she hath made compare$NEWLINE$Between our statures. She hath urged her height,$NEWLINE$And with her personage, her tall personage,$NEWLINE$Her height, forsooth, she hath prevailed with him.—$NEWLINE$And are you grown so high in his esteem$NEWLINE$Because I am so dwarfish and so low?$NEWLINE$How low am I, thou painted maypole? Speak.$NEWLINE$How low am I? I am not yet so low$NEWLINE$But that my nails can reach unto thine eyes.
paragraphs.translated: HERMIA$NEWLINE$“Puppet”? Why “puppet”?—Oh, I see where this is going. She’s talking about our difference in height. She’s paraded in front of him to show off how tall she is. She won him over with her height.—Does he have such a high opinion of you because I’m so short? Is that it? So how short am I, you painted barber pole? Tell me. How short am I? I’m not too short to gouge your eyes out with my fingernails.

paragraphs.original: HELENA$NEWLINE$(to LYSANDER and DEMETRIUS)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$and$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$I pray you, though you mock me, gentlemen,$NEWLINE$Let her not hurt me. I was never cursed.$NEWLINE$I have no gift at all in shrewishness.$NEWLINE$I am a right maid for my cowardice.$NEWLINE$Let her not strike me. You perhaps may think,$NEWLINE$Because she is something lower than myself,$NEWLINE$That I can match her.
paragraphs.translated: HELENA$NEWLINE$(to LYSANDER and DEMETRIUS) Please don’t let her hurt me, gentlemen, however much you want to tease me. I never was much good with insults. I’m not mean and catty like her. I’m a nice shy girl. Please don’t let her hit me. Maybe you think that because she’s shorter than me I can take her.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$and$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: HERMIA$NEWLINE$“Lower”? Hark, again!
paragraphs.translated: HERMIA$NEWLINE$“Shorter!” See, she’s doing it again!

paragraphs.original: HELENA$NEWLINE$Good Hermia, do not be so bitter with me.$NEWLINE$I evermore did love you, Hermia,$NEWLINE$Did ever keep your counsels, never wronged you—$NEWLINE$Save that, in love unto Demetrius,$NEWLINE$I told him of your stealth unto this wood.$NEWLINE$He followed you. For love I followed him.$NEWLINE$But he hath chid me hence and threatened me$NEWLINE$To strike me, spurn me—nay, to kill me too.$NEWLINE$And now, so you will let me quiet go,$NEWLINE$To Athens will I bear my folly back$NEWLINE$And follow you no further. Let me go.$NEWLINE$You see how simple and how fond I am.
paragraphs.translated: HELENA$NEWLINE$Good Hermia, please don’t act so bitter toward me. I always loved you, Hermia, and gave you advice. I never did anything to hurt you—except once, when I told Demetrius that you planned to sneak off into this forest. And I only did that because I loved Demetrius so much. He followed you. And I followed him because I loved him. But he told me to get lost and threatened to hit me, kick me—even kill me. Now just let me go quietly back to Athens. I’ll carry my mistakes back with me. I won’t follow you anymore. Please let me go. You see how naïve and foolish I’ve been.

paragraphs.original: HERMIA$NEWLINE$Why, get you gone! Who is ’t that hinders you?
paragraphs.translated: HERMIA$NEWLINE$Well, get out of here then! What’s keeping you?

paragraphs.original: HELENA$NEWLINE$A foolish heart, that I leave here behind.
paragraphs.translated: HELENA$NEWLINE$My stupid heart, which I’m leaving behind here.

paragraphs.original: HERMIA$NEWLINE$What, with Lysander?
paragraphs.translated: HERMIA$NEWLINE$What, you’re leaving it with Lysander?

paragraphs.original: HELENA$NEWLINE$With Demetrius.
paragraphs.translated: HELENA$NEWLINE$No, with Demetrius.

paragraphs.original: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$Be not afraid. She shall not harm thee, Helena.
paragraphs.translated: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$Don’t be afraid. She can’t hurt you, Helena.

paragraphs.original: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$(to LYSANDER)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$No, sir, she shall not, though you take her part.
paragraphs.translated: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$(to LYSANDER) That’s right, Hermia won’t hurt Helena even if you try to help her.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: HELENA$NEWLINE$Oh, when she’s angry, she is keen and shrewd!$NEWLINE$She was a vixen when she went to school.$NEWLINE$And though she be but little, she is fierce.
paragraphs.translated: HELENA$NEWLINE$Oh, when you get her angry, she’s a good fighter, and vicious too. She was a hellcat in school. And she’s fierce, even though she’s little.

paragraphs.original: HERMIA$NEWLINE$“Little” again? Nothing but “low” and “little”!—$NEWLINE$Why will you suffer her to flout me thus?$NEWLINE$Let me come to her.
paragraphs.translated: HERMIA$NEWLINE$“Little” again? Nothing but “little” and “short”!— Why are you letting her insult me like this? Let me at her!.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$(to HERMIA) Get you gone, you dwarf,$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$You minimus of hindering knotgrass made,$NEWLINE$You bead, you acorn!
paragraphs.translated: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$(to HERMIA) Get lost, you dwarf, you tiny little weed, you scrap, you acorn!$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
