paragraphs.original: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$You are too officious$NEWLINE$In her behalf that scorns your services.$NEWLINE$Let her alone. Speak not of Helena.$NEWLINE$Take not her part. For if thou dost intend$NEWLINE$Never so little show of love to her,$NEWLINE$Thou shalt aby it.
paragraphs.translated: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$You’re doing too much to defend a woman who wants nothing to do with you. Leave Hermia alone. Don’t talk about Helena. Don’t take Helena’s side. If you continue treating Hermia so badly, you’ll pay for it.

paragraphs.original: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$Now she holds me not.$NEWLINE$Now follow, if thou darest, to try whose right,$NEWLINE$Of thine or mine, is most in Helena.
paragraphs.translated: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$Hermia’s not holding onto me anymore. Follow me if you’re brave enough, and we’ll fight over Helena.

paragraphs.original: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$“Follow”? Nay, I’ll go with thee, cheek by jowl.
paragraphs.translated: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$“Follow”? No, I’ll walk right next to you, side by side.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt LYSANDER and DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$LYSANDER$NEWLINE$DEMETRIUS
paragraphs.translated: DEMETRIUS and LYSANDER exit.$NEWLINE$DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$LYSANDER

paragraphs.original: HERMIA$NEWLINE$You, mistress, all this coil is long of you.$NEWLINE$Nay, go not back.
paragraphs.translated: HERMIA$NEWLINE$All this fighting is because of you. Stay where you are.

paragraphs.original: HELENA$NEWLINE$I will not trust you, I,$NEWLINE$Nor longer stay in your curst company.$NEWLINE$Your hands than mine are quicker for a fray.$NEWLINE$My legs are longer though, to run away.
paragraphs.translated: HELENA$NEWLINE$I’m not sticking around here any more. I don’t trust you. You might be a better fighter than I am, but my legs are longer and I can run away faster.

paragraphs.original: Exit HELENA$NEWLINE$HELENA
paragraphs.translated: HELENA exits.$NEWLINE$HELENA

paragraphs.original: HERMIA$NEWLINE$I am amazed and know not what to say.
paragraphs.translated: HERMIA$NEWLINE$I just can’t believe any of this. I don’t know what to say.

paragraphs.original: Exit HERMIA$NEWLINE$HERMIA
paragraphs.translated: HERMIA exits.$NEWLINE$HERMIA

paragraphs.original: OBERON$NEWLINE$(to ROBIN) This is thy negligence. Still thou mistakest,$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Or else committ’st thy knaveries willfully.
paragraphs.translated: OBERON$NEWLINE$(to ROBIN) This is all your fault. You make mistakes constantly, or else you cause this kind of trouble on purpose.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ROBIN$NEWLINE$Believe me, King of Shadows, I mistook.$NEWLINE$Did not you tell me I should know the man$NEWLINE$By the Athenian garment he had on?$NEWLINE$And so far blameless proves my enterprise,$NEWLINE$That I have 'nointed an Athenian’s eyes.$NEWLINE$And so far am I glad it so did sort,$NEWLINE$As this their jangling I esteem a sport.
paragraphs.translated: ROBIN$NEWLINE$Believe me, King of Illusions, I made a mistake. Didn’t you tell me that I’d be able to recognize the man by the Athenian clothes he was wearing? So far I’ve done exactly what I was supposed to do—I put the love potion on an Athenian’s eyes. And so far I’m pleased with the way things have turned out, since I find all of this commotion very entertaining.

paragraphs.original: OBERON$NEWLINE$Thou seest these lovers seek a place to fight.$NEWLINE$Hie therefore, Robin, overcast the night.$NEWLINE$The starry welkin cover thou anon$NEWLINE$With drooping fog as black as Acheron,$NEWLINE$And lead these testy rivals so astray$NEWLINE$As one come not within another’s way.$NEWLINE$Like to Lysander sometime frame thy tongue,$NEWLINE$Then stir Demetrius up with bitter wrong.$NEWLINE$And sometime rail thou like Demetrius.$NEWLINE$And from each other look thou lead them thus,$NEWLINE$Till o'er their brows death-counterfeiting sleep$NEWLINE$With leaden legs and batty wings doth creep.$NEWLINE$(gives ROBIN another flower)$NEWLINE$(gives$NEWLINE$another flower)$NEWLINE$Then crush this herb into Lysander’s eye,$NEWLINE$Whose liquor hath this virtuous property$NEWLINE$To take from thence all error with his might$NEWLINE$And make his eyeballs roll with wonted sight.$NEWLINE$When they next wake, all this derision$NEWLINE$Shall seem a dream and fruitless vision.$NEWLINE$And back to Athens shall the lovers wend,$NEWLINE$With league whose date till death shall never end.$NEWLINE$Whiles I in this affair do thee employ,$NEWLINE$I’ll to my queen and beg her Indian boy.$NEWLINE$And then I will her charmèd eye release$NEWLINE$From monster’s view, and all things shall be peace.
paragraphs.translated: OBERON$NEWLINE$As you can see, these lovers are looking for a place to fight. Hurry up, Robin, and make the night dark and cloudy. Cover the sky with a low-hanging fog, as dark as hell, and get these overeager rivals so completely lost in the woods that they can’t run into each other. Imitate Lysander’s voice and egg Demetrius on with insults. Then rant for a while in Demetrius’s voice, and egg Lysander on. That way you’ll get them away from each other until they’re so exhausted that they’ll sleep like the dead. ( OBERON gives a new flower to ROBIN) When they’re asleep, crush some of this flower’s juice into Lysander’s eyes. The flower’s juice has the power to erase all the damage that’s been done to his eyes, and to make him see normally, the way he used to. When they wake up, all this trouble and conflict will seem like a dream or a meaningless vision. Then the lovers will go back to Athens, united together until death. While you’re busy with that, I’ll go see Queen Titania and ask her once again for the Indian boy. And then I’ll undo the spell that I cast over her, so she won’t be in love with that monster anymore. Then everything will be peaceful again.$NEWLINE$($NEWLINE$gives a new flower to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ROBIN$NEWLINE$My fairy lord, this must be done with haste.$NEWLINE$For night’s swift dragons cut the clouds full fast,$NEWLINE$And yonder shines Aurora’s harbinger,$NEWLINE$At whose approach, ghosts, wandering here and there,$NEWLINE$Troop home to churchyards. Damnèd spirits all,$NEWLINE$That in crossways and floods have burial,$NEWLINE$Already to their wormy beds are gone.$NEWLINE$For fear lest day should look their shames upon,$NEWLINE$They willfully themselves exile from light$NEWLINE$And must for aye consort with black-browed night.
paragraphs.translated: ROBIN$NEWLINE$We’ve got to act fast, my lord of the fairies. Night’s fading quickly, and in the distance the morning star is shining, warning us that dawn is coming. At dawn, the ghosts that have been wandering around all night go home to the graveyards. The souls of people who weren’t buried in holy ground, but instead lie rotting by the side of the road or at the bottom of a river, have already gone back to their wormy graves. They weren’t buried in a real graveyard because they committed suicide, and they don’t want their shame to be seen in daylight, so they avoid sunlight and stay forever in the darkness of night.

paragraphs.original: OBERON$NEWLINE$But we are spirits of another sort.$NEWLINE$I with the morning’s love have oft made sport,$NEWLINE$And like a forester the groves may tread$NEWLINE$Even till the eastern gate, all fiery red,$NEWLINE$Opening on Neptune with fair blessèd beams,$NEWLINE$Turns into yellow gold his salt green streams.$NEWLINE$But notwithstanding, haste. Make no delay.$NEWLINE$We may effect this business yet ere day.
paragraphs.translated: OBERON$NEWLINE$But we’re not like that. We’re a different kind of spirit, and we don’t have to run away from the sunlight. I like the morning. I often wander around in the woods like a forest ranger until the sun rises in the fiery red sky over the ocean, turning the salty green water to gold. But you should hurry anyway. Don’t delay. We still have time to get all of this done before daybreak.

paragraphs.original: Exit OBERON$NEWLINE$OBERON
paragraphs.translated: OBERON exits.$NEWLINE$OBERON

paragraphs.original: ROBIN$NEWLINE$Up and down, up and down,$NEWLINE$I will lead them up and down.$NEWLINE$I am feared in field and town.$NEWLINE$Goblin, lead them up and down.$NEWLINE$Here comes one.
paragraphs.translated: ROBIN$NEWLINE$Up and down, up and down,$NEWLINE$I will lead them up and down.$NEWLINE$The people fear me in the country and the town.$NEWLINE$Goblin, lead them up and down.$NEWLINE$Here comes one of them now.

paragraphs.original: Enter LYSANDER$NEWLINE$LYSANDER
paragraphs.translated: LYSANDER enters.$NEWLINE$LYSANDER

paragraphs.original: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$Where art thou, proud Demetrius? Speak thou now.
paragraphs.translated: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$Where are you, Demetrius, you arrogant bastard? Say something.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ROBIN$NEWLINE$(as DEMETRIUS)$NEWLINE$(as$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Here, villain. Drawn and ready. Where art thou?
paragraphs.translated: ROBIN$NEWLINE$(in DEMETRIUS’s voice) I’m over here, you villain, with my sword out and ready to fight. Where are you?$NEWLINE$(in$NEWLINE$’s voice)

paragraphs.original: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$I will be with thee straight.
paragraphs.translated: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$I’m coming.

paragraphs.original: ROBIN$NEWLINE$(as DEMETRIUS) Follow me then$NEWLINE$(as$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$To plainer ground.
paragraphs.translated: ROBIN$NEWLINE$(in DEMETRIUS’s voice) Let’s go to a flatter area where we can fight more easily.$NEWLINE$(in$NEWLINE$’s voice)

paragraphs.original: Exit LYSANDER$NEWLINE$LYSANDER
paragraphs.translated: LYSANDER exits.$NEWLINE$LYSANDER

paragraphs.original: Enter DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$DEMETRIUS
paragraphs.translated: DEMETRIUS enters.$NEWLINE$DEMETRIUS

paragraphs.original: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$Lysander, speak again!$NEWLINE$Thou runaway, thou coward, art thou fled?$NEWLINE$Speak! In some bush? Where dost thou hide thy head?
paragraphs.translated: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$Lysander, say something! You coward, did you run away from me? Say something! Are you behind some bush? Where are you hiding?

paragraphs.original: ROBIN$NEWLINE$(as LYSANDER) Thou coward, art thou bragging to the stars,$NEWLINE$(as$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Telling the bushes that thou look’st for wars,$NEWLINE$And wilt not come? Come, recreant. Come, thou child!$NEWLINE$I’ll whip thee with a rod. He is defiled$NEWLINE$That draws a sword on thee.
paragraphs.translated: ROBIN$NEWLINE$(in LYSANDER’s voice) You coward, are you bragging to the stars and telling the bushes that you want a fight, but then you won’t come and fight me? Come here, you coward! Come here, you child! I’ll beat you with a stick. It would be shameful to fight you with a sword, the way I would fight with a real man.$NEWLINE$(in$NEWLINE$’s voice)

paragraphs.original: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$Yea, art thou there?
paragraphs.translated: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$Are you there?

paragraphs.original: ROBIN$NEWLINE$(as LYSANDER)$NEWLINE$(as$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Follow my voice. We’ll try no manhood here.
paragraphs.translated: ROBIN$NEWLINE$(in LYSANDER’s voice) Follow my voice. This isn’t a good place to fight.$NEWLINE$(in$NEWLINE$’s voice)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter LYSANDER$NEWLINE$LYSANDER
paragraphs.translated: LYSANDER enters.$NEWLINE$LYSANDER

paragraphs.original: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$He goes before me and still dares me on.$NEWLINE$When I come where he calls, then he is gone.$NEWLINE$The villain is much lighter-heeled than I.$NEWLINE$I followed fast, but faster he did fly,$NEWLINE$That fallen am I in dark uneven way,
paragraphs.translated: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$He’s walking ahead of me, and he keeps daring me to follow him. When I reach the place he’s calling from, he disappears. This villain is much quicker than I am. I ran after him fast, but he ran away from me faster, so that now here I am in some dark part of the forest where the ground is uneven.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: And here will rest me.$NEWLINE$(lies down)$NEWLINE$(lies down)$NEWLINE$Come, thou gentle day!$NEWLINE$For if but once thou show me thy grey light,$NEWLINE$I’ll find Demetrius and revenge this spite.$NEWLINE$(sleeps)$NEWLINE$(sleeps)
paragraphs.translated: I’ll rest here. (he lies down) I hope the pleasant daytime comes soon! As soon as the gray light of early morning appears, I’ll find Demetrius and get my revenge for this insult.$NEWLINE$(he lies down)

paragraphs.original: Enter ROBIN and DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$ROBIN$NEWLINE$DEMETRIUS
paragraphs.translated: LYSANDER lies down and falls asleep. ROBIN and DEMETRIUS enter.$NEWLINE$LYSANDER$NEWLINE$ROBIN$NEWLINE$DEMETRIUS

paragraphs.original: ROBIN$NEWLINE$(as LYSANDER to DEMETRIUS)$NEWLINE$(as$NEWLINE$to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Ho, ho, ho! Coward, why comest thou not?
paragraphs.translated: ROBIN$NEWLINE$(in LYSANDER’s voice) Ha, ha, ha! Hey, You coward, why aren’t you coming?$NEWLINE$(in$NEWLINE$’s voice)

paragraphs.original: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$Abide me, if thou darest! For well I wot$NEWLINE$Thou runn’st before me, shifting every place,$NEWLINE$And darest not stand nor look me in the face.$NEWLINE$Where art thou now?
paragraphs.translated: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$Wait for me, if you’re not too scared! I know that’s why you’re running away from me, constantly changing places—you’re afraid to stand still and wait for me. You’re scared to look me in the eye. Where are you now?

paragraphs.original: ROBIN$NEWLINE$(as LYSANDER) Come hither. I am here.$NEWLINE$(as$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: ROBIN$NEWLINE$(in LYSANDER’s voice) Come here. I’m over here.$NEWLINE$(in$NEWLINE$’s voice)

paragraphs.original: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$Nay, then, thou mock’st me. Thou shalt buy this dear$NEWLINE$If ever I thy face by daylight see.$NEWLINE$Now go thy way. Faintness constraineth me$NEWLINE$To measure out my length on this cold bed.$NEWLINE$By day’s approach look to be visited.$NEWLINE$(lies down and sleeps)$NEWLINE$(lies down and sleeps)
paragraphs.translated: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$No, you’re just taunting me. You’ll pay for this if I ever see you face-to-face in the daylight. Go wherever you want. I’m exhausted; I need to lie down and sleep on this cold ground. But watch out. I’ll find you at dawn. (DEMETRIUS lies down and sleeps)$NEWLINE$($NEWLINE$lies down and sleeps)

paragraphs.original: Enter HELENA$NEWLINE$HELENA
paragraphs.translated: HELENA enters.$NEWLINE$HELENA

paragraphs.original: HELENA$NEWLINE$O weary night, O long and tedious night,$NEWLINE$Abate thy hours. Shine comforts from the east,$NEWLINE$That I may back to Athens by daylight$NEWLINE$From these that my poor company detest.$NEWLINE$And sleep, that sometimes shuts up sorrow’s eye,$NEWLINE$Steal me awhile from mine own company.$NEWLINE$(lies down and sleeps)$NEWLINE$(lies down and sleeps)
paragraphs.translated: HELENA$NEWLINE$Oh, what a long, tedious, exhausting night! I wish it would end. I wish the comforting light of day would shine so I can go back to Athens and get away from these people who hate me so much. I hope I’ll be able to sleep and escape my troubles for a while. People can sometimes forget their difficulties when they’re asleep. (HELENA lies down and sleeps)$NEWLINE$($NEWLINE$lies down and sleeps)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ROBIN$NEWLINE$Yet but three? Come one more.$NEWLINE$Two of both kinds make up four.$NEWLINE$Here she comes, cursed and sad.$NEWLINE$Cupid is a knavish lad$NEWLINE$Thus to make poor females mad.
paragraphs.translated: ROBIN$NEWLINE$Only three so far? We’re still waiting for one more. Two of both kinds makes four. Ah, here she comes, angry and sad. Cupid is a bad boy for making poor women go crazy like this.

paragraphs.original: Enter HERMIA$NEWLINE$HERMIA
paragraphs.translated: HERMIA enters.$NEWLINE$HERMIA

paragraphs.original: HERMIA$NEWLINE$Never so weary, never so in woe,$NEWLINE$Bedabbled with the dew and torn with briers,$NEWLINE$I can no further crawl, no further go.$NEWLINE$My legs can keep no pace with my desires.$NEWLINE$Here will I rest me till the break of day.$NEWLINE$Heavens shield Lysander if they mean a fray!$NEWLINE$(lies down and sleeps)$NEWLINE$(lies down and sleeps)
paragraphs.translated: HERMIA$NEWLINE$I’ve never been more exhausted or upset. I’m all wet from the dew and scratched up by thorns, and I can’t crawl any farther. I just can’t go on. My legs can’t hold themselves up. I’ll sleep here until morning. If they do fight, I hope Lysander is safe! (HERMIA lies down and sleeps)$NEWLINE$($NEWLINE$lies down and sleeps)

paragraphs.original: ROBIN$NEWLINE$On the ground$NEWLINE$Sleep sound.$NEWLINE$I’ll apply$NEWLINE$To your eye.$NEWLINE$Gentle lover, remedy.$NEWLINE$(squeezes flower juice into LYSANDER ’s eyes)$NEWLINE$(squeezes flower juice into$NEWLINE$’s eyes)$NEWLINE$When thou wakest,$NEWLINE$Thou takest$NEWLINE$True delight$NEWLINE$In the sight$NEWLINE$Of thy former lady’s eye.$NEWLINE$And the country proverb known—$NEWLINE$That every man should take his own—$NEWLINE$In your waking shall be shown.$NEWLINE$Jack shall have Jill.$NEWLINE$Nought shall go ill.$NEWLINE$The man shall have his mare again, and all shall be well.
paragraphs.translated: ROBIN$NEWLINE$Sleep well there on the ground. I’ll cure you, gentle lover, by putting this medicine on your eyes. (ROBIN puts the nectar of the flower on LYSANDER’s eyelids) When you wake you will be truly delighted to see the woman you once loved. And when you wake up, you’ll be a walking illustration of the well-known country proverb. “Jack will have Jill and everything will be all right.”$NEWLINE$($NEWLINE$puts the nectar of the flower on$NEWLINE$’s eyelids)

paragraphs.original: Exit ROBIN$NEWLINE$ROBIN
paragraphs.translated: ROBIN exits.$NEWLINE$ROBIN

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA sleep. Enter TITANIA, Queen of the Fairies; and BOTTOM, with the ass’s head; and fairies PEASEBLOSSOM, COBWEB, MOTH, MUSTARDSEED; OBERON the king behind them, unseen$NEWLINE$LYSANDER$NEWLINE$DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$HELENA$NEWLINE$HERMIA$NEWLINE$TITANIA$NEWLINE$BOTTOM$NEWLINE$PEASEBLOSSOM$NEWLINE$COBWEB$NEWLINE$MOTH$NEWLINE$MUSTARDSEED$NEWLINE$OBERON
paragraphs.translated: DEMETRIUS, HELENA, HERMIA, and LYSANDER are still sleeping on the stage. TITANIA enters with BOTTOM, who still has a donkey’s head, and the fairies PEASEBLOSSOM, COBWEB, MOTH, and MUSTARDSEED. OBERON enters behind them, unseen by those onstage.$NEWLINE$DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$HELENA$NEWLINE$HERMIA$NEWLINE$LYSANDER$NEWLINE$TITANIA$NEWLINE$BOTTOM$NEWLINE$PEASEBLOSSOM$NEWLINE$COBWEB$NEWLINE$MOTH$NEWLINE$MUSTARDSEED$NEWLINE$OBERON

paragraphs.original: TITANIA$NEWLINE$(to BOTTOM) Come, sit thee down upon this flowery bed$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$While I thy amiable cheeks do coy,$NEWLINE$And stick musk roses in thy sleek, smooth head,$NEWLINE$And kiss thy fair large ears, my gentle joy.
paragraphs.translated: TITANIA$NEWLINE$(to BOTTOM) Come over here and sit down on this flowery bed while I caress those lovable cheeks. I’ll put roses on your silky, smooth head and kiss your big, beautiful ears, my gentle darling.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$Where’s Peaseblossom?
paragraphs.translated: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$Where’s Peaseblossom?

paragraphs.original: PEASEBLOSSOM$NEWLINE$Ready.
paragraphs.translated: PEASEBLOSSOM$NEWLINE$Here.

paragraphs.original: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$Scratch my head, Peaseblossom. Where’s Monsieur Cobweb?
paragraphs.translated: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$Scratch my head, Peaseblossom. Where’s Monsieur Cobweb?

paragraphs.original: COBWEB$NEWLINE$Ready.
paragraphs.translated: COBWEB$NEWLINE$Here.

paragraphs.original: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$Monsieur Cobweb, good monsieur, get you your weapons in your hand and kill me a red-hipped humble-bee on the top of a thistle. And, good monsieur, bring me the honey bag. Do not fret yourself too much in the action, monsieur. And good monsieur, have a care the honey bag break not. I would be loath to have you overflown with a honey bag, signor.
paragraphs.translated: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$Monsieur Cobweb, sir, get out your weapons and kill me a striped bumblebee on a thistle, and bring me its honey. Don’t tire yourself out, monsieur. Oh, and monsieur, be careful not to break the honey-sac. I’d hate to see you drowned in honey, sir.

paragraphs.original: Exit COBWEB$NEWLINE$COBWEB
paragraphs.translated: COBWEB exits.$NEWLINE$COBWEB

paragraphs.original: Where’s Monsieur Mustardseed?
paragraphs.translated: Where’s Monsieur Mustardseed?

paragraphs.original: MUSTARDSEED$NEWLINE$Ready.
paragraphs.translated: MUSTARDSEED$NEWLINE$Here.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$Give me your neaf, Monsieur Mustardseed. Pray you, leave your courtesy, good monsieur.
paragraphs.translated: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$Give me your first, Mr. Mustardseed. Please, stop bowing, good sir.

paragraphs.original: MUSTARDSEED$NEWLINE$What’s your will?
paragraphs.translated: MUSTARDSEED$NEWLINE$What would you like me to do?

paragraphs.original: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$Nothing, good monsieur, but to help Cavalery Cobweb to scratch. I must to the barber’s, monsieur, for methinks I am marvelous hairy about the face. And I am such a tender ass, if my hair do but tickle me, I must scratch.
paragraphs.translated: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$Nothing, good sir, except to help Sir Cobweb scratch my head. I should go to the barber’s, monsieur, because I think I’m getting really hairy around the face. And I’m such a sensitive ass that if my hair even tickles me a little, I need to scratch.

paragraphs.original: TITANIA$NEWLINE$What, wilt thou hear some music, my sweet love?
paragraphs.translated: TITANIA$NEWLINE$Would you like to hear some music, my sweet love?

paragraphs.original: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$I have a reasonable good ear in music. Let’s have the tongs and the bones.
paragraphs.translated: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$I have a pretty good ear for music. Let’s hear someone play the triangle and the sticks.

paragraphs.original: TITANIA$NEWLINE$Or say, sweet love, what thou desirest to eat.
paragraphs.translated: TITANIA$NEWLINE$Or tell me, my sweet love, what you’d like to eat.

paragraphs.original: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$Truly, a peck of provender. I could munch your good dry oats. Methinks I have a great desire to a bottle of hay. Good hay, sweet hay, hath no fellow.
paragraphs.translated: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$Actually, I’d like a few pounds of grass. I’d like to munch on some good dry oats. Or maybe I’ve got a hankering for a bundle of hay. There’s nothing like good hay, really sweet hay.

paragraphs.original: TITANIA$NEWLINE$I have a venturous fairy that shall seek$NEWLINE$The squirrel’s hoard and fetch thee new nuts.
paragraphs.translated: TITANIA$NEWLINE$I have an adventurous fairy who’ll go seek out the squirrel’s secret stash and get you some fresh nuts.

paragraphs.original: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$I had rather have a handful or two of dried peas. But, I pray you, let none of your people stir me. I have an exposition of sleep come upon me.
paragraphs.translated: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$I’d rather have a handful or two of dried peas. But please don’t let any of your people wake me up. I really want to sleep now.

paragraphs.original: TITANIA$NEWLINE$Sleep thou, and I will wind thee in my arms.$NEWLINE$Fairies, be gone, and be all ways away.
paragraphs.translated: TITANIA$NEWLINE$Go to sleep, and I will wrap my arms around you. Fairies, go away. Run off in all directions.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt FAIRIES$NEWLINE$FAIRIES
paragraphs.translated: The FAIRIES exit.$NEWLINE$FAIRIES

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: So doth the woodbine the sweet honeysuckle$NEWLINE$Gently entwist. The female ivy so$NEWLINE$Enrings the barky fingers of the elm.$NEWLINE$Oh, how I love thee! How I dote on thee!
paragraphs.translated: I’m putting my arms around you just like the woodbine tendril gently twists itself around the sweet honeysuckle, and like the female ivy curls itself around the branches of the elm tree. Oh, how I love you! I’m so crazy about you!

paragraphs.original: TITANIA and BOTTOM sleep$NEWLINE$TITANIA$NEWLINE$BOTTOM
paragraphs.translated: BOTTOM and TITANIA sleep. ROBIN enters.$NEWLINE$BOTTOM$NEWLINE$TITANIA$NEWLINE$ROBIN

paragraphs.original: Enter ROBIN$NEWLINE$ROBIN

OBERON$NEWLINE$Welcome, good Robin. Seest thou this sweet sight?$NEWLINE$Her dotage now I do begin to pity.$NEWLINE$For, meeting her of late behind the wood,$NEWLINE$Seeking sweet favors from this hateful fool,$NEWLINE$I did upbraid her and fall out with her.$NEWLINE$For she his hairy temples then had rounded$NEWLINE$With a coronet of fresh and fragrant flowers,$NEWLINE$And that same dew, which sometime on the buds$NEWLINE$Was wont to swell like round and orient pearls,$NEWLINE$Stood now within the pretty flowerets' eyes$NEWLINE$Like tears that did their own disgrace bewail.$NEWLINE$When I had at my pleasure taunted her$NEWLINE$And she in mild terms begged my patience,$NEWLINE$I then did ask of her her changeling child,$NEWLINE$Which straight she gave me and her fairy sent$NEWLINE$To bear him to my bower in Fairyland.$NEWLINE$And now I have the boy, I will undo$NEWLINE$This hateful imperfection of her eyes.$NEWLINE$And, gentle Puck, take this transformèd scalp$NEWLINE$From off the head of this Athenian swain,$NEWLINE$That, he awaking when the other do,$NEWLINE$May all to Athens back again repair$NEWLINE$And think no more of this night’s accidents$NEWLINE$But as the fierce vexation of a dream.$NEWLINE$But first I will release the fairy queen.
paragraphs.translated: OBERON$NEWLINE$Welcome, good Robin. Do you see this sweet sight? Now I’m starting to pity Titania for being so infatuated. I ran into her recently at the edge of the forest, looking for sweet presents for this hateful idiot, and I scolded her and argued with her. She had put a wreath of fresh, fragrant flowers around his hairy forehead, and the drops of dew that lay in the center of the flowers made the flowers look like they were crying with shame to be decorating the head of that ugly jackass. When I had taunted her as much as I wanted to, and she begged me very nicely to leave her alone, I asked her for the stolen Indian child. She said yes right away, and sent a fairy to bring him to my home in Fairyland. And now that I have the boy, I’ll undo the spell that makes her vision so disgustingly wrong. And, gentle Puck, take this transformed ass’s head off of the head of that Athenian man, so that when he wakes up at the same time as the rest of them do, they can all go back to Athens. They’ll only remember the events of tonight as a very unpleasant dream. But first I’ll release the fairy queen from the spell.

paragraphs.original: (squeezing flower juice into TITANIA’s eyes)$NEWLINE$TITANIA
paragraphs.translated: (OBERON squeezes the juice from the second flower into TITANIA’s eyes)$NEWLINE$OBERON$NEWLINE$TITANIA

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Be as thou wast wont to be.$NEWLINE$See as thou wast wont to see.$NEWLINE$Dian’s bud o'er Cupid’s flower$NEWLINE$Hath such force and blessèd power.$NEWLINE$Now, my Titania, wake you, my sweet queen.
paragraphs.translated: Be like you used to be, and see like you used to see. This bud belongs to Diana, the goddess of virginity, and it has the power to undo the effects of Cupid’s flower. Now, Titania, wake up, my sweet queen.

paragraphs.original: TITANIA$NEWLINE$(waking) My Oberon, what visions have I seen!$NEWLINE$(waking)$NEWLINE$Methought I was enamored of an ass.
paragraphs.translated: TITANIA$NEWLINE$(waking up) Oberon, I’ve had such a strange dream! I dreamed I was in love with an ass.$NEWLINE$(waking up)

paragraphs.original: OBERON$NEWLINE$There lies your love.
paragraphs.translated: OBERON$NEWLINE$There’s your boyfriend, sleeping right over there.

paragraphs.original: TITANIA$NEWLINE$How came these things to pass?$NEWLINE$Oh, how mine eyes do loathe his visage now!
paragraphs.translated: TITANIA$NEWLINE$How did this happen? Oh, I hate looking at his face now!

paragraphs.original: OBERON$NEWLINE$Silence awhile.—Robin, take off this head.—$NEWLINE$Titania, music call, and strike more dead$NEWLINE$Than common sleep of all these five the sense.
paragraphs.translated: OBERON$NEWLINE$Be quiet for a while.—Robin, take off his donkey head.—Titania, get the fairies to play some music, and make these five people sleep more soundly than humans have ever slept before.

paragraphs.original: TITANIA$NEWLINE$Music, ho! Music such as charmeth sleep!
paragraphs.translated: TITANIA$NEWLINE$Music! Play the kind of music that puts people to sleep.

paragraphs.original: Music
paragraphs.translated: The music plays.

paragraphs.original: ROBIN$NEWLINE$(taking the ass’s head off BOTTOM)$NEWLINE$(taking the ass’s head off$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Now when thou wakest, with thine own fool’s eyes peep.
paragraphs.translated: ROBIN$NEWLINE$(removing the ass’s head from BOTTOM) When you wake up, see things with your own foolish eyes again.$NEWLINE$(removing the ass’s head from$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: OBERON$NEWLINE$Sound, music!—Come, my queen, take hands with me,$NEWLINE$And rock the ground whereon these sleepers be.$NEWLINE$(dances with TITANIA)$NEWLINE$(dances with$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Now thou and I are new in amity,$NEWLINE$And will tomorrow midnight solemnly$NEWLINE$Dance in Duke Theseus' house triumphantly,$NEWLINE$And bless it to all fair prosperity.$NEWLINE$There shall the pairs of faithful lovers be$NEWLINE$Wedded, with Theseus, all in jollity.
paragraphs.translated: OBERON$NEWLINE$Play the music.—Take my hands, my queen, and we’ll lull these people to sleep with our soft dancing. (he dances with TITANIA) Now that you and I are friends again, we can dance for Duke Theseus tomorrow at midnight, and bless his marriage and his marriage bed. These other lovers will get married alongside him, and they’ll all be in high spirits.$NEWLINE$(he dances with$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ROBIN$NEWLINE$Fairy King, attend, and mark.$NEWLINE$I do hear the morning lark.
paragraphs.translated: ROBIN$NEWLINE$Listen, Fairy King. I can hear the lark singing. Morning’s here.

paragraphs.original: OBERON$NEWLINE$Then, my queen, in silence sad,$NEWLINE$Trip we after the night’s shade.$NEWLINE$We the globe can compass soon$NEWLINE$Swifter than the wandering moon.
paragraphs.translated: OBERON$NEWLINE$In that case, my queen, let’s travel silently and solemnly across the globe to where it’s still night, circling the earth faster than the moon does.

paragraphs.original: TITANIA$NEWLINE$Come, my lord, and in our flight$NEWLINE$Tell me how it came this night$NEWLINE$That I sleeping here was found$NEWLINE$With these mortals on the ground.
paragraphs.translated: TITANIA$NEWLINE$While we’re walking, you can tell me how I ended up sleeping on the ground with these humans last night.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt OBERON, TITANIA, and ROBIN$NEWLINE$OBERON$NEWLINE$TITANIA$NEWLINE$ROBIN
paragraphs.translated: OBERON, TITANIA, and ROBIN exit.$NEWLINE$OBERON$NEWLINE$TITANIA$NEWLINE$ROBIN

paragraphs.original: Wind horn within Enter THESEUS and all his train, EGEUS, and HIPPOLYTA$NEWLINE$THESEUS$NEWLINE$EGEUS$NEWLINE$HIPPOLYTA
paragraphs.translated: A hunting horn blows. THESEUS enters with his servants, EGEUS and HIPPOLYTA.$NEWLINE$THESEUS$NEWLINE$EGEUS$NEWLINE$HIPPOLYTA

paragraphs.original: THESEUS$NEWLINE$Go, one of you, find out the forester.$NEWLINE$For now our observation is performed.$NEWLINE$And since we have the vaward of the day,$NEWLINE$My love shall hear the music of my hounds.$NEWLINE$Uncouple in the western valley. Let them go.$NEWLINE$Dispatch, I say, and find the forester.
paragraphs.translated: THESEUS$NEWLINE$One of you go find the forest ranger. Since we’re done with the May Day rites and it’s still so early in the morning, my love will have a chance to hear the beautiful music of my hunting dogs barking as they chase their prey. Unleash the dogs in the western valley. Let them go. Now go find the forest ranger.

paragraphs.original: Exit one of the train
paragraphs.translated: A servant exits.

paragraphs.original: We will, fair queen, up to the mountain’s top,$NEWLINE$And mark the musical confusion$NEWLINE$Of hounds and echo in conjunction.
paragraphs.translated: My beautiful queen, we’ll go up the mountain and listen to the hounds as their barking echoes in the cliffs and sounds like music.

paragraphs.original: HIPPOLYTA$NEWLINE$I was with Hercules and Cadmus once,$NEWLINE$When in a wood of Crete they bayed the bear$NEWLINE$With hounds of Sparta. Never did I hear$NEWLINE$Such gallant chiding. For, besides the groves,
paragraphs.translated: HIPPOLYTA$NEWLINE$I was with the heroes Hercules and Cadmus once, when their Spartan hunting dogs cornered a bear. I’d never heard such impressive barking before.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: The skies, the fountains, every region near$NEWLINE$Seemed all one mutual cry. I never heard$NEWLINE$So musical a discord, such sweet thunder.
paragraphs.translated: The forests, the skies, the mountains, everything around us seemed to echo the barks of the hounds. I’d never heard such raucous music, such pleasant thunder.

paragraphs.original: THESEUS$NEWLINE$My hounds are bred out of the Spartan kind,$NEWLINE$So flewed, so sanded, and their heads are hung$NEWLINE$With ears that sweep away the morning dew,$NEWLINE$Crook-kneed, and dew-lapped like Thessalian bulls,$NEWLINE$Slow in pursuit, but matched in mouth like bells,$NEWLINE$Each under each. A cry more tunable$NEWLINE$Was never hollaed to, nor cheered with horn,$NEWLINE$In Crete, in Sparta, nor in Thessaly.$NEWLINE$Judge when you hear.$NEWLINE$(sees the four sleeping lovers)$NEWLINE$(sees the four sleeping lovers)$NEWLINE$But, soft! What nymphs are these?
paragraphs.translated: THESEUS$NEWLINE$My dogs are bred from Spartan hounds. They have the same folds of flesh around their mouths, the same sandy-colored fur, and hanging ears that brush the morning dew off the grass. They have crooked knees and folds of skin under their necks, just like the Spartan hounds. They’re not very fast in the chase, but their barking sounds like bells ringing. Each bark is perfectly in tune with the others, like notes on a scale. No one, anywhere, has ever gone hunting with a more musical pack of dogs. Judge for yourself when you hear them. (he sees the four lovers sleeping) But wait a minute! Who are these women?$NEWLINE$(he sees the four lovers sleeping)

paragraphs.original: EGEUS$NEWLINE$My lord, this is my daughter here asleep.$NEWLINE$And this, Lysander. This Demetrius is.$NEWLINE$This Helena, old Nedar’s Helena.$NEWLINE$I wonder of their being here together.
paragraphs.translated: EGEUS$NEWLINE$My lord, that’s my daughter asleep on the ground over there, and this is Lysander here, and this is Demetrius, and this is Helena, old Nedar’s daughter. I don’t understand why they’re all here together.

paragraphs.original: THESEUS$NEWLINE$No doubt they rose up early to observe$NEWLINE$The rite of May, and hearing our intent$NEWLINE$Came here in grace our solemnity.$NEWLINE$But speak, Egeus. Is not this the day$NEWLINE$That Hermia should give answer of her choice?
paragraphs.translated: THESEUS$NEWLINE$They probably woke up early to celebrate May Day and came here for my celebration when they heard I’d be here. But tell me, Egeus. Isn’t today the day when Hermia has to tell us her decision about whether she’ll marry Demetrius?

paragraphs.original: EGEUS$NEWLINE$It is, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: EGEUS$NEWLINE$It is, my lord.

paragraphs.original: THESEUS$NEWLINE$Go, bid the huntsmen wake them with their horns.
paragraphs.translated: THESEUS$NEWLINE$Go tell the hunters to blow their horns and wake them up.

paragraphs.original: Exit one of the train
paragraphs.translated: A servant exits.

paragraphs.original: Wind horns and shout within LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA wake and start up$NEWLINE$LYSANDER$NEWLINE$DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$HELENA$NEWLINE$HERMIA
paragraphs.translated: Someone shouts offstage. Horns are blown. LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA, wake up.$NEWLINE$LYSANDER$NEWLINE$DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$HELENA$NEWLINE$HERMIA

paragraphs.original: Good morrow, friends. Saint Valentine is past.
paragraphs.translated: Good morning, my friends. Valentine’s Day is over.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Begin these woodbirds but to couple now?
paragraphs.translated: Are you lovebirds only starting to pair up now?

paragraphs.original: LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA kneel$NEWLINE$LYSANDER$NEWLINE$DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$HELENA$NEWLINE$HERMIA
paragraphs.translated: LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA all kneel.$NEWLINE$LYSANDER$NEWLINE$DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$HELENA$NEWLINE$HERMIA

paragraphs.original: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$Pardon, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$Forgive us, my lord.

paragraphs.original: THESEUS$NEWLINE$I pray you all, stand up.
paragraphs.translated: THESEUS$NEWLINE$Please, all of you, stand up.

paragraphs.original: LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA stand$NEWLINE$LYSANDER$NEWLINE$DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$HELENA$NEWLINE$HERMIA
paragraphs.translated: LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA get up.$NEWLINE$LYSANDER$NEWLINE$DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$HELENA$NEWLINE$HERMIA

paragraphs.original: (to LYSANDER and DEMETRIUS)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$and$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$I know you two are rival enemies.$NEWLINE$How comes this gentle concord in the world,$NEWLINE$That hatred is so far from jealousy$NEWLINE$To sleep by hate and fear no enmity?
paragraphs.translated: (to LYSANDER and DEMETRIUS) I know you two are enemies. Has the world really become so gentle and peaceful that people who hate each other have started to trust each other and sleep beside each other without being afraid?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$and$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$My lord, I shall reply amazèdly,$NEWLINE$Half sleep, half waking. But as yet, I swear,$NEWLINE$I cannot truly say how I came here.$NEWLINE$But as I think—for truly would I speak,$NEWLINE$And now do I bethink me, so it is—$NEWLINE$I came with Hermia hither. Our intent$NEWLINE$Was to be gone from Athens, where we might,$NEWLINE$Without the peril of the Athenian law—
paragraphs.translated: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$My lord, what I say may be a little confused, since I’m half asleep and half awake. I swear, at the moment I really couldn’t tell you how I ended up here. But I think—I want to tell you the truth, and now that I think about it, I think this is true—I came here with Hermia. We were planning to leave Athens to escape the Athenian law and—

paragraphs.original: EGEUS$NEWLINE$(to THESEUS) Enough, enough, my lord. You have enough!$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$I beg the law, the law, upon his head.—$NEWLINE$They would have stol'n away, they would, Demetrius,$NEWLINE$Thereby to have defeated you and me,$NEWLINE$You of your wife and me of my consent,$NEWLINE$Of my consent that she should be your wife.
paragraphs.translated: EGEUS$NEWLINE$(to THESEUS) Enough, enough, my lord. You’ve heard enough evidence! I insist that the law punish him—They were going to run away, Demetrius, they were running away to defeat us, robbing you of your wife and me of my fatherly right to decide who my son-in-law will be.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$(to THESEUS) My lord, fair Helen told me of their stealth,$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Of this their purpose hither to this wood.$NEWLINE$And I in fury hither followed them,$NEWLINE$Fair Helena in fancy following me.
paragraphs.translated: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$(to THESEUS) My lord, the beautiful Helena told me about their secret plan to escape into this forest. I was furious and followed them here, and the lovely Helena was so in love with me that she followed me.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: But, my good lord, I wot not by what power—$NEWLINE$But by some power it is—my love to Hermia,$NEWLINE$Melted as the snow, seems to me now$NEWLINE$As the remembrance of an idle gaud$NEWLINE$Which in my childhood I did dote upon.$NEWLINE$And all the faith, the virtue of my heart,$NEWLINE$The object and the pleasure of mine eye,$NEWLINE$Is only Helena. To her, my lord,$NEWLINE$Was I betrothed ere I saw Hermia.$NEWLINE$But like in sickness did I loathe this food.$NEWLINE$But as in health, come to my natural taste,$NEWLINE$Now I do wish it, love it, long for it,$NEWLINE$And will for evermore be true to it.
paragraphs.translated: I’m not sure how it happened—but somehow, something made my love for Hermia melt away like snow. My past love for Hermia now seems like a memory of some cheap toy I used to love as a child. Now the only person I love, and believe in, and want to look at, is Helena. I was engaged to her before I ever met Hermia. Then I hated her for a time, as a sick person hates the food he usually loves. But now I have my natural taste back, like a sick person when he recovers. Now I want Helena, I love her, I long for her, and I will always be true to her.

paragraphs.original: THESEUS$NEWLINE$Fair lovers, you are fortunately met.$NEWLINE$Of this discourse we more will hear anon.—$NEWLINE$Egeus, I will overbear your will.$NEWLINE$For in the temple by and by with us$NEWLINE$These couples shall eternally be knit.—$NEWLINE$And, for the morning now is something worn,$NEWLINE$Our purposed hunting shall be set aside.$NEWLINE$Away with us to Athens. Three and three,$NEWLINE$We’ll hold a feast in great solemnity.$NEWLINE$Come, Hippolyta.
paragraphs.translated: THESEUS$NEWLINE$You pretty lovers are lucky you met me here. We’ll talk more about this later.—Egeus, I’m overriding your wishes. These couples will be married along with me and Hippolyta in the temple later today.—And now, since the morning is almost over, we’ll give up on the idea of hunting. Come with us to Athens. We three couples will celebrate with a sumptuous feast. Come, Hippolyta.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt THESEUS, HIPPOLYTA, EGEUS, and train$NEWLINE$THESEUS$NEWLINE$HIPPOLYTA$NEWLINE$EGEUS
paragraphs.translated: THESEUS, HIPPOLYTA, and EGEUS exit with their followers.$NEWLINE$THESEUS$NEWLINE$HIPPOLYTA$NEWLINE$EGEUS

paragraphs.original: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$These things seem small and undistinguishable,$NEWLINE$Like far-off mountains turnèd into clouds.
paragraphs.translated: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$What exactly just happened? The events of last night seem small and hard to see clearly, like far-off mountains that look like clouds in the distance.

paragraphs.original: HERMIA$NEWLINE$When everything seems double. Methinks I see these things with parted eye,
paragraphs.translated: HERMIA$NEWLINE$Yes, it’s like my eyes are out of focus, and I’m seeing everything double.

paragraphs.original: HELENA$NEWLINE$So methinks.
paragraphs.translated: HELENA$NEWLINE$Me too.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: And I have found Demetrius like a jewel,$NEWLINE$Mine own, and not mine own.
paragraphs.translated: I won Demetrius so easily, as if he were a precious diamond I just found lying around. It’s mine because I found it, but I feel like someone else could easily come and claim it was hers.

paragraphs.original: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$Are you sure$NEWLINE$That we are awake? It seems to me$NEWLINE$That yet we sleep, we dream. Do not you think$NEWLINE$The duke was here, and bid us follow him?
paragraphs.translated: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$Are you sure we’re awake? It seems to me like we’re still sleeping, still dreaming. Do you remember seeing the duke here? Did he tell us to follow him?

paragraphs.original: HERMIA$NEWLINE$Yea, and my father.
paragraphs.translated: HERMIA$NEWLINE$Yes, he did. And my father was here too.

paragraphs.original: HELENA$NEWLINE$And Hippolyta.
paragraphs.translated: HELENA$NEWLINE$And Hippolyta.

paragraphs.original: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$And he did bid us follow to the temple.
paragraphs.translated: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$And he told us to follow him to the temple.

paragraphs.original: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$Why then, we are awake. Let’s follow him$NEWLINE$And by the way let us recount our dreams.
paragraphs.translated: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$Well, then, we’re awake. Let’s follow him. We can tell one another our dreams along the way.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA$NEWLINE$LYSANDER$NEWLINE$DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$HELENA$NEWLINE$HERMIA
paragraphs.translated: LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA exit.$NEWLINE$LYSANDER$NEWLINE$DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$HELENA$NEWLINE$HERMIA

paragraphs.original: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$(waking) When my cue comes, call me, and I will answer. My next is “Most fair Pyramus.” Heigh-ho! Peter Quince? Flute the bellows-mender? Snout the tinker? Starveling? God’s my life, stol'n hence, and left me asleep? I have had a most rare vision. I have had a dream—past the wit of man to say what dream it was. Man is but an ass if he go about to expound this dream. Methought I was—there is no man can tell what. Methought I was, and methought I had—but man is but a patched fool if he will offer to say what methought I had. The eye of man hath not heard, the ear of man hath not seen, man’s hand is not able to taste, his tongue to conceive, nor his heart to report what my dream was. I will get Peter Quince to write a ballad of this dream.$NEWLINE$(waking)
paragraphs.translated: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$(waking up) Tell me when my cue comes, and I’ll say my line. My next cue is “Most handsome Pyramus.” Hey! Peter Quince? Flute the bellows-repairman? Snout the handyman? Starveling? My God, they’ve all run away and left me sleeping here? What a weird dream I had.—You can’t even describe such a weird dream. You’d be an ass if you even tried to explain it. I thought I was—no, nobody can even describe what I was. I thought I was, I thought I had—but a person would be an idiot to try to say what I thought I had. No eye has ever heard, no ear has ever seen, no hand has tasted, or tongue felt, or heart described what my dream was like. I’ll get Peter Quince to write this dream down as a ballad.$NEWLINE$(waking up)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: It shall be called “Bottom’s Dream” because it hath no bottom. And I will sing it in the latter end of a play before the duke. Peradventure, to make it the more gracious, I shall sing it at her death.
paragraphs.translated: I’ll call it “Bottom’s Dream” because it’s so deep that it has no bottom. And I’ll sing it for the duke in the intermission of a play. Or maybe, to make it even more lovely, I’ll sing it when the heroine dies.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: BOTTOM exits.$NEWLINE$BOTTOM

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter QUINCE, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING$NEWLINE$QUINCE$NEWLINE$FLUTE$NEWLINE$SNOUT$NEWLINE$STARVELING
paragraphs.translated: QUINCE, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING enter.$NEWLINE$QUINCE$NEWLINE$FLUTE$NEWLINE$SNOUT$NEWLINE$STARVELING

paragraphs.original: QUINCE$NEWLINE$Have you sent to Bottom’s house? Is he come home yet?
paragraphs.translated: QUINCE$NEWLINE$Have you sent anyone to Bottom’s house? Has he come home yet?

paragraphs.original: STARVELING$NEWLINE$He cannot be heard of. Out of doubt he is transported.
paragraphs.translated: STARVELING$NEWLINE$No one’s heard from him. I’m sure he’s been kidnapped.

paragraphs.original: FLUTE$NEWLINE$If he come not, then the play is marred. It goes not forward. Doth it?
paragraphs.translated: FLUTE$NEWLINE$If he doesn’t show up, the play is ruined. It won’t go on. Will it?

paragraphs.original: QUINCE$NEWLINE$It is not possible. You have not a man in all Athens able to discharge Pyramus but he.
paragraphs.translated: QUINCE$NEWLINE$No, it would be impossible. He’s the only person in Athens who can play Pyramus.

paragraphs.original: FLUTE$NEWLINE$No, he hath simply the best wit of any handicraft man in Athens.
paragraphs.translated: FLUTE$NEWLINE$Definitely. He’s quite simply the smartest working-man in Athens.

paragraphs.original: QUINCE$NEWLINE$Yea, and the best person too. And he is a very paramour for a sweet voice.
paragraphs.translated: QUINCE$NEWLINE$Yes, and the best looking too. And his voice is the paramour of sweetness.

paragraphs.original: FLUTE$NEWLINE$You must say “paragon.” A “paramour” is, God bless us, a thing of naught.
paragraphs.translated:
FLUTE$NEWLINE$You mean “paragon.” A
“paramour” is something bad.$NEWLINE$“paramour”$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: Enter SNUG$NEWLINE$SNUG
paragraphs.translated: SNUG enters.$NEWLINE$SNUG

paragraphs.original: SNUG$NEWLINE$Masters, the duke is coming from the temple, and there is two or three lords and ladies more married. If our sport had gone forward, we had all been made men.
paragraphs.translated: SNUG$NEWLINE$The duke’s leaving the temple. Two or three more lords and ladies have been married too. If we’d been able to put on our play, we would have had it made.

paragraphs.original: FLUTE$NEWLINE$O sweet bully Bottom! Thus hath he lost sixpence a day during his life. He could not have ’scaped sixpence a day. An the duke had not given him sixpence a day for playing Pyramus, I’ll be hanged.
paragraphs.translated: FLUTE$NEWLINE$Oh that great, funny guy, Bottom! He would have gotten a pension of six pence a day for his whole life. Six pence a day would’ve been forced on him. I’ll be damned if the duke wouldn’t have given him six pence a day for playing Pyramus.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: He would have deserved it. Sixpence a day in Pyramus, or nothing.
paragraphs.translated:
And he would have deserved it too. Pyramus is worth
six pence a day, or it’s worth nothing!$NEWLINE$six pence a day,$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: Enter BOTTOM$NEWLINE$BOTTOM
paragraphs.translated: BOTTOM enters.$NEWLINE$BOTTOM

paragraphs.original: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$Where are these lads? Where are these hearts?
paragraphs.translated: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$Where are my guys? Where are my good fellows?

paragraphs.original: QUINCE$NEWLINE$Bottom! O most courageous day! O most happy hour!
paragraphs.translated: QUINCE$NEWLINE$Bottom! Oh, how wonderful to see you! Oh, what a relief!

paragraphs.original: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$Masters, I am to discourse wonders—but ask me not what, for if I tell you I am no true Athenian. I will tell you everything, right as it fell out.
paragraphs.translated: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$My friends, I’ve got some amazing things to tell you—but don’t ask me to tell you what. I swear by my Athenian citizenship that I won’t tell you anything. I’ll tell you everything exactly as it happened.

paragraphs.original: QUINCE$NEWLINE$Let us hear, sweet Bottom.
paragraphs.translated: QUINCE$NEWLINE$Tell us, Bottom.

paragraphs.original: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$Not a word of me. All that I will tell you is that the duke hath dined. Get your apparel together, good strings to your beards, new ribbons to your pumps. Meet presently at the palace. Every man look o'er his part. For the short and the long is, our play is preferred. In any case, let Thisbe have clean linen. And let not him that plays the lion pair his nails, for they shall hang out for the lion’s claws. And most dear actors, eat no onions nor garlic, for we are to utter sweet breath. And I do not doubt but to hear them say, “It is a sweet comedy.” No more words. Away, go away!
paragraphs.translated: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$No, you won’t get a word out of me. All I’ll tell you is that the duke has had dinner already. Now it’s time to get your costumes together. Find some good strings for tying on your false beards, and grab new ribbons to decorate your shoes. Meet me at the palace as soon as possible. Look over your lines again. Our play’s going to be performed for the duke! So make sure Thisbe’s wearing clean underwear, and make sure whoever’s playing the lion doesn’t cut his nails, because he needs them long to look like lion’s claws. And no one eat any onions or garlic. If we have sweet-smelling breath, I’m sure they’ll say “it’s a sweet play.” Now no more talking. Get busy, go!

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter THESEUS, HIPPOLYTA, and PHILOSTRATE, with other attendant lords$NEWLINE$THESEUS$NEWLINE$HIPPOLYTA$NEWLINE$PHILOSTRATE
paragraphs.translated: THESEUS, HIPPOLYTA, and PHILOSTRATE enter, with a number of lords and servants.$NEWLINE$THESEUS$NEWLINE$HIPPOLYTA$NEWLINE$PHILOSTRATE

paragraphs.original: HIPPOLYTA$NEWLINE$'Tis strange, my Theseus, that these lovers speak of.
paragraphs.translated: HIPPOLYTA$NEWLINE$These lovers are saying some strange things, Theseus.

paragraphs.original: THESEUS$NEWLINE$More strange than true. I never may believe$NEWLINE$These antique fables nor these fairy toys.$NEWLINE$Lovers and madmen have such seething brains,$NEWLINE$Such shaping fantasies, that apprehend$NEWLINE$More than cool reason ever comprehends.$NEWLINE$The lunatic, the lover, and the poet$NEWLINE$Are of imagination all compact.$NEWLINE$One sees more devils than vast hell can hold—$NEWLINE$That is the madman. The lover, all as frantic,$NEWLINE$Sees Helen’s beauty in a brow of Egypt.$NEWLINE$The poet’s eye, in fine frenzy rolling,$NEWLINE$Doth glance from heaven to Earth, from Earth to heaven.$NEWLINE$And as imagination bodies forth$NEWLINE$The forms of things unknown, the poet’s pen$NEWLINE$Turns them to shapes and gives to airy nothing$NEWLINE$A local habitation and a name.$NEWLINE$Such tricks hath strong imagination,$NEWLINE$That if it would but apprehend some joy,$NEWLINE$It comprehends some bringer of that joy.$NEWLINE$Or in the night, imagining some fear,$NEWLINE$How easy is a bush supposed a bear!
paragraphs.translated: THESEUS$NEWLINE$Yes, strange—and totally made up too. I’ll never believe any of these old legends or fairy tales. Lovers and madmen hallucinate about things that sane people just can’t understand. Lunatics, lovers, and poets all are ruled by their overactive imaginations. some people think they see devils and monsters everywhere—and they’re lunatics. Lovers are just as crazy, and think a dark-skinned gypsy is the most gorgeous woman in the world. Poets are always looking around like they’re having a fit, confusing the mundane with the otherworldly, and describing things in their writing that simply don’t exist. All these people have such strong imaginations that, when they feel happy, they assume a god or some other supernatural being is bringing that happiness to them. Or if they’re afraid of something at night, they look at the shrubbery and imagine it’s a wild bear!

paragraphs.original: HIPPOLYTA$NEWLINE$But all the story of the night told over,$NEWLINE$And all their minds transfigured so together,$NEWLINE$More witnesseth than fancy’s images$NEWLINE$And grows to something of great constancy,$NEWLINE$But, howsoever, strange and admirable.
paragraphs.translated: HIPPOLYTA$NEWLINE$But the story that these lovers are telling, and the fact that they all saw and heard exactly the same things, make me think there’s more going on here than imaginary fantasies. Their story is bizarre and astounding, but it’s solid and consistent.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter lovers: LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA$NEWLINE$LYSANDER$NEWLINE$DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$HELENA$NEWLINE$HERMIA
paragraphs.translated: The lovers—LYSANDER, DEMETRIUS, HELENA, and HERMIA—enter.$NEWLINE$LYSANDER$NEWLINE$DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$HELENA$NEWLINE$HERMIA

paragraphs.original: THESEUS$NEWLINE$Here come the lovers, full of joy and mirth.—$NEWLINE$Joy, gentle friends! Joy and fresh days of love$NEWLINE$Accompany your hearts!
paragraphs.translated: THESEUS$NEWLINE$Here come the lovers, laughing happily.—I wish you joy, my friends! I hope the days ahead are full of joy for you.

paragraphs.original: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$More than to us$NEWLINE$Wait in your royal walks, your board, your bed!
paragraphs.translated: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$We wish you even more joy, and hope joy comes to you in your royal walks, at your table, and in your royal bed!

paragraphs.original: THESEUS$NEWLINE$Come now, what masques, what dances shall we have$NEWLINE$To wear away this long age of three hours$NEWLINE$Between our after-supper and bedtime?$NEWLINE$Where is our usual manager of mirth?$NEWLINE$What revels are in hand? Is there no play,$NEWLINE$To ease the anguish of a torturing hour?$NEWLINE$Call Philostrate.
paragraphs.translated: THESEUS$NEWLINE$Now, what kind of entertainment do we have to fill up the long three hours between dinner and bedtime? Where is our entertainment director? What performances have been prepared? Aren’t there any plays for us to enjoy while we wait in torture for bedtime to come? Let me see Philostrate.

paragraphs.original: PHILOSTRATE$NEWLINE$Here, mighty Theseus.
paragraphs.translated: PHILOSTRATE$NEWLINE$Here I am, Theseus.

paragraphs.original: THESEUS$NEWLINE$Say, what abridgement have you for this evening?$NEWLINE$What masque, what music? How shall we beguile$NEWLINE$The lazy time if not with some delight?
paragraphs.translated: THESEUS$NEWLINE$Tell us what entertainment you’ve prepared for the evening. Which plays, what music? How will we pass the time without some entertainment?

paragraphs.original: PHILOSTRATE$NEWLINE$(giving THESEUS a document)$NEWLINE$(giving$NEWLINE$a document)$NEWLINE$There is a brief, how many sports are ripe.$NEWLINE$Make choice of which your highness will see first.
paragraphs.translated: PHILOSTRATE$NEWLINE$(giving THESEUS a piece of paper) Here’s a list of all of the acts that have been prepared. Choose which one you want to see first.$NEWLINE$(giving$NEWLINE$a piece of paper)

paragraphs.original: THESEUS$NEWLINE$(reads)$NEWLINE$(reads)$NEWLINE$“The battle with the Centaurs, to be sung$NEWLINE$By an Athenian eunuch to the harp.”$NEWLINE$We’ll none of that. That have I told my love,$NEWLINE$In glory of my kinsman Hercules.$NEWLINE$“The riot of the tipsy Bacchanals,$NEWLINE$Tearing the Thracian singer in their rage.”$NEWLINE$That is an old device, and it was played$NEWLINE$When I from Thebes came last a conqueror.
paragraphs.translated: THESEUS$NEWLINE$(reading) “The battle between Hercules and the Centaurs, to be sung by an Athenian eunuch, accompanied by a harp.” No, we won’t see that. I’ve already told that story to Hippolyta, while praising my cousin Hercules. What else? “The riot of the drunk Bacchanals who rip the singer Orpheus to shreds.” That’s an old show, and I saw it the last time I came back from conquering$NEWLINE$(reading)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: “The thrice three Muses mourning for the death$NEWLINE$Of learning, late deceased in beggary.”$NEWLINE$That is some satire, keen and critical,$NEWLINE$Not sorting with a nuptial ceremony.$NEWLINE$“A tedious brief scene of young Pyramus$NEWLINE$And his love Thisbe. Very tragical mirth.”$NEWLINE$“Merry” and “tragical”? “Tedious” and “brief”?$NEWLINE$That is hot ice and wondrous strange snow.$NEWLINE$How shall we find the concord of this discord?
paragraphs.translated: Thebes. “The nine Muses mourning the death of learning and scholarship.” That’s some sharp, critical satire, and it’s not appropriate for a wedding. “A tedious short drama about young Pyramus and his love Thisbe, a very sad and tragic comedy.” A sad comedy? Short but still tedious? That’s like hot ice and strange snow. How can this drama be so many contradictory things?

paragraphs.original: PHILOSTRATE$NEWLINE$A play there is, my lord, some ten words long,$NEWLINE$Which is as brief as I have known a play.$NEWLINE$But by ten words, my lord, it is too long,$NEWLINE$Which makes it tedious. For in all the play$NEWLINE$There is not one word apt, one player fitted.$NEWLINE$And tragical, my noble lord, it is.$NEWLINE$For Pyramus therein doth kill himself.$NEWLINE$Which, when I saw rehearsed, I must confess,$NEWLINE$Made mine eyes water—but more merry tears$NEWLINE$The passion of loud laughter never shed.
paragraphs.translated: PHILOSTRATE$NEWLINE$It’s a play about ten words long, which is the shortest play I’ve ever heard of. But in my opinion, it’s about ten words too long. That’s why it’s tedious. In the entire play, not one word is well-written, and not one of the actors is right for his part. It’s tragic because Pyramus kills himself. I have to admit that when I saw his suicide during rehearsal, I had tears in my eyes—but they were tears of laughter.

paragraphs.original: THESEUS$NEWLINE$What are they that do play it?
paragraphs.translated: THESEUS$NEWLINE$Who are the actors?

paragraphs.original: PHILOSTRATE$NEWLINE$Hard-handed men that work in Athens here,$NEWLINE$Which never labored in their minds till now,$NEWLINE$And now have toiled their unbreathed memories$NEWLINE$With this same play against your nuptial.
paragraphs.translated: PHILOSTRATE$NEWLINE$Rough workmen from Athens who never spent much time thinking. Now they’ve worn out their out-of-shape brains to put on this play for your wedding.

paragraphs.original: THESEUS$NEWLINE$And we will hear it.
paragraphs.translated: THESEUS$NEWLINE$So let’s see it.

paragraphs.original: PHILOSTRATE$NEWLINE$No, my noble lord.$NEWLINE$It is not for you. I have heard it over,$NEWLINE$And it is nothing, nothing in the world—$NEWLINE$Unless you can find sport in their intents,$NEWLINE$Extremely stretched and conned with cru 'l pain$NEWLINE$To do you service.
paragraphs.translated: PHILOSTRATE$NEWLINE$No, my noble lord. This play isn’t right for you. I’ve seen the whole thing, and it’s completely worthless—unless you think their bad acting and their misremembered lines—which they memorized so painfully—are funny.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: THESEUS$NEWLINE$I will hear that play.$NEWLINE$For never anything can be amiss$NEWLINE$When simpleness and duty tender it.$NEWLINE$Go, bring them in.—And take your places, ladies.
paragraphs.translated: THESEUS$NEWLINE$I’ll watch this play. Nothing can really be bad when it’s created by simple people who try hard. Come on, bring them in. And sit down, ladies.

paragraphs.original: Exit PHILOSTRATE$NEWLINE$PHILOSTRATE
paragraphs.translated: PHILOSTRATE exits.$NEWLINE$PHILOSTRATE

paragraphs.original: HIPPOLYTA$NEWLINE$I love not to see wretchedness o'er charged$NEWLINE$And duty in his service perishing.
paragraphs.translated: HIPPOLYTA$NEWLINE$I don’t like seeing poor people overburdened or looking bad when they’re trying to do something good.

paragraphs.original: THESEUS$NEWLINE$Why, gentle sweet, you shall see no such thing.
paragraphs.translated: THESEUS$NEWLINE$You won’t see anything like that, sweetheart.

paragraphs.original: HIPPOLYTA$NEWLINE$He says they can do nothing in this kind.
paragraphs.translated: HIPPOLYTA$NEWLINE$He just said that they’re no good at acting.

paragraphs.original: THESEUS$NEWLINE$The kinder we, to give them thanks for nothing.$NEWLINE$Our sport shall be to take what they mistake.$NEWLINE$And what poor duty cannot do, noble respect$NEWLINE$Takes it in might, not merit.$NEWLINE$Where I have come, great clerks have purposèd$NEWLINE$To greet me with premeditated welcomes,$NEWLINE$Where I have seen them shiver and look pale,$NEWLINE$Make periods in the midst of sentences,$NEWLINE$Throttle their practiced accent in their fears,$NEWLINE$And in conclusion dumbly have broke off,$NEWLINE$Not paying me a welcome. Trust me, sweet,$NEWLINE$Out of this silence yet I picked a welcome,$NEWLINE$And in the modesty of fearful duty$NEWLINE$I read as much as from the rattling tongue$NEWLINE$Of saucy and audacious eloquence.$NEWLINE$Love, therefore, and tongue-tied simplicity$NEWLINE$In least speak most, to my capacity.
paragraphs.translated: THESEUS$NEWLINE$Then we’re even kinder people for thanking them for something that they’re not good at. We’ll entertain ourselves by accepting their mistakes. When poor dutiful people can’t do certain things well, generous people can consider the effort they put into it rather than the effect that they produce. In my travels, great scholars have come up to me, meaning to greet me with well-rehearsed welcoming speeches, and I have seen them tremble and turn pale, and pause inappropriately in the middle of their sentences, and botch their well-rehearsed tones of voice because they’re so nervous, and then break off abruptly at the end, without actually welcoming me. Trust me, my sweet, I figured out that they were trying to welcome me even though they were silent, and that message was as clear from someone who was modest and nervously dutiful as it is from someone who is loud and audacious and eloquent. Therefore, love and tongue-tied simplicity can say the most even when they’re saying the least, in my opinion.

paragraphs.translated: PHILOSTRATE enters.$NEWLINE$PHILOSTRATE

paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.translated: PHILOSTRATE$NEWLINE$Your grace, the person who is going to deliver the prologue is ready.

paragraphs.translated: THESEUS$NEWLINE$Let him come forward.

paragraphs.original: PROLOGUE$NEWLINE$(delivered by QUINCE)$NEWLINE$(delivered by$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$If we offend, it is with our good will.$NEWLINE$That you should think we come not to offend,$NEWLINE$But with good will. To show our simple skill,$NEWLINE$That is the true beginning of our end.$NEWLINE$Consider then we come but in despite.$NEWLINE$We do not come as minding to contest you,$NEWLINE$Our true intent is. All for your delight$NEWLINE$We are not here. That you should here repent you,$NEWLINE$The actors are at hand, and by their show$NEWLINE$You shall know all that you are like to know.
paragraphs.translated: PROLOGUE$NEWLINE$If we happen to offend you, it’s because we want to. We don’t want you to think we came here to offend you, except that we want to offend you with our good intentions. Our plan to show off our little bit of talent will wind up getting us executed. Please keep in mind we’re only here out of spite. We don’t come here with the intention of making you happy. We’re absolutely not here to delight you. The actors are ready to come out and make you sorry. By watching their show, you’ll find out everything you’re likely to know.$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: THESEUS$NEWLINE$This fellow doth not stand upon points.
paragraphs.translated: THESEUS$NEWLINE$This guy doesn’t pay much attention to punctuation.

paragraphs.original: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$He hath rid his prologue like a rough colt. He knows not the stop. A good moral, my lord: it is not enough to speak, but to speak true.
paragraphs.translated: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$He rode that prologue like a wild horse. He didn’t know how to stop it. The moral of this story is that it’s not enough to speak; you have to speak grammatically.

paragraphs.original: HIPPOLYTA$NEWLINE$Indeed he hath played on his prologue like a child on a recorder—a sound, but not in government.
paragraphs.translated: HIPPOLYTA$NEWLINE$Yes, he performed his prologue like a child plays a recorder—he can make sounds, but they’re out of control.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: THESEUS$NEWLINE$His speech was like a tangled chain. Nothing impaired, but all disordered. Who is next?
paragraphs.translated: THESEUS$NEWLINE$His speech was like a tangled chain. It went on and on and was a total mess. Who’s next?

paragraphs.original: PROLOGUE$NEWLINE$(delivered by QUINCE)$NEWLINE$(delivered by$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Gentles, perchance you wonder at this show.$NEWLINE$But wonder on, till truth make all things plain.$NEWLINE$This man is Pyramus, if you would know.$NEWLINE$This beauteous lady Thisbe is certain.$NEWLINE$This man, with lime and roughcast, doth present$NEWLINE$Wall, that vile wall which did these lovers sunder.$NEWLINE$And through Wall’s chink, poor souls, they are content$NEWLINE$To whisper. At the which let no man wonder.$NEWLINE$This man, with lanthorn, dog, and bush of thorn,$NEWLINE$Presenteth Moonshine. For, if you will know,$NEWLINE$By moonshine did these lovers think no scorn$NEWLINE$To meet at Ninus' tomb—there, there to woo.$NEWLINE$This grisly beast, which “Lion” hight by name,$NEWLINE$The trusty Thisbe, coming first by night,$NEWLINE$Did scare away, or rather did affright.$NEWLINE$And, as she fled, her mantle she did fall,$NEWLINE$Which Lion vile with bloody mouth did stain.$NEWLINE$Anon comes Pyramus, sweet youth and tall,$NEWLINE$And finds his trusty Thisbe’s mantle slain.$NEWLINE$Whereat, with blade, with bloody blameful blade,$NEWLINE$He bravely broached his boiling bloody breast.$NEWLINE$And Thisbe, tarrying in mulberry shade,$NEWLINE$His dagger drew, and died. For all the rest,$NEWLINE$Let Lion, Moonshine, Wall, and lovers twain$NEWLINE$At large discourse, while here they do remain.
paragraphs.translated: PROLOGUE$NEWLINE$(delivered by QUINCE) Ladies and gentlemen, perhaps you are wondering what is going on. Well, keep wondering, until the truth makes everything clear. This man is Pyramus, if you want to know. This beautiful lady is definitely Thisbe. This man with the limestone and cement is portraying Wall, that horrible wall that kept these lovers apart. They are content to whisper through Wall’s little hole, the poor souls, and no one should be surprised. This man, with his lantern, dog, and thornbush, portrays Moonshine, because, if you want to know, the lovers were not ashamed to meet each other by moonshine at Ninus’s tomb in order to carry on their courtship. This grisly beast, which is called “Lion,” scared away, or rather frightened, the faithful Thisbe when she arrived at the meeting place at night. As she ran away from him, she dropped her cloak, which the horrible Lion stained with his bloody mouth. Soon Pyramus comes along, a tall and handsome young man, and finds his faithful Thisbe’s cloak to be dead. At this point, he takes his sword, his bloody blameful blade, and bravely breaks open his boiling bloody breast. And Thisbe, hiding in the shade of the mulberry bushes, took his dagger and killed herself. For the rest of the story, let Lion, Moonshine, Wall, and the two lovers talk more about it, since they’re standing here.$NEWLINE$(delivered by$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: THESEUS$NEWLINE$I wonder if the lion be to speak.
paragraphs.translated: THESEUS$NEWLINE$I wonder if the lion’s going to talk.

paragraphs.original: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$No wonder, my lord. One lion may when many asses do.
paragraphs.translated: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$It wouldn’t surprise me, my lord. If these asses can speak, a lion should be able to.

The truth is so.$NEWLINE$And this the cranny is, right and sinister,$NEWLINE$Through which the fearful lovers are to whisper.
paragraphs.translated: WALL$NEWLINE$(played by SNOUT) At this point I, Snout, play a wall. But not just any wall. I want you to understand that I’m pretending to be a kind of wall that has a little hole in it. The lovers Pyramus and Thisbe often whispered very secretly through that hole. This clay, this cement, and this stone that I’m carrying around show that I’m that wall. It’s the truth. And this is the crack, right side and left side (points with two fingers), through which the frightened lovers will be whispering.$NEWLINE$(played by$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(points with two fingers)

paragraphs.original: THESEUS$NEWLINE$Would you desire lime and hair to speak better?
paragraphs.translated: THESEUS$NEWLINE$Can you imagine cement and stone talking better?

paragraphs.original: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$It is the wittiest partition that ever I heard discourse, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$It’s the smartest partition I’ve ever heard speak, my lord.

paragraphs.original: THESEUS$NEWLINE$Pyramus draws near the wall. Silence!
paragraphs.translated: THESEUS$NEWLINE$Pyramus is coming up to the wall. Be quiet!

paragraphs.original: PYRAMUS$NEWLINE$(played by BOTTOM)$NEWLINE$(played by$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$O grim-looked night! O night with hue so black!$NEWLINE$O night, which ever art when day is not!$NEWLINE$O night, O night! Alack, alack, alack,
paragraphs.translated: PYRAMUS$NEWLINE$(played by BOTTOM) Oh, grim-looking night! Oh, night that is so black in color! Oh night, which is always there when it is not day! Oh night! Oh night! So sad, sad, sad,$NEWLINE$(played by$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: I fear my Thisbe’s promise is forgot!—$NEWLINE$And thou, O Wall, O sweet, O lovely Wall,$NEWLINE$That stand’st between her father’s ground and mine.$NEWLINE$Thou Wall, O Wall, O sweet and lovely Wall,$NEWLINE$Show me thy chink to blink through with mine eyne!
paragraphs.translated: I’m afraid my Thisbe has forgotten her promise!—And you, oh Wall, oh sweet, oh lovely Wall, you stand between her father’s property and mine, you Wall, oh Wall, oh sweet and lovely Wall. Show me your hole to stick my eye up against!

paragraphs.original: WALL holds up fingers as chink$NEWLINE$WALL
paragraphs.translated: WALL holds up two fingers$NEWLINE$WALL

paragraphs.original: Thanks, courteous Wall. Jove shield thee well for this!$NEWLINE$But what see I? No Thisbe do I see.$NEWLINE$O wicked Wall through whom I see no bliss!$NEWLINE$Cursed be thy stones for thus deceiving me!
paragraphs.translated: Thank you, you’re such a polite wall. God bless you for doing this. But what’s this I see? I don’t see any Thisbe. Oh wicked wall, through which I don’t see any happiness! Damn your stones for disappointing me like this!

paragraphs.original: THESEUS$NEWLINE$The wall, methinks, being sensible, should curse again.
paragraphs.translated: THESEUS$NEWLINE$Since the wall is conscious, it should curse back at him.

paragraphs.original: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$(out of character) No, in truth, sir, he should not. “Deceiving me” is Thisbe’s cue. She is to enter now and I am to spy her through the wall. You shall see, it will fall pat as I told you. Yonder she comes.$NEWLINE$(out of character)
paragraphs.translated: BOTTOM$NEWLINE$(out of character) No, actually, sir, he shouldn’t say anything. It’s not his turn, it’s Thisbe’s. “Disappointing me like this” is Thisbe’s cue. She’s supposed to enter now, and I’ll see her through the wall. You’ll see, it’ll happen exactly like I say. Here she comes.$NEWLINE$(out of character)

paragraphs.translated: THISBE$NEWLINE$(played by FLUTE) Oh wall, you’ve often heard me moaning because you keep me separated from my handsome Pyramus! My cherry lips have often kissed your bricks, which are stuck together with cement.$NEWLINE$(played by$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.translated: THISBE$NEWLINE$But I’m only kissing the wall’s hole, not your lips at all.

paragraphs.original: PYRAMUS$NEWLINE$Wilt thou at Ninny’s tomb meet me straightway?
paragraphs.translated: PYRAMUS$NEWLINE$Will you meet me right away at Ninny’s grave?

paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: THESEUS$NEWLINE$Now is the mural down between the two neighbors.
paragraphs.translated: THESEUS$NEWLINE$The lovers should’ve waited around a little longer—the wall between them is down now.

paragraphs.original: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$No remedy, my lord, when walls are so willful to hear without warning.
paragraphs.translated: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$What can you do? That’s what happens with talking walls.

paragraphs.original: HIPPOLYTA$NEWLINE$This is the silliest stuff that ever I heard.
paragraphs.translated: HIPPOLYTA$NEWLINE$This is the silliest thing I’ve ever seen.

paragraphs.original: THESEUS$NEWLINE$The best in this kind are but shadows, and the worst are no worse if imagination amend them.
paragraphs.translated: THESEUS$NEWLINE$The best plays are still only illusions, and the worst are just as good, if you just use your imagination to fill them in.

paragraphs.original: HIPPOLYTA$NEWLINE$It must be your imagination then, and not theirs.
paragraphs.translated: HIPPOLYTA$NEWLINE$In that case it’s your imagination that’s interesting, not the play.

paragraphs.original: THESEUS$NEWLINE$If we imagine no worse of them than they of themselves, they may pass for excellent men. Here come two noble beasts in, a man and a lion.
paragraphs.translated: THESEUS$NEWLINE$If we imagine these guys as they imagine themselves, then they’re first-class actors. Look, here come two noble animals, a man and a lion.

paragraphs.original: THESEUS$NEWLINE$A very gentle beast, of a good conscience.
paragraphs.translated: THESEUS$NEWLINE$Ah, it’s a sensitive animal, with a good conscience.

paragraphs.original: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$A very best at a beast, my lord, that e'er I saw.

paragraphs.translated: THESEUS$NEWLINE$True. And as wise as a goose.

paragraphs.translated: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$Oh, that’s not true, my lord. He’s not brave enough to be wise.

paragraphs.translated: THESEUS$NEWLINE$He’s not wise enough to be brave. Anyway, he is what he is. Let’s listen to the moon.

paragraphs.translated: HIPPOLYTA$NEWLINE$I’m tired of this moon. I wish he’d wax or wane off the stage.

paragraphs.translated: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$Well, all of these should be in the lantern, because they’re all in the moon. But be quiet, here comes Thisbe.

paragraphs.translated: PYRAMUS$NEWLINE$Sweet Moon, I thank you for your sunny beams. I thank you, Moon, for shining now so bright, because by the light of your gracious, golden, glittering gleams, I hope to be able to see my faithful Thisbe.—But wait. Oh no! But, look, poor me, what a terrible tragedy is here! Eyes, do you see? How can it be? Oh, dainty duck! Oh, dear! Your cloak so good, what, stained with blood? Come, terrible Furies, and punish whoever has hurt her! Oh, Fate, come and cut the thread of my life. Conquer, crush, conclude, and kill!

paragraphs.original: THESEUS$NEWLINE$This passion and the death of a dear friend would go near to make a man look sad.
paragraphs.translated: THESEUS$NEWLINE$You could get sad watching this actor’s passionate lament—if one of your good friends happened to die right at the same time.

paragraphs.original: HIPPOLYTA$NEWLINE$Beshrew my heart, but I pity the man.
paragraphs.translated: HIPPOLYTA$NEWLINE$Damned if I don’t feel sorry for him.

paragraphs.translated:
PYRAMUS$NEWLINE$Oh, Mother Nature, why did you create lions? A mean and awful lion has
deflowered my darling, who is—no, no, who was the most beautiful lady who ever lived, or loved, or liked, or looked. Come on, tears, pour over me! paragraphs.translated: THESEUS$NEWLINE$With a doctor’s help he might recover and become an ass again.

paragraphs.translated: THESEUS$NEWLINE$She’ll see him by starlight. Here she comes. Her moaning and groaning will end the play.

paragraphs.translated: DEMETRIUS$NEWLINE$I can’t decide whether Pyramus or Thisbe is better. God help us if he’s a better man. But God help us if she’s a better woman.

paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.translated: LYSANDER$NEWLINE$Look, she’s spotted him with those sweet eyes of hers.
